data.subject: ACG
data.name: ACC Decisions
data.description: Accounting concepts and analysis essential to determining the income and financial position of a business enterprise. Prerequisite: a) MAC 1105 or equivalent or higher-level course with a grade of 'C' or higher; and b) Minimum 30 credits earned; and (c) Business students only

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Intro ACG
data.description: Introduction to the principles used in measuring organization activities. For non-business majors only. Prerequisite:  (a) Business Minors or (b) Project Management Minors or (c) Biological Sciences (Bioentrepreneur Track) Majors or (d) Bachelor of Health Service Administration (e) BS in Construction Management, or (f) Mathematics (Business Track) Majors

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Managerial Accounting
data.description: Use of accounting concepts, analysis, and financial data to aid in the evaluation of the business enterprise; and to aid management in its planning, organizing, and controlling functions. Prerequisites: a) College of Business students with ACG 2021, or equivalent with a grade of 'C' or higher, or b) Bachelor of Health Services Administration students with ACG 3024, or equivalent, with a grade of 'C' or higher.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Financl Acc I
data.description: Underlying concepts and ethical, regulatory and business environment of financial reporting with emphasis on measurement, analysis and interpretation of income, cash flows and financial position. Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C' or higher in (a) QMB3003 or MAC2233 or (any Calculus 1 course or higher); and (b) ACG3301 or equivalent c) 60 credits earned d) qualifying Accounting Entrance Exam score and GPA (BUEE only).

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Financl Acc II
data.description: Underlying concepts and ethical, regulatory, and business environment of financial reporting with emphasis on measurement, analysis and interpretation of financial position.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Mgmt Accounting
data.description: Determination and control of production costs; job order and process systems; actual and standard costs; budgetary control; performance measurement; ethics; short-run decision models.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Acctg Info Systems
data.description: The study of the concepts and terminology of accounting information systems and the use of IT to and decision making in accounting and auditing. Prerequisites: (a) QMB3003 or MAC2233 or (any Calculus 1 or higher course), and (b) ACG3301 or equivalent, (c) 60 credits earned, and (d) qualifying BAcc Entrance Exam score and GPA (BUEE only).

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Auditing
data.description: Standards and procedures of auditing financial information, ethics and responsibilities of auditors, collection and documentation of audit evidence, reporting and international auditing standards. Must be taken in the last semester of the student's program.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Thry & Rsrch In Actg
data.description: An evaluative overview of the classical literature in financial accounting and the contemporary empirical research published in the leading scholarly journals. Examined are income determination theories, normative accounting principles, accounting information and stock prices, and principal-agent relationships. Prerequisite: Permission of Doctoral advisor in Accounting.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Pos Thry Resch In Ac
data.description: Construction of theory to explain accounting and auditing practices in an environment of regulation using empirical research findings from a growing body of economic-based research in accounting and finance. Prerequisite: Permission of doctoral advisor in Accounting.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Supervised accounting research projects determined by professor and student. May involve conferences, supervised reading and reports. Consent of sponsoring professor and admission to the Ph.D. program.

data.subject: ACG
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Original research that is supervised by a faculty committee and defended openly before the university committee. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Org Lrng and HRD
data.description: Developing rationale and philosophy of human resource development and understanding theories of workplace and organizational learning.  Understanding and applying models of organizational learning.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Writing for Publ
data.description: Students develop an understanding of the scholarly writing process and produce scholarly work for submission.  Topics include topic selection and manuscript organization, preparation, and review.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Inst Dev And Impl
data.description: The course includes the following: 1. a systematic approach to developing instructional materials and strategies appropriate to adult and organizational needs and 2. implementation strategies including instructional delivery skills for adult learning. Prerequisite: ADE 5383 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Adult Teach Methods
data.description: Students explore adult teaching philosophy and methods and prepare to teach in a variety of adult learning environments such as higher education, community education, ABE, TESOL and adult literacy.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Computer Based Trng
data.description: This is a basic course in computer based instruction and training which includes the application of instructional design to CBT, and proficiency in an authoring software. Prerequisites: ADE 5383 and working knowledge of personal computers are recommended.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Dir Stud Ade/Hrd
data.description: This is a course of specialized intensive study in areas of interest to the student. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Teaching Practicum
data.description: With faculty supervision, students deliver instruction to acquire teaching experience in an adult education environment such as higer education, community education, ABE, TESOL or adult literacy.

data.subject: ADE
data.name: Ed.D. Dissertation
data.description: This course focuses on research for doctoral dissertation for those students approved for candidacy in the Adult Education/Human Resource Development Program. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Principles Of Adv
data.description: Comprehensive survey of basic principles and practices of advertising emphasizing creative/media strategy decision processes and historical, social, economic, and social influences.

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Creative Concepts
data.description: Familiarization with the creative process and creative problem solving techniques. Emphasis on group work, brainstorming and idea generation. Will formulate strategies using all communication tools. Prerequisite: MMC 3123 or COM 3714, ADV 3008 or PUR 3000, VIC 3400, MMC 3003 or PUR 1951

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Advertising and Society
data.description: The relationship between advertising, economic, political and ethical issues.

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Media Planning
data.description: Planning, execution, and control of advertising media programs. Emphasis on characteristics of the media, buying and selling processes, and methods and techniques used in campaign planning. Prerequisites: ADV 3008 or PUR 3000, ADV 3200

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Branding and Social Media
data.description: This course will develop students understanding of the importance of brand equity; how to build, measure and manage brand equity with digital/social media; how to construct the best digital content and distribution strategy to tell a brand's story.

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Bold Practicum 2
data.description:
This course is the second semester option of PUR 4940, which operates as
a student-run agency under faculty supervision. In this advanced course
students will learn the workings of a professional agency working with
real clients.

data.subject: ADV
data.name: Media Planning
data.description: This course is intended to be a survey of the media planning discipline of advertising.

data.subject: AEB
data.name: Farm Econ Management
data.description: The application of economic principles to farm management, budgeting techniques, farm financial and risk analysis, and marketing plan. Covers farm management strategies for sustainable farming.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Black Pop Cult Global Dim
data.description: In-depth examination of key issues including black popular cultures in global perspectives with a focus on historical processes, race, racialization, gender, sexuality, language, religion and identity.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Global Hip Hop
data.description: Examines the global, transnational and Africana dimensions of Hip Hop.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Hip Hop Race Gen Sex
data.description: Examination of sexual, gender and racial/ethnic identity constructions in Hip Hop cultures both in United States and globally.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Student-generated research projects in African and African Diaspora studies. Independent investigations, reports on individual and assigned readings with AADS core and affiliated faculty.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Anws Teach Institute
data.description: Offers teachers' Institute on literature, culture, history, politics designed to meet Florida State Teachers Certification requirements which includes instruction on pedagogy.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Student generated research projects in African and African Diaspora Studies. Independent investigation, reports on individual and assigned reading with AADS core and affiliated faculty.

data.subject: AFA
data.name: AADS Graduate Colloq
data.description: Colloquia, symposia, lectures, conferences presented by faculty, visiting scholars, and graduate students on topics of current research interest. May be repeated with departmental approval.

data.subject: AFH
data.name: African Civ
data.description: Examines key developments of African civilizations.

data.subject: AFH
data.name: Hist South Africa
data.description: Examines the development of the South African nation in terms of its African and European heritage from the early Khoisan societies through apartheid and Mandela's election.

data.subject: AFR
data.name: Heritage and Values II
data.description: Survey and follow on course to AFR 1101 designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer I raining Corps. Featured topics include:The Air Force Core Values, mission and organization structure, military customs and courtesies, dress and appearance, team building, AF Operations, Making policy and Strategy, Air Force Power through WWI, career opportunities for officers, communication skill development, and more.

data.subject: AFR
data.name: Team & Leadership Fund II
data.description: AFR 2131 is a continuation of Team and Leadership Fundamentals I and provides students a leadership mindset. Features topics include: The US Constitution, Civilian Control of the Military, Air and Space System Capabilities and Introduction to Leadership Theory. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course by providing cadets with followership experiences.

data.subject: AFR
data.name: Leading and Comm II
data.description: AFR 3230 is designed to build on the leadership fundamentals taught in AFR 2130 and AFR 2131. The theme of this year is 'Leading People and Effective Communication.' You will have the opportunity to utilize your skills as they begin more of a leadership role in the detachment. The goal is for each of you to have a more in-depth understanding of how to effectively lead people, and this semester will provide some of the tools to apply in detachment leadership roles. A mandatory Leadership Laboratory complements this course by providing advanced leadership experiences, giving students the opportunity to apply the leadership and management principles of this course.

data.subject: AFR
data.name: Security, Res & Com Prep II
data.description: AFR 4210 is an examination of the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership ethics, and Air Force doctrine. Special topics of interest focus on the military as a profession, officership, military justice, civilian control of the military, preparation for active duty, and current issues affecting military professionalism with a continuing emphasis on the refinement of communication skills.

data.subject: AFS
data.name: Latn Amer Caribbean Africa
data.description: An introduction to the historical and dynamic relationships that have unfolded since the 1500s between Latin America and the Caribbean, on one side, and Sub-Saharan Africa on the other.

data.subject: AGG
data.name: Agriculture Internship
data.description: Practical experience by working or conducting research at a farm, field, or private or government agency on topics related to food and agriculture with approval of faculty supervisor. May be repeated. (Pass/Fail only) Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.

data.subject: AGR
data.name: Mod Crop Pro
data.description: Basic of various agronomic crops, how they related to environment, what are the principles of production, management of problems, and the utilization of crops.

data.subject: AGR
data.name: Adv Mod Crop Pro
data.description: An advance course in agronomy applying crop, soil, and environmental sciences in understanding agricultural systems in the world. Includes the concepts of plant, seed, water, soil, tillage, pest, post harvest, ecophysiology, and sustainable aspects of crop production.

data.subject: AGR
data.name: Sustainable Farming Syst
data.description: Analysis of sustainability of modern agricultural farming systems under a variety of ecological economic and cultural settings.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Amer Hist Since 1877
data.description: Survey of American history since 1877 including such topics as industrialization, political reform, experiences in war, social conflict, and changing conceptions of the meaning of democracy.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Mod Amer Civ
data.description: Examines the development of the United States from the early republic to the present. Topics include society, culture, politics and economics. Written work meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: America & Movies
data.description: An examination of the social and cultural history of 20th century America through its movies.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Age Of Jefferson
data.description: A survey of Jeffersonian America (1790-1828) with emphasis on the origins of American politics, the emerging American economy, the rise of American nationalism, and Jeffersonian mind.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: African-Amer Hist
data.description: Black society in the United States and its relation to the political, economic, social, and cultural history of America.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Race, Gender, Science
data.description: Examines the ways in which scientists and physicians in the Atlantic World categorized, defined, and assigned meaning to racial and gendered differences.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Rdgs In Amer Hist
data.description: Students read books from different historiographical traditions and with conflicting interpretations about an important subject in American history. Subjects will vary according to professor. Course may be repeated with departmental approval. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: AMH
data.name: Rsch Amer Hist II
data.description: Semester two of a two-semester research seminar investigating topics in American history. Topics may vary.May be repeated with approval of Graduate Program Director.

data.subject: AML
data.name: AM Lit 1492-Present
data.description: Survey of American fiction, poetry, and drama from 1492 to the present, that examines the interactions between literacy texts and social, cultural, or political currents.

data.subject: AML
data.name: Modern Amer Poetry
data.description: Study of American poetry written in the twentieth century. Among the poets to be examined are Elizabeth Bishop, Gwendolyn Brooks and Richard Wilbur.

data.subject: AML
data.name: Modernism In Am Lit
data.description: The course provides working definitions of modernism and post-modernism and will consider how the writers of the twentieth century use those outlooks while addressing political, social, and personal issues.

data.subject: AML
data.name: 19C African-Am Lit
data.description: An examination of literary works written by African Americans during the 19th Century. May be repeated with change of content.

data.subject: AML
data.name: Periods Amer Lit
data.description: The literature and criticism regarding one specified period of American literature, such as colonial, federal, transcendental, antebellum, or twentieth century. May be repeated with change of content. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Environm Anthro
data.description: Theories of human adaptation, including environmental determinism, possibilism, cultural ecology, materialism, and evolutionary ecology. Credit for both ANT 3403 and ANT 5548 will not be granted. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Directed Ind Study
data.description: Supervised readings and/or field research and training. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Directed Field Resea
data.description: Permission of the instructor required.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Theory in Anthropology
data.description: Examines the relationship between theory and research in the social sciences, focusing on the historical, contemporary, and philosophical foundations of anthropological thought.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Doctoral Exam Preparation
data.description: Preparation for the preliminary doctoral exam under the direction of a faculty member. Hours may vary. Prerequisite: Permission of major professor.

data.subject: ANG
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Completion of doctoral dissertation. Hours may vary. Prerequisite: Permission of major professor and doctoral candidacy.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Intro Anthropology
data.description: This course surveys the four subfields of anthropology, including physical anthropology and human evolution, archaeology, cultural anthropology, and linguistics. Introduces basic anthropological theories and concepts.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Anthro Theory
data.description: This course examines the process of theory building and explanation in the social sciences, and outlines the historical and philosophical foundations of anthropological thought. Theorists and schools of thought reviewed include Darwin and evolution; Boas and historical particularism; Freud and culture and personality; and Malinowski and functionalism.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: World Ethnographies
data.description: Introduces students to ethnography, which is the art of writing culture.  Teaches students to compare and contrast cultures through ethnographic reading, writing, and critiques.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Myth-Ritual-Mysticis
data.description: Anthropological approaches to the study of myth, ritual, and mysticism, as religious and symbolic systems. The social and psychological functions of myth and ritual in small-scale and complex societies will be compared.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Sex, Gender, & Culture
data.description: Cross-cultural ethnographic data will be utilized to examine the enculturation of sex roles, attitudes, and behavior; cultural definitions of maleness and femaleness; and varieties of human sexual awareness and response.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Ant Race/Ethnicity
data.description: Considers ethnicity and concepts of race in cross-cultural perspectives with emphasis on the historical and cultural and construction of identity, intercultural relationships, and social stratification.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Intro Qual Research Meth
data.description: Introduction to qualitative data collection, analysis, and documentation.  Fieldwork experiences include observation, interviewing, and utilizing non-obtrusive measures.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Language And Culture
data.description: Examines the relationship between language and culture, with emphasis on the linguistic structuring of perception and culture; speech styles and their relationship to the identities and inequalities associated with gender, class and ethnicity; and the politics of bilingualism and multilingual nations.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Latin America
data.description: Examines cultures and societies of the Latin American region.  Topics may include indigenous and peasant cultures, social movements, urban and global transformations, and class, gender and ethnicity.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Psychedelics and Culture
data.description: Multidisciplinary survey of role of psychedelics in shamanism and world religions, and in research on addiction, depression, creativity and spirituality.

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Visual Methods Research
data.description: Provides conceptual and methodological tools for incorporating visual techniques, particularly documentary film, photographs, and the PhotoVoice approach, into interdisciplinary research. Prerequisite: SYA 3000

data.subject: ANT
data.name: Directed Ind Study
data.description: Supervised readings and/or field research and training. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: APK
data.name: Exercise Physiology
data.description: Immediate physiological responses to exercise and the long-term adaptations that occur as a result of training.

data.subject: APK
data.name: Sport Psychology
data.description: Concepts related to the psychological aspects surrounding sport performance will be discussed. Required course in the Undergraduate Sport Management Track.

data.subject: APK
data.name: Exercise Psychophysiology
data.description: This course provides an introduction to exercise psychophysiology and neuroscience. Emphasis will be on perceptual, psychological, and psychophysiological responses to exercise and sport tasks.

data.subject: ARA
data.name: Arabic I
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: ARA
data.name: Arabic II
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Design Graphics 2
data.description: A continuation of Design graphics I with the exploration of broader graphic tools of conceptual representation.  Subject areas emphasize computer graphics and multiple media.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Design Studio 2
data.description: A continuation of Design 1 (ARC 1301). An introduction to principles of proportion and scale with an emphasis on the relationship between the body and three dimensional space. The design process is emphasized.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Design Studio 4
data.description: A continuation of design studio 3 structure, material, design details, human factors and interior architecture are explored for small scale infill urban buildings project.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Des Hist Ant To Ma
data.description: Survey of architectural, interior, and landscape design from antiquity to the Middle Ages, including western and non-western traditions. Critical reading and writing course.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Des Hist Ren To Xix
data.description: Survey of architectural, interior, and landscape design from the Renaissance to the XIX century, including western and non-western traditions.  Critical reading and writing course.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 1
data.description: Through the study of statics and strength of materials this course provides a scientific basis for understanding structural systems behavior. Completion of ARC 2580 will meet this course requirement.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 1 Lab
data.description: The lab sessions will supplement lectures through additional practice and hands-on problems designed to enhance the application of structural concepts. Completion of ARC 2580 meets requirement.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Form Stud 2
data.description: A continuation of architectural design investigations begun in Formative Studio.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Comp Prac In Des II
data.description: Advanced study in concepts, issues and methods in computer-aided architectural design.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Arch Design 6
data.description: This studio focuses on housing and related components including the repetitive spatial and structural elements, circulation and contextual considerations. Prerequisite: ARC 5329

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Arch Design 8
data.description: Architectural design explorations of site, building codes, community objectives will be undertaken through individual programming, process and design initiatives for a complex building project. Prerequisite: ARC 5340

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Arch Design 9: Sust Prac
data.description: Architectural projects of medium scale. Exploration and application of sustainable practices emphasizing relation of site and environmental issues to architectural production and design methodology. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and ARC 5361.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Mat Meth of Const
data.description: Study of the types of construction and materials used in institutional, residential, and office building assemblies. How materials are installed and inspected, including the use of special equipment. Explorations of the theories and histories of construction will be explored.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 3
data.description: This is the third course in the structures sequence. It is focused on analysis and design of reinforced concrete structures and lateral resistive systems. Prerequisite: ARC 5554.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 3 Lab
data.description: The lab sessions will supplement lectures through additional practice and hands-on problems that are designed to enhance the application of structural concepts. Prerequisite: ARC 5554. Corequisite: ARC 5555.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 1
data.description: Through the study of statics and strength of materials this course provides a scientific basis for understanding structural systems behavior. Prerequisites: PHY 2053 and MAC 2233 or MAC 1114 or MAC 1147.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Structures 1 Lab
data.description: The lab sessions will supplement lectures through additional practice and hands-on problems that are designed to enhance the application of structural concepts. Prerequisites: PHY 2053 and MAC 2233 or MAC 1114 or MAC 1147. Corequisite: ARC 5582.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Envir Systems in Arch 2
data.description: This course considers the role of acoustic and luminous behaviors in architecture and the architectural design process. Topics including daylighting, artificial lighting, electrical systems and acoustics.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Des Hist Ren to XIX
data.description: Survey of architectural, interior, and landscape design from the Renaissance to the nineteenth century, including Western and non-Western traditions. Explorations of related and causal ideologies will be covered in lectures, readings, and student assignments.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Coursework on a particular aspect of architecture under the direction of faculty in a classroom format.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Internship Experience
data.description: Experience in architectural practice learned through work with licensed professionals.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Architecture Internship
data.description: Advanced issues in architecture practice learned through work experience with licensed professionals.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Theories of the Digital
data.description: This course explores theories of the digital. The aim is to develop a theoretical framework to understand the impact of the digital on architectural design, fabrication and urban life. Prerequisite: Admission to the doctoral program.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Miami Urban Studies
data.description:
Studies concerning the social, political, economic and environmental of Urbanism in
Southern Florida in general and Miami in particular. Prerequisite: Admission into the Doctoral Program.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Coursework on a particular aspect of Architecture under the direction of faculty in an individual study format.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: ARE Preparation
data.description: Preparation to take the Architect Registration Exam. Prerequisite: ARC 5361 and ARC 5483

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Masters Project
data.description: Coursework under the direction of faculty for the completion of project by candidate for the degree of Master of Architecture. Prerequisite: ARC 5361, ARC 6356, ARC 5555, ARC 5621, ARC 5744, ARC 5205, ARC 5176

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Doctoral Project
data.description:
Coursework under the direction of faculty for the completion of the Doctoral
Project by a candidate for the degree of Doctorate of Design.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Adv Research Methods
data.description:
Advanced methods of data acquisition, analysis, and interpretation used in
architectural research.

data.subject: ARC
data.name: Doctoral Defense
data.description: The formal presentation of the Doctoral Project. Prerequisite: ARC 7980, 12 credits, Corequisite: ARC 7980, 9 credits.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Teach Elem Art
data.description: Knowledge and skills for the development and implementation of art experiences in the elementary curriculum for the elementary classroom teacher. Lab fee required.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Sp. Teach. Lab: Art K-5
data.description: Development of instructional skills, techniques, and strategies for teaching art in the elementary school. Laboratory and field participation required.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Sp. Teach. Lab: Art 6-12
data.description: Development of instructional skills, techniques, and strategies for teaching art in the middle and senior high school. Laboratory and field participation required. Lab fee required.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Student Tchg In Art
data.description: Supervised teaching in an elementary and secondary school.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Practicum: Art Ed
data.description: Supervised teaching in a junior or senior high school.

data.subject: ARE
data.name: Curr Instruction Art
data.description: Examination of theoretical bases of curriculum development in art education. Analysis of objectives, content, methods, and materials for art instruction in the elementary, junior, and senior high school.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Exploring Art
data.description: Offers an introductory, non-chronological approach to the understanding and appreciation of art.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Art Hist. Survey I
data.description: A broad survey of the visual arts and architecture from the Paleolithic Period through the Middle Ages.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Art Hist. Survey II
data.description: A broad survey of the visual arts and architecture from the Renaissance through the Modern Age.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Baroque Art
data.description: European art of the 17th and early 18th centuries. Artists to be considered include Bernini, Caravaggio, Velazquez, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Rubens, Poussin, La Tour, and Watteau.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Intro African Arts
data.description: Examines the continuities between African arts and the arts of African Diaspora. It traces the visual arts from the earliest cave paintings in Africa to the latest Hip-Hop arts in the United States.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Later Italian Ren
data.description: A study of the late 15th and 16th century Italian art, with emphasis on the High Renaissance and Mannerism. Artists to be considered include Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Andrea del Sarto, Giorgione, Titian, Pontormo, and Parmigianino.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Art And Politics
data.description: An investigation into the interrelationship between art and political issues, with emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Modern Art
data.description: A survey of European and American art from 1890-1945.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Contemporary Art
data.description: A survey of art from 1945 to the present.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: African Arts
data.description: A study of the visual arts in Africa from the ancient world to the present. It focuses on the historical transformation and regional variability in art forms and their meanings on the Continent.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Arts China and Japan
data.description: This course is an introduction to and overview of the arts of China and Japan from antiquity to present covering a wide range of media in their historical, philosophical and religious contexts.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Chinese Painting
data.description: In examination of the social history of Chinese painting, this course looks into masters, masterpieces and art patrons of the last 3000 years.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Hist Photo Since 45
data.description: An examination of the most significant photographic works, critical concepts, and new trends which have arisen since WWII.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: History of Digital Art
data.description: A chronological examination of the work of the world's most significant digital works in the visual arts 1900 to present.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Research
data.description: Art history, criticism, and theory in areas not covered by the present program and that the student wishes to study. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor. May be repeated.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Internship
data.description: Students will work under supervision of the Art department. Permission number is required before registering, 60 hours per semester minimum.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Art History Thesis
data.description: Required for art history majors. Students will research a topic and prepare a serious quality paper.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Baroque Art
data.description: Baroque art and architecture of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in europe. slide lectures and discussions, advanced research required.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Contemporary Art
data.description: Course examines the visual arts in Europe and the U.S. from the 1960's to the present with focus on major art movements, artists, and artwork.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Arts of China and Japan
data.description: This course is an introduction to and overview of the arts of China and Japan from antiquity to present covering a wide range of media in their historical, philosophical and religious contexts.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Chinese Painting
data.description: In examination of the social history of Chinese painting, this course looks into masters, masterpieces and art patrons of the last 3000 years.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Hist Photo Since 45
data.description: An examination of the most significant photographic works, critical concepts, and new trends which have arisen since WWII.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Advanced Art and Politics
data.description: The course explores the political role of art in Europe and Latin America from ancient Greece to the present. It also traces how the idea of the 'political' changed from the ancient to modern periods. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Research
data.description: Art history, criticism, and theory in areas not covered by the present program and which the student wishes to study. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor. May be repeated.

data.subject: ARH
data.name: Internship Exper
data.description: Supervised work experience in approved institution. Prerequisite: Permission of Director of Museum Studies.  May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: 2d Design
data.description: Studio course introducing the basic art elements such as line, value, and color to develop the students vocabulary and awareness of two-dimensional potential in various media.

data.subject: ART
data.name: 3d Design
data.description: Studio course introducing the basic elements inherent in three-dimensional works of art. Shape, mass, balance, proportion, and scale are elements which will be explored.

data.subject: ART
data.name: 3D Animation
data.description: This course will introduce students to the fundamental terminology, concepts, and techniques of creating computer generated 3D animation. Prerequisites:  ART 1201C, ART 1203C, ART 2300C, ART 3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: 2D Animation
data.description: This course will introduce students to the fundamental terminology, concepts, and techniques of creating traditional and computer generated 2D animation. Prerequisites:  ART 1201C, ART 1203C, ART 2300C, ART 3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: Beginning Drawing
data.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of drawing. The course equips the student with a variety of basic skills, approaches and concepts explored through a comprehensive range of media.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Begin Figure Drawing
data.description: Drawing from model. Student will study gesture, movement, form, volume, light, and other varied media.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Begin Printmaking
data.description: Introduces the student to a number of processes. Explores primarily one of the following: etching, lighography or screen printing with excursions into relief collograph, monotype and color as appropriate.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Beginning Painting
data.description: Introduction to development of expression, through individual understanding of tools, materials, technique, perception and vocabulary of painting.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Digital Imaging
data.description: This is an introduction to digital image manipulation.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Digital Media
data.description: A dynamic, inter-disciplinary approach to the creation of video art and interactive media work. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intro Video Art
data.description: Introduction to basic practices of video media with emphasis on making video/audio work. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intro Digital Art Lab
data.description: An introduction in the basic practices of new media for making digital art. Prerequisite: ART1201C, ART1203C, ART2300C, ART3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: Beginning Sculpture
data.description: Beginning sculpture students will be given assigned problems structured to study the forms in nature and the work of other sculptors.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Beginning Ceramics
data.description: A beginning course for art and non-art majors that introduces the fundamentals of throwing and glaze applications. Prerequisites:  ART 1201C, ART 1203C, ART 2300C, ART 3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intro Arts Marketing
data.description: Introduction to marketing communication and tools; considers business management concerns for the current art practice organization. Completion of this course results in a digital portfolio.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Animation
data.description: A continued study in the practices of animation for making digital art.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Drawing
data.description: Further development of technical drawing skills. Focus is on experimentation with various materials and processes, with an emphasis on personal direction. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Figure Drawing
data.description: Further exploration of the live human figure as it determines our understanding of subject, theme, composition and meaning. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Interm Printmaking
data.description: Exploration and expansion of experimental print processes as they relate to student's own imagery and acquired skills. Greater independence and personal direction. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Painting
data.description: Intermediate painting with expectation of an extended practice in observational live model painting and exploration of meaning of materials and techniques. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Figure Painting
data.description: Development of perceptual and technical painting skills in figure painting. Emphasis will be given to the understanding of the figure palette as well as medium applications. Prerequisite: ART 1201C, ART 2300C, ART 2500C

data.subject: ART
data.name: Begin Fiber Based Art
data.description: Introduces the technology of creating imagery on and with the use of clothing, thread, printmaking, ink, and photography. May be repeated. Prerequisites:  ART 1201C, ART 1203C, ART 2300C, ART 3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: Portrait Painting
data.description: Development of perceptual and technical painting skills in portraiture. Emphasis will be given to the understanding of the portrait palette as well as medium applications. Prerequisites: ART 2500C and ART 3335C

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Ex Video
data.description: A continued study in the basic practices of video media with emphasis on video/audio work.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Story Development
data.description: This class explores methods of storytelling focusing on narrative and character development. Relate traditional mediums and technology to contemporary art production. Prerequisites:  ART 1201C, ART 1203C, ART 2300C, ART 3820

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Sculpture
data.description: Intermediate sculpture is structured for the student who has acquired basic skills and is ready to test their creative abilities through individualized projects. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermediate Ceramics
data.description: Intermediate ceramics is designed for the student who has acquired the fundamental skills taught in basic ceramics. Projects are designed to advance technical skills and aesthetic growth. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Research & Development
data.description: VT1 explores media/techniques based practice and introduces global theories, content-based practices, studio disciplines, and the ability to assess their own art practice in a global context.  For Visual Arts majors only

data.subject: ART
data.name: Creative Practice
data.description: An advanced studio-based course with a strong theoretical component where concepts are examined through a variety of approaches and media.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Drawing
data.description: Students are expected to possess an accomplished level of skills and strong personal direction in order to focus on the development of a consistent body of personal work. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Figure Drawing
data.description: Students are expected to possess a developed level of skill in drawing the figure and a strong personal direction. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Printmaking
data.description: Instructional emphasis will be toward individual solutions. Student expected to independently research technical problems. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Painting
data.description: Advanced painting with expectation of intense observational practice with a live model, and further investigation into technical and material exploration along with conceptual issues. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Adv. Portrait Painting
data.description: Further development of perceptual and technical painting skills in portraiture. Emphasis will be given to the visual articulation of color temperature, textural and spatial qualities. May be repeated. Prerequisites: ART 3569C

data.subject: ART
data.name: Figure Painting
data.description: This course is designed for students to learn the fundamental skills and knowledge of figure painting. Studio projects will help students understand the basics of painting from life.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intmd. Fiber Based Art
data.description: Covers fiber based techniques as applied to the context of contemporary art practices. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Animation
data.description: An advanced study in the practices of animation for making digital art.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Video Art
data.description: Advanced aesthetic, conceptual, and technical aspects of visual electronic media. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Intermed Digital Art Lab
data.description: A continued study in the basic practices of new media for making digital art.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Adv Digital Art Lab
data.description: This is an advanced investigation of digital arts.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Sculpture
data.description: Advanced sculpture is structured for students who have acquired intermediate skills and are ready to test their technical skills and conceptual growth beyond the intermediate level. May be repeated. Prerequisite: ART 2710C, ART 3710C

data.subject: ART
data.name: Advanced Ceramics
data.description: Focuses on the development of a well produced, accomplished body of work that reflects the individual's ideas. May be repeated. Prerequisite: ART 3760C

data.subject: ART
data.name: Research
data.description: Students may study or research an individual art project with an art faculty member. Complexity and amount of work will determine the number of credit hours granted. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Thesis I
data.description: The course will expose students to fundamental issues and ideas current in the field of art. An inquiry into the structure of art and its relationship to society, knowledge, and the self. Prerequisite: ART 3822

data.subject: ART
data.name: Thesis II
data.description: Studio work in student's major area with major professor, resulting in a student exhibit. Arrangements with major professor one semester before graduation. Written thesis required.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Graduate Fibers
data.description: Graduate level studio course, explores issues of the fiber medium and its context in contemporary practice.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Drawing
data.description: Advanced drawing. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Printmaking
data.description: Advanced printmaking. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Painting
data.description: Advanced painting. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Grad Figure Painting
data.description: Graduate figure painting focuses on highly developed perceptual and technical painting skills in various aspects of figure study. May be repeated. Prerequisites: ART 4560C or approved course work.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Grad. Portrait Painting
data.description: Graduate portrait painting focuses on highly developed perceptual and technical painting skills in various aspects of portraiture. May be repeated. Prerequisite: ART 4335C or approved course work.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Digital Art Lab
data.description: This is an advanced graduate level studio course in the digital arts experimenting with and finding compelling strategies for digital arts production.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Video Art
data.description: Graduate level research of digital media with emphasis on fundamental strategies for making video/audio work. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Sculpture
data.description: Advanced sculpture. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Ceramics
data.description: The advanced student will explore all aspects of expression in clay and glaze. Students will be expected to be mostly self-directed. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Vis. Art Marketing
data.description: Students seeking a degree in studio art will be able to appraise and present a portfolio to an appropriate organization.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Directed Study
data.description: A course of study in a selected area under the supervision of an appropriate faculty member. Mandatory for MFA students in semester of graduation. Advanced approval by faculty and graduate advisory required (3cr). May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Research
data.description: Students may study or research an individual art project with an art faculty member. Complexity and amount of work will determine the number of credit hours granted. May be repeated.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Grad Art Sem II
data.description: Discussion of students work within the context of the contemporary art world. Issues and practical concerns for the professional artist will be addressed, such as dealing with galleries, grant writing and business procedures. Mandatory for MFA students.

data.subject: ART
data.name: Prosp & Exhib Prep
data.description: Offers students the opportunity to complete the research and preparation of written components required for graduation, including thesis and artist statement.

data.subject: ASH
data.name: History of Japan
data.description: Survey of the history of Japan from the origins of Japanese civilization in the early centuries BCE to the contemporary era, with an in-depth focus on selected topics such as the transitions from classical to medieval and early modern to modern periods.

data.subject: ASH
data.name: East Asian Civ
data.description: The historical developments of Chinese and Japanese civilizations and cultures from the earliest beginnings and classical period through the middle ages and eighteenth century as well as the modern era.

data.subject: ASH
data.name: Hist Travel Japan
data.description: History of Japan's cultural, social, political and religious history through the examination of travel and travel literature.

data.subject: ASL
data.name: ASL I
data.description: A linguistic foundation in ASL, including a cognitive understanding of basic linguistic principles of the language, expressive (signing) ability and receptive processing of sign language.

data.subject: ASL
data.name: American Sign Language II
data.description: A second-semester level of instruction in ASL, including cognitive understanding of linguistic principles of the language, expressive (signing) ability and receptive processing of sign language.Prerequisite: ASL I

data.subject: ASN
data.name: China Then and Now
data.description: Examination of China, focusing on its culture, history, religion, and societal life.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Corporate Culture China
data.description: An overview of intercultural etiquette and the corporate practices applied in China and its relations with worldwide companies.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Topics in Korean Culture
data.description: Examines the basic concepts of Korean history, language, and food and social customs to gain a deeper understanding of contemporary Korean culture.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Asia Through Films
data.description: Overview of Asian culture, history, and society through Asian cinema.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Japanese Anime and Manga
data.description: Examines a historical, cultural, and societal perspective of anime and manga in Japan, dating pre-modern to pre and post-WWII to modern times.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: K-Pop and J-Pop Culture
data.description: Examines the global dissemination, visibility, and prominence of the Korean Wave and Japanese pop culture, including examples of music, dramas/film, video games, manhwa/manga, fashion/beauty, and food.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Zen and Tea Ceremony
data.description: An introduction to the cultural traditions and social behavior of Asia that covers the history, theory, and practice of Chado, or Way of Tea, a Zen-Buddhist inspired art.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Intro East Asia
data.description: An overview of East Asia from traditional to modern times including the interaction among Asian cultures as well as between Asia and the world.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Pop Culture East Asia
data.description: Major popular and visual cultural expressions of traditional and modern China, Japan, and Korea, ranging from paintings, calligraphy, and performance to contemporary cuisine and K-pop.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Japan & New East
data.description: Issues of nationalism, regionalism and globalism in light of the emerging role of Japan in relation to the ascendancy of China and the implications for East Asia.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Dynamics Of Asia
data.description: An interdisciplinary study of the classical and contemporary periods in Asian civilizations, including tradition and modernization, culture and the arts, gender and diversity, and international relations. Content may vary from semester to semester. Course may be repeated.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: E Asian Texts Translation
data.description: Reading and interpretation in translation of classical to modern cool writings from literature, culture, arts, and religion in East Asia.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Zen and the Arts
data.description: Examines the history, theory, and practice of Chado (Way of Tea), a Zen-inspired art that has had, and still exerts, a long-lasting influence on Japanese society.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Ind Research
data.description: Topics will be selected to meet academic needs for students doing research in some specialized area of asian studies.  Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: An examination of specific topics in Asian Studies. The content to be determined by instructor.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Master's Essay in AS
data.description: Supervised research project. Requires prior approval by instructor. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. May be retaken for credit.

data.subject: ASN
data.name: Internship
data.description: Students intern in local, national and international organizations with ties to Asia. The nature of the work to be determined in conjunction with the advisor. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the department required.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Descriptive Astronomy
data.description: An introductory survey of our universe. Topics include the formation and evolution of the universe, including planets, stars, galaxies, and black holes.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Descriptive Astronomy Lab
data.description: Laboratory course to accompany AST 1002. An introduction to experimental work in astronomy including laboratory exercises during the day in the lab and evening observating sessions.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Solar Sys Astronomy
data.description: General principles of Astronomy with emphasis on the structure and evolution of the Solar System, the laws of planetary motion, and the physical aspects of the sun, planets, and interplanetary debris.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Solar Sys Astr Lab
data.description: Laboratory section of AST 2003. Outdoor observing of the moon, planets and indoor exercises including celestial positions and time, the moon's orbit, planetary motions, comparative planetology.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Observ Astronomy
data.description: Observational astronomical techniques from radio to x-rays including CCD Imaging, Photometry, and Spectroscopy.

data.subject: AST
data.name: Observ Astron Lab
data.description: The lab component associated with Observational Astronomy.  Covers acquisition, reduction and interpretation of astronomical data using telescopes and computers.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Eval and Diagnosis II
data.description: Clinical evaluation and diagnosis of orthopedic injuries and/or dysfunctions that occur to the upper extremity during physical activity. Prerequisites: ATR 5217C, ATR 5305C, ATR 5815L. Corequisite: ATR 5316C.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Ther Interventions II
data.description: Introduction to therapeutic modalities and rehabilitation techniques encountered in athletic training practice for sub-acute and chronic injuries, including application of associate clinical skills. Corequisite: ATR 5218C.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Clinical Ed II
data.description: Designed to allow students to apply athletic training techniques associated with orthopedic assessment of the lower extremity and therpeutic modalities. Prerequisites: ATR 5217C, ATR 5305C, ATR 5815L. Corequisites: ATR 5218C, ATR 5316C.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: AT Entrepreneurship
data.description:
Leadership and business strategies related to athletic training. Topics that will be
covered include characteristics associated with entrepreneurism, innovation, and
identifying niches.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Business in AT
data.description:
Establishing a business structure, creating a market for one's business,
management and leadership principles, and other critical components of starting
and operating a successful business venture.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Navigating Academia in AT
data.description: Introduces the structure and governance of a college/University academic setting. Common terms, titles, roles, expectations are discussed. Components of teaching, scholarship, service, and advising.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Clinical Ed V
data.description: Designed to allow students to apply the athletic training techniques associated with administration and professionalism in allied health care in selected clinical education settings. Prerequisites: ATR 5517, ATR 5845L.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: Contemp Issues in AT
data.description: This course examines contemporary issues relevant to the profession of Athletic Training. Prerequisites: ATR 5517, ATR 5845L, ATR 6621. Corequisite: ATR 6855L.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: DAT Applied Scholarship II
data.description: Designed to introduce one to applied scholarship. Describes the publication process for poster and presentation for local, state, regional, national, and international journals and conferences. Prerequisite: ATR 7630 or permission from the instructor.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: DAT Applied Scholarship III
data.description: Analyzes qualitative and quantitative literature for clinical practice and academia. Small grant funding will be introduced.Prerequisites: ATR 7631 or permission from the instructor.

data.subject: ATR
data.name: DAT Capstone Project
data.description: Individualized Specialization plan chosen from either Educational Leadership or Entrepreneurial Leadership which develops a body of knowledge and skills culminating in a capstone project. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Open to DAT students only.

data.subject: BCH
data.name: Gen. Biochemistry
data.description: Chemistry of proteins, lipids, car-bohydrates, and nucleic acids; principles of enzymology, metabolism, and bioenergetics.

data.subject: BCH
data.name: Gen.Biochemistry
data.description: Chemistry of proteins, lipids, car-bohydrates, and nucleic acids; principles of enzymology, metabolism, and bioenergetics.

data.subject: BCH
data.name: Cellular chemistry
data.description:
An analysis of the biochemical principles that determine cellular processes. Explores
the interactions of macromolecules in cells and their environment, and the metabolic
pathways that govern life. Prerequisites: BSC 2010, CHM 1045 & CHM 1045L

data.subject: BCH
data.name: Intro Biochem Res
data.description: An overview of the analysis of biochemical data and experimental design.

data.subject: BCH
data.name: Biochem Graduate Seminar
data.description: Presentations and discussions of current topics in the biochemical sciences. Corequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Plans Interpret
data.description: Building construction plans interpretation of working drawings for residential, commercial building, and civil construction.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Con Mater and Meth
data.description: A study of the origins, production and uses of construction materials such as concrete, steel, aluminum, wood, brick, and stone. A combination of structural and non-structural, interior and exterior materials and assemblies will be examined.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Bldg Construction Drawing
data.description: Prepare plans, elevations and sections appropriate to general construction using computer assisted modeling techniques.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Surveying
data.description: Principles and practices of surveying as it applies to building construction.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Structural Design I
data.description: Applications of the principals of statics and strength of materials to engineering problems of equilibrium, strength and stiffness. Topics include equilibrium of forces, stress, strain, beams and col.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Prin Contruct Mgt
data.description: Covers the construction industry with emphasis on the principles of construction management.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Estimating I
data.description: Principles and practices of estimating providing application and drill in surveying quantities of labor and materials for general construction projects: excavation, concrete and formwork, carpentry, masonry, structural steel, lath and plaster, interior finishes.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Scheduling I
data.description: Critical path and precedence diagram methods in construction planning and scheduling, including: resource management, cashflow, PERT, time compression and scheduling updating.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Con Sitework and Equip
data.description: Exposition and critical analysis of practical and sequential aspects of converting raw land to finished product. Course will define various steps and discuss equipment and techniques of accomplishment. Prerequisite: BCN 2210.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Construction Safety
data.description: Introduces occupational safety hazards associated with the construction industry. Emphasis placed on recognition, evaluation, and control of safety hazards particularly as they relate to the Occupational Safety and Health Act.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Legal Aspects
data.description: Legal and business aspects of engineering contracts and specifications in the construction industry. Analysis, study of precedents, and application of contract clauses, including changes, changed conditions, termination, disputes, payments, risk and insurance, inspection, liquidated damages, and technical requirements. Prerequisite:  BCN 3027

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Fin Mgmt Const Org
data.description: Accounting for construction operations; labor, materials, equipment, and overhead costs. Money management, depreciation, taxes, loans, profit/losses analysis.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Doc & Comm
data.description: Writing and transmitting construction documentation for technical and legal requirements for construction projects in a global context. Stresses development of verbal and written communication skills. Prerequisite:  BCN 1272

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Industry Internship
data.description: This course provides an opportunity for students to gain supervised, practical work experience in their particular field of interest within the industry. Prerequisites: Consent of advisor and School Director.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Bldg Information Modeling
data.description: Introduce and explore the application of Building Information Modeling (BIM) both as a product and a process in building construction. Prerequisite: BCN 2253, BCN 3611, BCN 3720

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Structural Design II
data.description: Intro to the material properties, allowable stresses, codes and standards for the design of reinforced concrete, pre-stressed concrete, reinforced masonry structures and the design of steel structures

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Temp Structures
data.description: Material properties, allowable stresses, applicable codes and standards for timber structures and the theory and practice of the planning, design, erection and maintenance of temporary structures.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Env Control I
data.description: A study of the concepts of thermal and plumbing systems in residential and commercial buildings, including code provisions and cost estimates.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Sustain App to Const
data.description: This course presents a study of the concepts and techniques of sustainable construction. An in depth review of sustainable materials and construction techniques will be covered.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Cost Estimating II
data.description: Quantity take-offs and pricing, and the application of computing techniques in construction estimating.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Mgmt Of Const Prjcts
data.description: Management of construction project field operations and procedures as they relate to contract management, planning, control, coordination, quality, safety, documentation, and resource management. Prerequisites: BCN 3720, BCN 3730, BCN 3611.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Scheduling II
data.description: The application of advanced computerized planning, scheduling, and simulation techniques to construction operations, processes, and control.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Qualt Cont In Constr
data.description: Quality control as governed by the job inspector, contractor superintendent, architect-engineer, building official, and governmental agencies and requirements.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Senior Project
data.description: This course requires the senior level construction management student to work on a project designed to integrate the knowledge acquired in multiple topics within the undergraduate curriculum. Prerequisites: BUL 4310 and all BCN courses except BCN 3753.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Sustainable Const
data.description: Study of the concepts and techniques of sustainable construction, in depth review of sustainable materials and construction techniques.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Hazard Mitigation
data.description: Reducing potential damage to the built environment from natural hazards, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, explosions. Benefit-cost analysis.  Regulatory problems.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Cost Ana & Con
data.description: Description of different types of estimating techniques in relation to different stages in a construction project. Productivity analysis, measurement of progress, and techniques of cost control are covered.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Interdis Aspect Hou
data.description: Recognition and definition of those factors which affect the planning, financing, and construction of housing projects. The operations and responsibilities of a multidisciplinary team dealing with decision process. This course takes a critical look at the housing delivery system to include: how the housing industry operates, various technologies prevalent in housing construction, and constraints to housing. The course will also look at the future, examining problems and forces that will shape opportunities.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Produc In Const
data.description: An in-depth study of common issues relating to productivity improvements in construction.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Prin Const Sch
data.description: Application of CPM and PERT to construction planning, time-cost trade-off, resource/cost-flow management and analysis, repetitive task planning, progress updating, and computerized scheduling

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Safety Mgmt
data.description: Introduce the graduate student in Construction Management to the important elements essential in managing the safety function of a construction company.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Legal Env
data.description: Legal and business aspects of engineering contracts and specifications in the construction industry. Analysis, study of precedents, and application of contract clauses, including changes, changed conditions, termination, disputes, payments, risk and insurance, inspection, liquidated damages, and technical requirements.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Const Fin Mgmt
data.description: Money management in construction operations:  financing, funding, sources of money, cash flow, disbursement, liability and bonding, cost and managerial accounting, and profit analysis.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Codes And Reg
data.description: Study of building codes required by local, county, and state levels and their relation to quality control.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Mgt Mkt Constr Serv
data.description: Human effectiveness in marketing construction management services in the public and private sectors.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Independent Studies
data.description: Individual studies under supervision of faculty, tutor, or advisor. Requires prior approval of advisor and Chair.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Intensive study for small group of students in a particular topic, or a limited number of topics not otherwise offered in the curriculum.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Grad CM Internship
data.description: Supervised work in construction management. Evaluation and reports required. Prerequisites: Consent of advisor and Department Chair

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Dec & Risk In Const
data.description: Techniques of decision analysis for the medium to top level management personnel in the construction industry. Typical construction related problems that involve risk and uncertainty are studied.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Adv Estimating
data.description: Application of computer software to rigorous exercises in construction estimating. Cost information related to construction with applications in current practice. Prerequisites: BCN 5618 or Instructor Permission

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Ai In Constr Mgmt
data.description: The course presents a study of the concepts, techniques, and applications of AI technology in the construction management domain.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Automation in Const
data.description: In depth introduction and analysis of automation technologies in construction, covering issues related to the application, implementation and evaluation of automation technologies throughout the lifecycle of a construction process for smart jobsites.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Graduate level research carried out under the supervision of a faculty member.

data.subject: BCN
data.name: Thesis
data.description: (Total of 6 credit hours spread over at least two consecutive terms with 1-3 credit hours in each must be completed.) Students develop a thesis under the direction of a senior faculty mentor, and their supervisory committee, and advance and defend their propositions before an audience of peers, scholars, and their supervisory committee. Requires approval of advisor, supervisory committee, and Department Chair.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Intro to Biomed Eng
data.description: This course will provide a broad view of biomedical engineering and introduce the sub-areas within the field. Students will be provided with the history, current status and the future of the field.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Intro to BME Computing
data.description: Introduction to computers for biomedical engineers. Basic computer programming principles and introduction to computer software such as MATLAB and Labview.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Eng An Bio Sys I
data.description: A quantitative, model approach to physiological systems at the cellular and tissue level.  Thermodynamic, biochemical and biophysical principles of the cell, general system anatomy and functionality. Prerequisites: PHY 2049 (with a 'C' or better) and CHM 2210 (with a 'C' or better). Corequisite: BME 2740.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Eng An Bio Sys II
data.description: Quantitative description of physiological systems at the integrative systems level.  Includes engineering analysis relating design to organ function.

data.subject: BME
data.name: BME Transport
data.description: Basic principles of heat, mass, and fluid transport.  Derivation of basic equations, and simplification techniques.  Applications to physiological systems, artificial organs, and pharmacokinetics. Prerequisites:  BME2740, EGM3503, CHM1046 (with a grade of 'C' or better), MAP2302 (with a grade of 'C' or better), PHY2049 (with a grade of 'C' or better)  and MAC2313 or MAC2283 (with a grade of 'C' or better)

data.subject: BME
data.name: BME Data Eval Prin
data.description: Design and analysis of clinical and biomedical experiments.  Statistical process control and measuring performance relevant to medical device industry. Prerequisites: ESI 3215 or STA 3033

data.subject: BME
data.name: Clinical Rotations
data.description: Clinical lectures, video presentations, and observational and participatory rotations through various divisions and laboratories at BME's clinical and industrial partners.

data.subject: BME
data.name: BME Lab II
data.description: Design, implementation and analysis of biomedical experiments, including bio-signal data acquisition, processing and analysis, mass transport and medical image processing and interpretation. Prerequisites: BME 3721, EEL 3110 Corequisite: BME 4100, BME 3632.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Biomaterials
data.description:
Materials used in prosthesis for skin and soft tissue, vascular implant devices, bone repair, and artificial joints.  Structure-property relationships for biological tissue. 	
Prerequisite:  EGM 3503  For MME students only: PCB 3702, EGN 3311, EGN 3321 Corequisite: BME 3404. No Corequisite for MME students.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Biomech Card Systems
data.description: Functional cardiovascular physiology and anatomy; analysis and computation of cardiovascular flow; constitutive properties of tissue; coronary and systemic circulation; flow and stress considerations in cardiovascular assist devices.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Eng  Hemodynamics
data.description: Fluid Mechanics of the circulatory system, rheology of blood, lubrication mechanics.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Medical Inst Design
data.description: Concepts of transducers and instrumentation systems; origins of biopotentials; electrical safety; applications of medical instrumentation.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Medical Imaging
data.description: Fundamentals of major imaging modalities including x-ray radiology, x-ray computed tomography, ultrasonography, magnetic resonance imaging, nuclear imaging (PET and SPECT), and optical imaging.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Des Biomed Devices
data.description: Introduction to biomedical engineering design, materials selection, product and process development, manufacturing and of medical devices. Application of modern software tools in device design and sim. Prerequisites:  BME 3404, BME 3721, BME 4011, BME  4503C  Corequisite:  BME 3632

data.subject: BME
data.name: Senior Design Proj
data.description: Customer needs; design requirements; biocompatibility; regulatory, ethical, societal, and environmental considerations; creativity; project management; prototype construction and testing; final report and presentation.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Undergrad Research in BME
data.description: Participate in supervised research activities on current biomedical engineering topics under the direction of a BME faculty member.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Undergrad Seminar
data.description: The course consists of oral presentations made by guests, faculty and students on current topics and research activities in Biomedical Engineering.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Undergraduate Internship
data.description: Engineering practice in biomedical applications in device manufacturing, research and development, healthcare delivery or a related area. Interns will be required to submit a pre-semester objective to the Biomedical Engineering Academic Advisor, as well as a final report and evaluation that must be completed and approved by the internship supervisor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: BME CO-OP
data.description: Engineering Practice in biomedical applications at an industrial partner's site. Intern will be hired through a cooperative agreement to conduct collaborative research with supervision of advisor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Cardio Biomech
data.description: Functional cardiovascular physiology and anatomy; analysis and computation of cardiovascular flow; constitutive properties of tissue and analyses of relevant deformation and stress profiles. Prerequisite: Permission from instructor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Biomed Phys Eng II
data.description: Introductory course on neural and musculoskeletal physiology and associated engineering concepts frequently encountered in the Biomedical Engineering field.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Med Imag Instr
data.description: Engineering basis of medical imaging systems, including radiology, X-Ray CT, SPECT, PET, MRI, and laser and ultrasound based imaging, as well as instrument quality assurance procedures. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Optical Spect
data.description: Introduction to the scientific principles of optical spectroscopic technologies and their usage in the field of medicine.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Analy & Sim of PHys Proc
data.description: Study of advanced computational techniques in BME. Focus on execution (in MATLAB), conceptualization, analysis of the relevant literature, and oral presentation of results. Corequisite: STA4202 or STA 4234 or STA 5236 or STA 6176 or STA 6746

data.subject: BME
data.name: Ind Studies
data.description: Individual research studies for qualified biomedical engineering graduate students. Work is to be performed under the supervision of an advisor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: BME MS Project
data.description: Individual work culminating in a professional practice-oriented report suitable for the requirements of the Professional Track of the MS program in biomedical engineering.  Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Graduate level biomedical engineering research carried out under the supervision of a faculty member.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Biomed Eng Seminar
data.description: Problems in Biomedical Engineering and results of ongoing research will be presented and discussed by invited experts. Prereqisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Doctoral BME Sem
data.description: The course consists of oral presentations made by guests, faculty and graduate students on advanced topics and current research activities in Biomedical Engineering.

data.subject: BME
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Doctoral Research leading to the Ph.D. Biomedical engineering dissertation.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Med Gen
data.description: The course covers fundamental principles of medical genetics integrated with biochemistry, cell biology and molecular biology. Prerequisite: Enrollment in the HWCOM Graduate Certificate Program in Molecular and Biomedical Sciences.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: End of Life Care
data.description: This course teaches the basic concepts associated with end-of-life care for adults. Emphasis is placed on symptom management, preparation for death, and support to adults and their families.
