The goal is to develop knowledge of specific strategies to support end-of-life care planning among patients, families and healthcare professionals. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Path and Med Histo
data.description: Introductory course in the study of normal tissues and organs and how these are affected by disease. Prerequisite: Enrollment in the HWCOM Graduate Certificate in Molecular and Biomedical Sciences.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Pharmacology
data.description: This course is an introduction to the basic principles of pharmacology and to the primary classes of drug therapy, including the prototypic agents. The main goal of the medical training (curriculum) is to develop the diagnostic and therapeutic skills (competencies) required by a basic doctor. Safe and effective prescribing is a core competency. In addition, learning should provide an appropriate framework fostering the ability to assimilate information about new drug development that will occur throughout a professional career (self-directed learning). The Pharmacology teaching is designed with this final goal (to attain a core competency) in mind and reflects the paradigm shift from a process-focused education to an outcome-oriented education. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Med Physio
data.description: The course is designed to introduce the students to essential concepts of medical physiology. Prerequisite: Enrollment in the HWCOM Graduate Certificate Program in Molecular and Biomedical Sciences.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Pathology and Infectious Disea
data.description: Pathology and Infectious Disease is an introductory course in the study of disease and the general principles of infectious disease. The Pathology component of the course will emphasize the general concepts and vocabulary to lay the groundwork that will be useful during the subsequent courses within the organ systems modules. Areas covered in this course include general concepts of histology, cellular adaptations, necrosis, apoptosis, inflammation, repair, hemodynamic disorders, neoplasia, and pathology as it relates to nutritional / environmental factors, as well as an introduction to forensic medicine and pediatric and genetic disorders. In addition, during this course the students will also receive general concepts relating to clinical laboratory medicine and regulatory organizations allied to the field of medicine and hospital oversight in a 2 hour lecture referred to as fundamentals of laboratory medicine, followed by a one hour practical in the classroom. The Infectious Disease component includes an overview of microbes, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites, important to human disease and disease processes. Specific topic areas of this component of the course include microbial disease, virulence mechanisms, evasion strategies used by pathogens against the antimicrobial immune response, and innate antimicrobial mechanisms. General concepts (building blocks for comprehending organ-specific pathology presented in Period 2) are emphasized in this introductory course. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Nervous Syst Behavior I
data.description: This course provides an integrated, multidisciplinary overview of the structural and functional relationships of the central and peripheral nervous systems under both healthy and diseased conditions. The course covers essential concepts in normal and pathologically altered neurological functions (using neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neuropharmacology, neuropathology, and clinical neurology). The goal of the course is to give students the skills to develop and prioritize a differential diagnosis, localize lesions based on diagnostic tests and neurological signs, explain the patient's signs and symptoms, as well as propose and interpret diagnostic tests and approaches to therapy. The format of the course includes lectures, laboratory work, small-group case-based discussions, and clinical correlates presented through a variety of application exercises and case discussions. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Renal System
data.description: This course is an introduction to the study of the renal system. It will help the student integrate what they have learned in previous courses (e.g., Anatomy, Physiology, Biochemistry, Genetics, Epidemiology, Histology, and Pharmacology) and lead to an understanding of the mechanisms of diseases involving the kidneys. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Nervous Syst Behavior II
data.description: This course will present the fundamentals of psychiatry and psychological principles that are the foundation for clinical work in Period 3. These principles include psychiatric diagnoses and treatment, cognitive neuroscience, cognitive and emotional development, and principles of psychopharmacology and psychotherapy. Learning will take place in an interactive process using team-based learning, problem-based learning, and some traditional lectures. Independent study and preparation prior to group activities will be an integral part of the learning process. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BMS
data.name: Clinical Epidemiology and Res
data.description: This course is an introduction to the foundations and methods of clinical and epidemiological research. The main perspective is the use of quantitative methods to address clinical or epidemiological research questions, as well as the use of research to inform the practice of medicine. Concepts from the sciences of clinical epidemiology and biostatistics will be presented to the student in theory and problem-based scenarios. Prerequisite: Enrolled in the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine.

data.subject: BOT
data.name: Introductory Botany
data.description: A history of mankind's study and use of plants, and a survey of plants of economic importance. Includes lab. No science prerequisite.

data.subject: BOT
data.name: Intro Botany Lab
data.description: A history of mankind's study and use of plants, and a survey of plants of economic importance. Includes lab. No science prerequisite. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: BOT
data.name: Morphol Of Vasc Plt
data.description: Origin and evolution of plants, especially vascular plants of tropical origin. Analysis of vascular plant anatomy and morphology, emphasizing the underlying principles of plant construction.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: General Biology I
data.description: Biomolecules, cells, energy flow, genetics, and physiology. Science background or Biology major recommended. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Gen Biology Lab I
data.description: Biomolecules, cells, energy flow, genetics, and physiology. Science background or Biology major recommended.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: General Biology II
data.description: A survey of organismal biology with emphasis on botany and zoology. Science background or Biology major recommended. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Gen Biology Lab II
data.description: A survey of organismal biology with emphasis on botany and zoology. Science background or Biology major recommended. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Human Biology
data.description: Biological and general scientific principles governing human structure, function, health, and relationship to the planetary environment. For non-science majors. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Human Bio Lab
data.description: Biological and general scientific principles governing human structure, function, health, and relationship to the planetary environment. For non-science majors. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Biology career planning
data.description:
We explore career paths, develop professional skills, review what is needed for your
path and plan your remaining time at FIU to advance your goals. For sophomore level
and transfer biology majors.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Anatomy & Physiology I
data.description: Anatomy and Physiology I is the first of a two-course sequence. It is a study of the structure and function of human biology including cells, tissues, organs and systems. For non-biology majors. Prerequisite or corequisite: BSC 2085L

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Anatomy & Phys I Lab
data.description: Anatomy and Physiology I is the first of a two-course sequence. It is a study of the structure and function of human biology including cells, tissues, organs and systems. For non-biology majors. Prerequisite or corequisite: BSC 2085.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Wildlife Forensics
data.description: An interdisciplinary approach to wildlife conservation, critical aspects of conservation strategy as it relates to illegal trafficking and the role of forensics/crime science in its prevention. [B] Prerequisite: BSC2010, BSC2011

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Make Your Mutant
data.description: Mutating existing proteins to study their structure/function relationship in their relation to health and disease. Good preparation for going into biotech, biomedical and biopharma fields. Corequisite: PCB 3063 or BCH 3033

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Science Literacy

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Student Research Lab

data.subject: BSC
data.name: QBIC Ecology Journal Club
data.description: A seminar styled course teaching QBIC students how to dissect and analyze complex analytically written scientific articles in Ecology (PCB 3043).

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Biological Science Intern
data.description: Supervised, practical experience in a professional, laboratory or field setting in which biologists may work. Department permission is required. May be repeated. Prerequisites: Permission from FIU faculty advisor is required.

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Topics Organism Diversity

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Biotechnology

data.subject: BSC

data.subject: BSC

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Student Research Lab

data.subject: BSC

data.subject: BSC

data.subject: BSC

data.name: WS: R For Biologists

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Glaser Seminar

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Teaching Biology

data.subject: BSC
data.name: Student Research Lab

data.name: Topics In Biology

data.name: Biology Internship

data.subject: BUL

data.description: The course includes issues such as: Contracts, Torts, Legal/Political/Economic aspects of Ethics and the Law, U.C.C., Antitrust Law, Employment Law, Administrative Law, Securities Law, and International Business Law topics.Prereq(a)Bus students ACG3301,ECO2013, ECO2023and(QMB3003or(STA 2023andMAC2233) or Calc I or higher) or equ. grade of 'C' or higher; (b)BS Construction Management, ACG3024 and (ECO2013 or ECO2023) and MAC2233 and STA2023 or equivalents with C or better

data.description: Substantive issues and principles of law including agency, partnership and corporation law, commercial paper, antitrust, employment, administrative, environmental and computer law; ethical issues in business law. Prerequisite: (a) Grade of C or higher in BUL 4310 or BUL 4320; and (b) qualifying Accounting Entrance Exam score and GPA (BUEE only)

data.subject: CAP
data.name: HCI for CS
data.description: HCI foundations, user-centered interaction design, prototyping and programming interactive systems, qualitative and quantitative evaluation techniques, designing multimodal interfaces. Prerequisite:  COP3337

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Intro Game Theory
data.description: Introduction to all major topics of game theory, including game representations, solution concepts, algorithms & complexity, repeated games, learning, auctions, voting, applications to many disciplines. Prerequisites :MAC 2312 or Permission of the Instructor.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Intro to Machine Learning
data.description: Topics will include concepts, principles, and approaches of machine learning, including classification, clustering, structured models and recommendation system.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Artificial Intelligence
data.description: Introduction to all major topics in artificial intelligence, including search, logic, optimization, constraint satisfaction, planning, probabilistic reasoning, multiagent systems, machine learning. Prerequisite: COP 3530

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Intro to NLP
data.description: The concepts and principles of computer processing of natural language, including linguistic phenomena, formal methods, and applications.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Intro Data Mining
data.description: Data mining applications, data preparation, data reduction and various data mining techniques such as association, clustering, classification, anomaly detection.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Modeling & Simulations
data.description: Introduction to discrete-event systems, a survey of modeling tools, mathematical & statistical modeling, role of random numbers, verification & validation, and applications. Prerequisite: (STA-2023 or STA-3033) and COP-3530

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Game Theory
data.description: Game representations, solution concepts, algorithms & complexity, repeated games, learning, auctions, voting application to many disciplines. Familiarity with mathematical proofs would be helpful.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Machine Learning
data.description: Decision trees, Bayesian learning reinforcement learning as well as theoretical concepts such as inductive bias, the PAC learning, minimum description length principle.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Grad NLP
data.description: The concepts and principles of computer processing of natural language, including linguistic phenomena, formal methods, and applications. Students will conduct an independent research project. Prerequisites: M.S. or Ph.D. standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Adv Comp Graphics
data.description: N/A

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Data Vis
data.description: Advanced class on data visualization principles and techniques. Students propose, implement, and present a project with strong collaborative and visual components.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Princip Data Mining
data.description: Introduction to data mining concepts, knowledge representation, inferring rules, statistical modeling, decision trees, association rules, classification rules, clustering, predictive models, and instance-based learning. Prerequisites: COP 4710 and STA 3033.

data.subject: CAP
data.name: Adv. Topics in ML
data.description: Advanced course on machine learning principles and techniques. Students propose, implement, and present a collaborative project with advanced machine learning techniques. Prerequisite: CAP 5610.

data.subject: CCE
data.name: Proj Plan Civ Engr
data.description: Introduction to techniques for planning activities, operations, finance, budget, workforce, quality, safety.  Utilize case studies as learning tools for students aspiring to superintendent positions.

data.subject: CCE
data.name: Const Eng Mgmt
data.description: Course will cover construction organization, planning and implementation; impact and feasibility studies; contractual subjects; liability and performance; the responsibility of owner, contractor and engineer.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Criminology
data.description: Examines the nature, extent, and causes of crime and criminal behavior.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Criminal Justice
data.description: An examination of the history, organization, and function of the criminal justice system, including police, courts, and corrections.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Homicide
data.description: A comprehensive study of homicide in the United States through the examination of individual cases, typology construction, and models.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Drugs and Crime
data.description: Examines the history and consequences of mind-altering drugs, and criminal behavior as it is affected by drugs, the legal response to substance abuse, treatment and prevention of substance abuse.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Victimology
data.description: A comprehensive study of victimization, including the relationship between the victims and offenders, and their interaction with the criminal justice system.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Apprenticeship
data.description: LEAP combines classroom instruction with specialized police training and workplace experience to produce successful law enforcement professionals and future leaders in the field. Prerequisites: 60 credits

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Criminological Theory
data.description: Advanced study and critical appraisal of various theories of crime causation, including an examination of biological psychological, economic, and sociological perspective on the etiology of crime.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Crime And The Media
data.description: An examination of the role of the media in reporting crime and the extent to which media coverage of crime and the criminal justice system impacts the commission of crimes and the operation of the system.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Ethics Criminal Justice
data.description: An introduction to ethical decision making in the criminal justice system.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: GIS and Crime Mapping
data.description:
Utilizes ArcGIS software to help students examine and identify patterns of crime
incidents through a geographical lens.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Courts and Forensic Science
data.description: Examines the criminal justice system and its reliance on forensic evidence in the court room.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Criminal Trials
data.description: Provides an in depth understanding to the concepts of a criminal trial.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Death Penalty
data.description: An examination of the problems and issues related to the death penalty in the United States.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Senior Capstone CJ
data.description: Emphasizes integration of knowledge acquired in previous courses. Students engage in development and production of a senior level research paper grounded in relevant criminology and criminal justice. Prerequisite: Senior standing and completion of CCJ 2020, CCJ 4014, CCJ 4700, and CJL 4064.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Organized Crime
data.description: Historical development of organized crime in the U.S.; defining 'organized crime' from U.S. and international perspective; patterns of criminal activity; critique of police and prosecutorial efforts to curb organized crime.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: White Collar Crime
data.description: The nature of white-collar crime and its social control is examined including the definition, typologies, theories, law, policing, regulating, prosecuting, defending, and its adjudication.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Race and Crime
data.description: Examines the intersection between race and crime in the criminal justice system, in addition to the role that race plays in policing, courts, corrections, and the death penalty.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Women Crime & Cj
data.description: Women as deviants, criminals, victims, and professionals in the criminal justice system.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Human Trafficking
data.description: Examines issues related to human trafficking and immigration from an international and global perspective.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Research Methods
data.description: Explores basic research methods and analytical techniques used in criminology and criminal justice.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Internship in CJ
data.description: Provides an opportunity for the student to observe the criminal justice system in operation. Prerequisite: 2.0. GPA minimum.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Minorities in Just Admin
data.description: This course focuses on current research and theories of racial, ethnic, and gender discrimination within America's criminal justice system.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Criminological Theory
data.description: The study of theoretical and research issues related to the nature and causes of crime and the administration of justice.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: CJ Policy Analysis
data.description: An overview of the formation, implementation, quantitative and qualitative evaluation, and ethical aspects of policy making in the criminal justice system. Prerequisite: 15 criminal justice graduate credit hours.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Research on Human Rights
data.description: Students will develop a greater understanding of pressing human rights problems and how to define and study them, design programs to address them, monitor program implementation, and measure impact.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Transnational Crime
data.description: Examination of the nature of transnational crime and the manner in which it relates to national security.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Human Trafficking
data.description: An investigation of the origins and current trends in the trafficking of humans for profit.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Data Analysis
data.description: An applied introduction to multivariate statistical analysis in criminal justice research.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Advanced Data Analysis
data.description: An applied introduction to longitudinal analysis in criminal justice research. Prerequisite: CCJ 6706.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Graduate students engage in criminal justice research under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisites: CCJ 6705, CCJ 6706.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Teaching Methods
data.description: Introduces students to effective pedagogical, teaching, and learning strategies used across the higher education continuum. Prerequisite: 18 graduate credit hours in criminal justice.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Special Topics C J
data.description: An intensive analysis of a particular topic in criminal justice. May be repeated for different topics.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Internship Program
data.description: Provides graduate student with the opportunity to gain work experience in an organization. Prerequisite: Student must have a minimum of 3.0 GPA.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Comprehensive Exam
data.description: Completion of a research study suitable for submission to an academic journal, including an oral presentation and defense (pass/fail grading). Prerequisite: Completion of all required coursework. Corequisite: Completion of all required coursework.

data.subject: CCJ
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Supervised research on an original research project submitted in partial fulfillment of doctoral degree requirements, including an oral presentation and defense (pass/fail grading). Prerequisites: CCJ 7960, CCJ 7926.

data.subject: CDA
data.name: Computer Architecture
data.description: Covers the levels of organization in a computer; digital logic; machine and assembly language programming, design of memory, buses, ALU, CPU; virtual memory, I/O.Prerequisite: COP 3337 and (COT 3100 or MAD 2104).

data.subject: CDA
data.name: Intro. to Computer Design
data.description: Computer architecture and design, CPU, memory systems, caches, data, input/output devices, bus architecture, and computer control. Processor types, instruction set and assembly language programming. Prerequisite: EGN 2271

data.subject: CDA
data.name: Intro to Mobile Robotics
data.description: A first course on the theoretical and practical aspects of mobile robotics. Topics include locomotion, kinematics, sensing and perception, localization and mapping, planning and navigation.

data.subject: CEG
data.name: Geotechnical Engr I
data.description: Engineering geology, soil properties; stresses in soils; failures; criterias; consolidation and settlement; compaction, soil improvement and slope stabilization.

data.subject: CEG
data.name: Geotechnical Test La
data.description: Laboratory experiments to identify and test behavior of soils and rocks.

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Intro Human-Comp Interaction
data.description: Fundamental concepts of human-computer interaction, cognitive models, user-centered design principles and evaluation, emerging technologies.

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Software Eng I
data.description: Software Process Model, software analysis and specification, software design, testing. Prerequisites: CGS3095 and COP 3337

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Software Eng II
data.description: Issues underlying the successful development of large scale software projects: Software Architectures; Software Planning and Management; Team Structures; Cost Estimation.

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Fund SW Testing
data.description: Fundamentals of software testing. Topics include: test plan creation, test case generation, program inspections, specification-based and implementation-based testing, GUI testing, and testing tools.

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Cloud Computing
data.description: Topics include the concepts and principles of cloud computing and the techniques of using cloud systems and developing cloud applications. Prerequisites:  CNT4713 and (CDA 3102 or CDA4101) or permission of the instructor

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Software Security
data.description: Development of applications that are free from common security vulnerabilities, such as buffer overflow, SQL injection, and cross-site scripting attacks. Emphasis is on distributed web applications. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CEN
data.name: Software Data Model
data.description: Essential software and data modeling methods and techniques such as UML, XML, and ER.

data.subject: CES
data.name: Structural Analysis
data.description: To introduce the student to the basic concepts and principles of structural theory relating to statically determinate beams, arches, trusses and rigid frames, including deflection techniques.

data.subject: CES
data.name: Steel Design
data.description: The analysis and design of structural elements and connections for buildings, bridges, and specialized structures utilizing structural steel. Both elastic and plastic designs are considered.

data.subject: CES
data.name: Reinforced Concrete
data.description: The analysis and design of reinforced concrete beams, columns, slabs, retaining walls and footings; with emphasis corresponding to present ACI Building Code. Introduction to prestressed concrete is given.

data.subject: CES
data.name: Intr Prestress Conc
data.description: The fundamental principles of design for prestressed concrete structures. Understanding of the behavior of prestressed concrete structures, material properties, and the detailed considerations in limit state design.

data.subject: CES
data.name: Prestress Conc.Des.
data.description: The behavior of steel and concrete under sustained load. Analysis and design of pre-tensioned and post-tensioned reinforced concrete members, and designing these members into the integral structure. Prerequisite: CES 4702.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Career Orientation in Civil En
data.description: Course provides an overview of the Civil Engineering profession, including understanding of the discipline subfields, to assist students in determining the area(s) of emphasis they might want to follow for their professional career.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Computer Tools for Eng
data.description: Introduction to computer software commonly used in engineering, as Excel, Mathcad or Matlab. Numerical techniques to obtain approximated solutions to engineering problems are also included. Prerequisite: PHY2048, and MAC2312 or MAC2282

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Civil Comp. Tech & Vis.
data.description: The course will discuss computational techniques to develop analysis codes for civil engineering applications and visualization tools to leverage for computer-aided design of civil infrastructure. Prerequisite: CGN 2420 and CES 3100.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Gis Civil & Env Eng
data.description: Introduction to the basics of geographic information systems and their applications in civil and environmental engineering, landscape architecture, and other related fields.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Sustainable Bldg Eng
data.description: Introduces students to the basic concepts of designing building materials and complimentary systems in such a way that the enclosures control heat, air and moisture so that a durable, energy efficient, healthy building is provided without using excess materials and energy. Students from different backgrounds will learn principles and methodologies to enhance the environmental performance of buildings, including all applicable regulatory and sustainability frameworks.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: C E Sr Design Proj
data.description: Mandatory course for all senior students, to experience the design of a practical project by utilizing knowledge learned from previous courses for presenting a solution. Done under the supervision of a faculty member and professional engineer. Prerequisites:  CEG 4011, CEG 4011L, TTE4201, CES 3100

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Spec Topics Civ Eng
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Co-Op Work Exp
data.description: Supervised full-time work experience in engineering field. Limited to students admitted to the Co-op program with consent of advisor. Evaluation and report required.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Civil Engr Seminar
data.description: Basic principles and applications of civil engineering, including structural, transportation, environmental, geotechnical, construction, and water resources engineering for civil engineering students.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Gis Civil & Env Eng
data.description: Introduction to the basics of geographic information systems, their software and hardware, and their applications in Civil and Environmental Engineering, landscape architecture, and other related fields. Corequisites: TTE 4201 or CWR 3103 or ENV 3001.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Corrosion Control in CE
data.description: The course provides understanding of principles of corrosion phenomena with emphasis on its application to materials in civil engineering including testing methods, corrosion control, and durability. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Sp Top In Civil Eng
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Dir Ind Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports independent investigations selected by the student and professor with approval of advisor.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Graduate level research carried out under the supervision of a faculty member. Maximum 12 credits can be counted for Ph.D. students only. Prerequisite: Permission of the Major Professor.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Graduate Seminar
data.description: An examination of recent technical findings in selected areas of concern. Emphasis is placed on presentations (oral and written), research activities, readings, and active discussions among participants.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Thesis
data.description: The student following the thesis option of the Master's degree will pursue research through this course. The research work will culminate with an acceptable thesis. Prerequisite: Permission of the graduate's thesis advisor.

data.subject: CGN
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Doctoral research leading to Ph.D. civil engineering dissertation. Prerequisites: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Intro to Database for All
data.description: Introduction to database concepts including query languages, data organization and modeling, architecture, and security. Emphasis on relational databases with SQL. Not acceptable for CS majors.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Intro to Computing
data.description: Overview of the computing field to students, research programs and career options.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Intro To Micro Comp
data.description: A hands-on study of microcomputer software packages for applications such as operating system, word processing, spreadsheets, and database management. For students without a technical background. Not acceptable for credit for Computer Science majors.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Comp Appls Business
data.description: A hands-on study of spreadsheet and database management package for business students without a technical background. Not acceptable for credit for Computer Science majors.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Computr Data Analys
data.description: A hands-on study of how to use a modern spreadsheet program to analyze data, including how to perform queries, summarize data, and solve equations.  For non-technical students.  Not acceptable for CS students.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Technology in the Global Arena
data.description: Legal, ethical, social impacts of computer technology on society, governance, quality of life: intellectual property, privacy, security, professionalism, social identity in the U.S. and globally.Prerequisites:  (COP2250 or COP2210) and (ENC3213 or ENC3249).  This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Using The Internet
data.description: Internet history and importance. What is available on the Net. Tools such as email, listserves, telnet, ftp, Archie, Veronica, Gopher, netfind, the World Wide Web, Wais, and Mosaic. Nontechnical.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Computer Os
data.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts of operating systems and their implementation in UNIX and Windows. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Appl Networking
data.description: Principles of computer network design, operation and management.  Network protocols.  Network configuration.  Network security.  Not acceptable for credit for Computer Science majors.

data.subject: CGS
data.name: Websiteconmgmt
data.description: The fundamentals of creating and maintaining a website.  Installation and maintenance of a web-server.  Techniques for building multimedia interactive web-pages.  Not acceptable for credit for Computer Science majors.

data.subject: CHI
data.name: Chinese I
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: CHI
data.name: Chinese II
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: CHI
data.name: Interm CHI II
data.description: To improve students' speaking, writing, listening, reading skills in Chinese. Students learn how to use useful expressions of experience and thought.

data.subject: CHI
data.name: Interm Chi Conv
data.description: Focuses on conversation. Topics include time, numbers, shopping, clothing, food, transportation, education, culture, etc.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Chemistry & Society
data.description: A course for non-science majors which introduces students to basic concepts in chemistry and applies those concepts to contemporary issues such as air/water pollution, energy and food production, drugs, nutrition, and toxic chemicals. Prerequisites: One year of high school or college algebra. (Lab fees assessed) (F,S,SS)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Chem & Society Lab
data.description: A course for non-science majors which introduces students to basic concepts in chemistry and applies those concepts to contemporary issues such as air/water pollution, energy and food production, drugs, nutrition, and toxic chemicals. Prerequisites: One year of high school or college algebra. (Lab fees assessed) (F,S,SS)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Survey Of Chemistry
data.description: General and organic chemistry for non-science majors only. Atoms and molecules, states of matter, equilibrium, kinetics, acids and bases and introduction to organic chemistry. Laboratory must be taken concurrently. Does not fulfill requirements for chemistry, biology or pre-med majors. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Survey Chem Lab
data.description: General and organic chemistry for non-science majors only. Atoms and molecules, states of matter, equilibrium, kinetics, acids and bases and introduction to organic chemistry. Laboratory must be taken concurrently. Does not fulfill requirements for chemistry, biology or pre-med majors. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Gen Chemistry I
data.description: Fundamental principles of general chemistry: states of matter, atomic structure, stoichiometry, chemical bonding, acid-base reactions, and gas laws. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Gen Chem Lab I
data.description: Fundamental principles of general chemistry: states of matter, atomic structure, stoichiometry, chemical bonding, acid-base reactions, and gas laws. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Gen Chemistry II
data.description: Continuation of General Chemistry I (CHM 1045). Fundamental principles of chemistry: thermodynamics, solutions, kinetics, equilibrium and electrochemistry. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Gen Chem Lab II
data.description: Continuation of General Chemistry I (CHM 1045). Fundamental principles of chemistry: thermodynamics, solutions, kinetics, equilibrium and electrochemistry. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Survey Organic Chem
data.description: A basic one-semester survey course in organic chemistry for non-majors presenting a broad background in the reactions and structures of organic molecules. Does not fulfill requirements for chemistry, biology, or pre-med majors. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the course. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Survey Org Chem Lab
data.description: A basic one-semester survey course in organic chemistry for non-majors presenting a broad background in the reactions and structures of organic molecules. Does not fulfill requirements for chemistry, biology, or pre-med majors. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the course. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Organc Chem I
data.description: An introduction to chemical bonding and atomic structure theory as it pertains to the chemistry of carbon compounds. Correlation between structure and reactivity of organic molecules followed by a systematic look at the various reaction types using reaction mechanisms as a tool for study. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Org Chem Lab I
data.description: An introduction to chemical bonding and atomic structure theory as it pertains to the chemistry of carbon compounds. Correlation between structure and reactivity of organic molecules followed by a systematic look at the various reaction types using reaction mechanisms as a tool for study. Concurrent registration in both lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed)

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Organic Chem II
data.description: Continuation of CHM 2210, 2210L. Concurrent registration in lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed) Lecture is corequisite for lab.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Organic Chem Lab II
data.description: Continuation of CHM 2210, 2210L. Concurrent registration in lecture and laboratory is required. (Lab fees assessed) Lecture is corequisite for lab.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Intro Analyt Chem
data.description: Fundamentals of classical quantitative analysis. Topics include theory of precipitation, acid-base and oxidation-reduction reactions, as well as an introduction to spectrophotometric methods of analysis, ion-exchange techniques and complex formation. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the lecture.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Intr Analyt Chm Lab
data.description: Fundamentals of classical quantitative analysis. Topics include theory of precipitation, acid-base and oxidation-reduction reactions, as well as an introduction to spectrophotometric methods of analysis, ion-exchange techniques and complex formation. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the lecture.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Fund.Phys.Chm
data.description: Principles of physical chemistry. Topics include thermodynamics, equilibria, electrochemistry, and reaction kinetics. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the course.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Fund.Phys.Chm.Lab
data.description: Principles of physical chemistry. Topics include thermodynamics, equilibria, electrochemistry, and reaction kinetics. Laboratory must be taken concurrently with the course.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Phys Chem I
data.description: Principles of thermodynamics, gas laws, kinetic theory of gases, chemical equilibrium, electrochemistry, and kinetics. Laboratory to be taken concurrently with the course.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Phys Chm Lab I
data.description: Principles of thermodynamics, gas laws, kinetic theory of gases, chemical equilibrium, electrochemistry, and kinetics. Laboratory to be taken concurrently with the course.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Phys Chem II
data.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics. The Schrodinger equation and its application to rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopy, atomic and molecular structure, and bonding.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Phys Chem Lab II
data.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics. The Schrodinger equation and its application to rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopy, atomic and molecular structure, and bonding.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Fund Inorganic Chem
data.description: Fundamental principles of inorganic chemistry including atomic properties, valence and molecular orbital bonding, ionic solids, coordination chemistry and applications.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Inorganic Chemistry Lab
data.description: Synthesis, purification, and study of coordination and organometallic compounds. Prerequisite: CHM 3610

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Chem/Biochem Internship
data.description: One semester of full-time supervised work in a laboratory. A written report and supervisor evaluation will be required of each student. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the department required.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Instrument Analysis
data.description: Instrumental methods of chemical analysis, including electro-analytical methods, gas and liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry, x-ray fluorescence, and spectrophotometric methods.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Instr Analysis Lab
data.description: Instrumental methods of chemical analysis, including electro-analytical methods, gas and liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry, x-ray fluorescence, and spectrophotometric methods.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Adv Org Chem
data.description: An intensive examination of the major areas of contemporary organic chemistry. Reactive intermediates, pericyclic reactions, molecular rearrangements, and modern synthetic methods are among the topics covered.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Org Struc Detn
data.description: The qualitative analysis of organic compounds using modern spectroscopic, chromatographic and chemical methods.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Bio-Organic Chem
data.description: Chemistry of naturally-occurring organic compounds of biological importance. The relationship between organic chemistry and the chemical reactions which constitute the living organism.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Biol Chemistry I
data.description: Structures and functions of nucleic acids and proteins and cellular processes such as metabolism, replication and transcription are examined from a chemistry perspective. Lecture is corequisite for lab.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Biol Chem I Lab
data.description: Structures and functions of nucleic acids and proteins and cellular processes such as metabolism, replication and transcription are examined from a chemistry perspective. Lecture is corequisite for lab.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Biol Chemistry II
data.description: Continuation of Biological Chemistry I (CHM 4304).  Further exploration of bio-organic reaction mechanisms. Chemistry DNA synthesis and repair.  Chemistry of information transfer. Reactions of drugs.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Bio Chem Lab II
data.description: Continuation of Biological Chemistry Laboratory I. Experimental methods presented include NMR, enzyme inhibition assays, macromolecular thermodynamics, peptide sequencing, ligand binding assays, chromatography.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Under Res Chem
data.description: The student works directly with a professor on a research project. Credit is assigned based on 4 hr/wk laboratory/library work per credit hour. A written report is required. Report must be submitted to the Undergraduate Research Committee for approval. For additional credits of undergraduate research student must register for CHM 4911L.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Undergrad Res 2
data.description: Faculty directed research in chemistry. Credit is assigned based on 4 hr/wk laboratory/library work per credit hour. May be repeated.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Senior Seminar
data.description: Techniques for preparation and presentation of a scientific seminar and postgraduate career development. Completion of an oral presentation, written report, and exit exam in chemistry required.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Analytical Met
data.description: Analysis of analytical data, electrochemistry, spectro-analytical techniques, chromatography, survey of new analytical methods. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Adv Chromatography
data.description: Intensive examination of the contemporary practice of chromatography including available chromatographic techniques, their selection and application. Prerequisites: CHM 4130 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Organic Chem
data.description: Advanced topics in organic chemistry. Structure of organic molecules, reaction mechanisms, organic synthesis, and natural product chemistry. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Biol Chem
data.description: Structures of biological molecules; Biochemical reaction mechanisms; Enzyme kinetics; Biomolecular thermodynamics; Biomolecular spectroscopy. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Physical Chem
data.description: Prequantum physics, the Schrodinger equation and its solutions, atoms and molecules, rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopy. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Phys Chem II
data.description: Gas laws; thermodynamics and equilibrium, electrochemistry, and chemical kinetics. Prerequisite: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Advanced Polymer Chem
data.description: Advanced aspects of polymer chemistry. Properties, synthesis, uses and characterization of various polymeric materials. Prerequisites: CHM 2210 and CHM 2211. Corequisite: Graduate Standing.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Learning Theories: 3DL
data.description: An investigation of Three-Dimensional Learning and how it can be used to synthesize information learned in their chemistry courses. Also emphasizes assessment of scientific practices and core ideas.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Advanced BioChem II
data.description: Introduction to biochemical pathways regulation and intra- and extracellular communication on the molecular level.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Statistical Thermo
data.description: Principles of statistical thermodynamics. Ensembles, classical and quantum statistics, ideal and nonideal gases, equilibrium, crystals, liquids, and polymers.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Research Ethics
data.description: Ethical issues in biochemical research. Scientific misconduct, professional integrity, intellectual property, authorship and publication. Corequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Ind Study Chemistry
data.description: Independent study and problems in an area of chemistry, under faculty supervision. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Grad Research
data.description: The student works directly with a professor on a research project. Credit is assigned on the basis of four hr/wk per credit hour. Results to be presented as a seminar. Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Graduate Seminar
data.description: An examination of various current research topics in chemistry. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Chem Colloquium
data.description: Analysis of current developments and topics presented by faculty members and registered students. Prerequisite: Admission to graduate program in chemistry.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Supervised Teaching
data.description: Graduate student serves as lecturer and demonstrator in undergraduate laboratories coordinated and supervised by a faculty member. May be repeated. A maximum of three hours may apply to the Master's degree. Prerequisite: Good graduate standing.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Thesis Research
data.description: Research toward completion of Master's Thesis. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of the department.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Thesis
data.description: Completion of thesis. Prerequisite: Permission of major professor.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: Dissertation Researc
data.description: Research towards the completion of a doctoral dissertation. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Graduate Standing.

data.subject: CHM
data.name: PH.D. Dissertation
data.description: Completion of doctoral dissertation. Prerequisite: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy. May be repeated.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Survey Forensic Sci
data.description: A survey course introducing the principles and techniques of forensic science as they pertain to crime scene investigation and crime laboratory analysis.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Surv For Sci Lab
data.description: Laboratory course to accompany survey of forensic science lecture with emphasis on biological evidence. Topics include, CSI, DNA, toxicology, and serology.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Science
data.description: Modern instrumental methods of chemical analysis and their use in the administration of justice.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Science Lab
data.description: Laboratory to accompany Forensic Science, CHS 4503C.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Sci Intern
data.description: Internship in a forensic-science laboratory, contributing in a specific manner on an assigned problem. Twenty hrs/wk. Written report required. Open only to students in the Criminalistics Chemistry Program.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Marine Chemistry
data.description: A study of how the chemistry of marine systems operate and interact with biological, geological, and physical processes. Prerequisites:  CHM2210 and CHM2210L,  or  CHM 2200 and  CHM 2200L; CHM3120, CHM3120L, (or permission of the instructor)

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Intro. to 3-D Learning
data.description: An overview of Three-Dimensional Learning and how students can use this theory of learning to synthesize the information learned in their introductory chemistry courses. Prerequisites: CHM1045, CHM 1046,CHM 2210,CHM 2211, and CHM 3120

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Analy Lab
data.description: Laboratory to accompany Forensic Analysis CHS 5535. Prerequisites: CHM 3120, CHM 3120L, CHM 2211, CHM 2211L or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Toxicology
data.description: Provides the basic concepts of forensic toxicology as it applies to drug and body fluid analysis. Prerequisites: CHM 2211+L, CHM 3120+L, CHM 4305+L (BCH 3033+L) or permission of instructor.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Forensic Chemistry
data.description: Advanced analytical methods in Forensic Chemistry for application to the analysis of controlled substances, materials (ie., paint, glass, and fibers), flammable and explosives residues with an emphasis on new methods and method development.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Advanced Radiochemistry
data.description: Radioanalytical techniques, applications of radioisotopes and tracers, nuclear reactor, the chemistry of trausuranic elements, the nuclear fuel cycle and advanced solvent extraction processes. Prerequisite: CHS 6110.

data.subject: CHS
data.name: Grad Forens Intern
data.description: Internship in an operational forensic laboratory, contributing in a specific manner on an assigned research project. Six hours a week minimum residence time per credit in the lab under the supervision of a host lab scientist and a faculty member is required. A final written report and presentation required. Prerequisite: Core courses in Forensic M.S. Program.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Internship-Teaching CS
data.description: Internship for teaching computational thinking to students in K-12, following established curriculum such as Google CS First, Code.org, and MIT Media Lab's Scratch. May be repeated.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports on independent investigations.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Capstone I
data.description: Students learn how to perform efficiently in Agile/Scrum teams of up to 5 members and learn how to design and implement solutions to problems as a team. Prerequisite: (COP 3337 or COP 3804) and Junior Standing

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Enterprise Security
data.description: Policies and practices for information assurance, incident response, disaster recovery, cost assessment, vulnerability assessment, vulnerability testing, and risk mitigation strategies. Prerequisite: CNT 4403 or EEL 4806

data.subject: CIS
data.name: IT Automation
data.description: IT automation: mgmt models, auditing, assets, change mgmt, network monitoring, OS imaging, patch mgmt, help desk, remote control, user state mgmt, end-point security, backup, disaster recovery.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Senior Project
data.description: Students work on faculty supervised projects in teams of up to 5 members to design and implement solutions to problems utilizing knowledge obtained across the sprectum of Computer Science courses. Prerequisites: CEN 4010 and Permission of the Senior Project Coordinator.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Capstone II
data.description: Students work on faculty supervised projects in teams of up to 5 members to design and implement solutions to problems utilizing knowledge obtained across the spectrum of Computer Science courses. Prerequisite: CIS 3950 and Senior Standing.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Advanced Digital Forensic
data.description: Presents advanced AI/ML-based concepts in forensic software, tools, technology. Provides experience in selection and use of different tools for analyzing evidence and aiding investigations. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Soc Econ Pol Asp Cyber
data.description: The broader human context of cybersecurity, from the perspective of society, economics, and policy. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Storage Systems
data.description: Introduction to storage systems, storage system components, storage architecture, devices, trends and applications, performance, RAID, MEMS and portable storage, file-systems, OS storage management.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Principles of Cybersec
data.description: Cybersecurity algorithms, techniques. Mathematical foundations. Symmetric and public key encryption. Authentication, key infrastructure, certificates. Covert channels. Access control. Vulnerabilities. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Fund of Computer Security
data.description: Information assurance algorithms and techniques. Security vulnerabilities. Symmetric and public key encryption. Authentication and Kerberos. Key infrastructure and certificate. Mathematical foundations. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Systems Security
data.description: Risk, Trust, and Threat models; Types of Attacks; Safe Programming Techniques; Operating System Mechanisms, Virtual Machine Systems; Hardware Security Enforces; Application Security; Personal Security. Prerequisite: CIS 5372.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports on independent investigations. Prerequisite: Permission of the department.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Advanced Special Topics
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special advanced studies not otherwise offered.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Thesis
data.description: Prerequisite: Completion of all other requirements for the M.S. Degree in Computer Science.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Graduate Research
data.description: Doctoral research prior to candidacy. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of the department.

data.subject: CIS
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Prerequisite: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: CIV
data.name: Civic Literacy Test
data.description: N/A

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Professional Development
data.description: An overview and exploration of development of the criminal justice profession.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Policing in Society
data.description: Examines the establishment, role and function of policing in democratic society.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Security & Crime Science
data.description: Examines situational and legislative approaches to the prevention of crime and the apprehension of suspects. Emphasis on theories, problem-solving, implementation and consequences of these approaches.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Crime Scene Investigation
data.description: Understand how to perform basic search patterns. Demonstrate how to identify, document, and collect forensic evidence. Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different evidence types.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Cold Case Investigation
data.description: Explores best practice cold case investigation techniques as well as discuss resources available to investigators.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Comparative CJS
data.description: A comparative study of the major legal traditions (e.g., common law, civil law, socialist law) and analysis of the criminal justice system across the world, including police, courts, and corrections.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Interview & Interrogation
data.description: An overview of best practices in interviewing techniques and interrogation tactics in the criminal justice system. Compares and contrasts witness/victim interviews and suspect interrogations.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Cyber Crime
data.description: Examines the types, extent and response to cyber crime, including the constitutional protections and procedural law that governs its detection and prosecution.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Crime Science Capstone
data.description: This senior capstone course integrates material learned in the Crime Science curriculum.Prerequisite: Senior standing in Crime Science

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Efficacy of Forensics
data.description: Discussion of forensic evidence efficacy, issues facing evidence collection and examination, use of forensic evidence in the investigative process, and courtroom challenges.

data.subject: CJE
data.name: Law Enforcement Practicum
data.description: Combines classroom instruction with specialized police training and workplace experience to produce successful law enforcement professionals and future leaders in the field.

data.subject: CJJ
data.name: Juvenile Justice
data.description: Examines the nature and extent of delinquency and the justice system response to juvenile crime.

data.subject: CJL
data.name: The Courts
data.description: An overview of jurisdiction, policies, and procedures of courts in the administration of criminal justice.

data.subject: CJL
data.name: Justice&Constitution
data.description: A case law study of constitutional issues related to the administration of criminal justice.

data.subject: CJL
data.name: Criminal Evidence
data.description: A study of evidentiary principles and rules of evidence, and their application in a courtroom setting.

data.subject: CJL
data.name: Criminal Law
data.description: Examines the structure, function, and principles of criminal law, including the acts, mental state, and attendant circumstances that are necessary elements of crime.

data.subject: CJL
data.name: Legal Issues in CJ
data.description: This course examines diverse and frequently debated legal topics from both legal and sociological perspectives.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Personal Adjustment
data.description: Study of personal adjustment in the social and occupational life of the individual. Emphasis on interpersonal aspects of effective behavior.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Child Psychopatholog
data.description: Various forms of abnormal behavior in infancy, childhood, and adolescence are examined within the context of traditional and contemporary psychological theory. Problems of differential diagnosis and forms of remediation are discussed.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Psychopathology
data.description: Various forms of behavior pathology are examined in the light of traditional and current concepts of mental health and illness. Problems of diagnosis and treatment are discussed. The role of social mores is examined.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Psych Health & Ill
data.description: Course provides an overview of the field of health psychology and behavioral medicine with an emphasis on psychological, social, cultural, and global factors affecting health and health care/policy.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Psychotherapy
data.description: Current approaches to the treatment and improvement of psychological disorders are critically surveyed. Emphasis is placed on the examination of the various techniques of psychotherapy and behavior therapy. Broader strategies of prevention and mental health promotion like consultation, counseling, and programmed agency services are also studied.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Affective Bases
data.description: A comprehensive introduction to the literature on affective science with a focus on: behavioral,biological, cognitive, and social dimensions, as well as the relevance to clinical science. Prerequisite: Graduate Standing

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Foundation Practicum I
data.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the principles of psychological assessment and measurement in children and hands on practice in the administration of selected cognitive tests. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Assessment and Treatment II
data.description: Provides an in-depth examination of the evidenced-based assessments used in the psychological evaluation and treatment for children and adolescents with externalizing problems. Prerequisite: CLP 5007.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Assessment and Treatment III
data.description: Provides an overview of theory, research, and evidenced-based practices relevant for evidence based assessment and intervention for use with developmental, learning and pediatric disorders. Prerequisite: CLP 5007.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Dissem and Implement Research
data.description: Addresses the increasing need to bridge research and practice to inform a new generation of effective services that are accessible to the large numbers of children and families in need.

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Adv Clinical Prac
data.description: Allows students to practice clinical skills through participation in interactive classroom exercises while gaining clinical experience. Prerequisite: Clinical Practicum (CLP 6945).

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Foundations Practicum II
data.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the principles of psychological treatments for children and adolescents, with applied practice and supervision in psychotherapy techniques. Prerequisites: PSY 5939 (Foundation Practicum I: Assessment).

data.subject: CLP
data.name: Clinical Internship
data.description: Clinical Internship in Psychology for Ph.D. candidates who have completed the Clinical Practicum and at least 45 graduate credit hours. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and permission of the instructor, CLP 6945.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Sensors for IoT
data.description: This course introduces sensors and sensor design for loT devices. Topics include history of loT-enabled sensors, design and fabrication of smart sensors, theory and case studies of important smart sen. Prerequisite: EGN 2271

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Microcontrollers for IoT
data.description: Overview of embedded systems and microcontrollers with a comprehensive in-depth look at the MSP43Q. Students will learn about this powerful mixed-signal, low power consumption microcontroller. Prerequisite: EGN 2271

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Wireless Comm. for IoT
data.description: This course will cover source coding for data compression, channel coding for error correction, digital transmission and reception, wireless channels, and the narrow-band loT communication system.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: IoT/Sensor Data Analytics
data.description: This course examines the ingestion, storage, analysis and reporting of massive quantities of loT/sensor data collected from distributed data sources and processing with big data technologies. Prerequisites: EEL2880 or COP 2210 or COP 2250 or equivalent or instructor permission

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Applied Machine Learning
data.description: This course will focus on the application of traditional machine learning algorithms and popular framework to large sensor and loT data sets.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: IoT Python Prog
data.description: This course will introduce students to the Python programming language as it applies to its interaction to sensor and loT devices. Prerequisites: EEL2880 or COP 2210 or COP 2250 or equivalent or instructor permission

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Network Protocols for loT
data.description: This course introduces the underlying network protocols for loT communications. Protocols at the medium access and network layers are discussed. Prerequisite: TCN 4211

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Mobile and loT Security
data.description: Emerging topics in policies and practices for mobile and loT devices. Skills include identifying and assessing values and threats, and mitigating risks to loT and mobile assets. Prerequisites: CNT 4403 or EEL 4806

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Computer Security
data.description: Fundamental concepts and principles of computing and network security, symmetric and asymmetric cryptography, hash functions, authentication, firewalls and intrusion detection, and operational issues.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Advanced Network Management
data.description: Advanced principles of modern internetworking network design and implementation. Hands on experience with routers and switches and core Internet support protocols.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Data Communications
data.description: Study Computer network models and protocol layers. Topics include: error handling, frames, broadcast networks, channel allocation; network routing algorithms, internetworking, TCP/IP, ATM protocols.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Net-centric Computing
data.description: This course covers networking fundamentals, network security, network applications, mobile and wireless computing. The course focuses on network programming, including sockets and web programming concepts.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Adv IoT Analytics & Cloud
data.description: This course will focus on the theoretical concepts, principles, tools, techniques and deployment models and analytics for cloud services.

data.subject: CNT
data.name: Adv Sensor/loT Deep Learn
data.description: This course will focus use of deep learning techniques and algorithms on structured and unstructured data received from sensors and loT devices.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Intro to Comm Arts
data.description: This course will provide students with a comprehensive overview of academic policies, procedures, and requirements for matriculation and graduation from the Department of Communication Arts.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Bus And Prof Commun
data.description: Identification of communication situations specific to business and the professions. Analysis of variables related to communication objectives and preparation of oral presentations and business correspondence.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Writing for Business
data.description: This is a two credit course designed for Business majors to develop and improve speech and writing techniques applied to business contexts.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Organizational Comm
data.description: Explores the role of communication in organizations, as well as the role of technology, corporate culture, leadership, teamwork, ethics, and diversity in effective communication among organizations.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Managerial Communication
data.description: Students examine effective communication in hiring and promoting, in conflict, in community interaction and in the internal communication of an organization.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Crisis Comm
data.description: This course reviews the latest research, explains how crisis communication can prevent/reduce the threats of a crisis, and provides guidelines for how best to act and react in an emergency situation.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Nonverbal Communication
data.description: Study of nonlinguistic and paralinguistic aspects of communication, including personal space, body language, eye contact, touch, and paralanguage.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Com in Film
data.description: This course will examine the unique relationship between communication and film from the 1920's (the era of silent film) through today.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Intercultural Comm
data.description: Students develop the skills to build and maintain relationships across cultures by focusing on similarities and differences in communication behaviors, perceptions, language usage and social practices.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Social Media Impact Comm
data.description: This course will examine 'social media' from a communication perspective; with a focus on how media technologies influence the way we communicate (verbally and nonverbally) with others.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Design Comm Strategies
data.description: This course develops skills in designing communication strategies - the plans for communicating information related to specific issue, event, situation, or audience.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Environmental Communication
data.description: Through landmark essays exploring ecological conflicts, land use policy, natural disasters, and ecological movements, this course analyzes the communication applications related to the field.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Fnd. of Comm.
data.description: Introduction to future practitioners of public relations, advertising, and applied communication of the written and visual styles of communication used in their professions. Prerequisites: ENC 1101 and ENC 1102

data.subject: COM
data.name: Internship Experience
data.description: Experience in communication practice learned through work and application in an organization.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Research Meth Comm
data.description: This course will introduce students to a range of social sciences and communication research methods (quantitative and qualitative) applied to communication professions and scholarship.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Interviewing
data.description: This class will prepare students for their professional careers in the areas of information gathering and employment interviews and an online portfolio.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Internat Business Comm
data.description: This course will provide students with the theoretical and experiential framework for examining the meaning of communication in global business.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Conflict Management
data.description: Students will analyze conflict management concepts, principles, strategies and techniques, and examine the communication skills needed for productive conflict management or resolution.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Dir Ind Stud in Comm Arts
data.description: Specialized intensive study in a specific area of special interest to the student.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Spec Topics in Comm Arts
data.description: Intensive study for a small group of students in a particular topic, or limited number of topics not otherwise offered in the curriculum.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Internship in Comm Arts
data.description: Internship credit ranges from 1-6 credits. Three credits max per semester, up to 2 semesters. A 3 credit internship is 12-15 hours per week at job (for a 16 week semester) plus class assignments. Prerequisite:  Minimum of 3.0 GPA for communication arts and/or PRAAC

data.subject: COM
data.name: Campaigns
data.description: The senior capstone seminar synthesizes the major curriculum components through an integrated communication campaigns working with real organizations and evaluated by communication experts. Prerequisite: MMC 3303, MMC 4200, MMC 3123 or COM3714, IDS 3309, VIC 3400, (ADV 3008 or PUR 3000), (MMC 4609 or COM 4310), ADV4323, COM 3520, PUR 4101, and 102 earned credits.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Indep. Study
data.description: Specialized intensive study in an area of special interest to the student with a focus on directed, independent research. Prerequisite: Requires prior approval by instructor, graduate standing, and full admittance in the program.

data.subject: COM
data.name: Grad Internship
data.description: On-the-job learning in activity at selected and approved organizations. May include advertising and PR agencies, as well as private, governmental or non-profit organizations. Prerequisite: Requires prior approval by instructor.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Intro to Computer Programming
data.description: Uses graphics and animation in a media programming environment to teach problem solving and programming concepts to students with no prior experience. May not be taken after COP 2210 or COP 2250.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Programming I
data.description: A first course in computer science that uses a structured programming language to study programming and problem solving on the computer. Includes the design, construction and analysis of programs.  Student participation in a closed instructional lab is required.  This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Java Programming
data.description: A first course in programming for IT majors.  Syntax and semantics of Java.  Classes and Objects.  Object oriented program development.  Not acceptable for credit for Computer Science majors.  This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Programming II
data.description: An intermediate level course in Object Oriented programming.  Topics include primitive types, control structures, strings arrays, objects and classes, data abstraction inheritance polymorphism and an introduction to data structures. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Data Structures
data.description: Basic concepts of data organization, running time of a program, abstract types, data structures including linked lists, nary trees, sets and graphs, internal sorting. This course will have additional fees. Prerequisites:  COP 3337 and (MAD 2104 or COT 3100)

data.subject: COP
data.name: Intermediate Java
data.description: A second course in Java programming.  Continues Programming in Java by discussing object-oriented programming in a more detail, with larger programming projects and emphasis on inheritance.  Not acceptable for credit  for CS majors. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Designing Web Pages
data.description: Designing basic pages for display on the World Wide Web.  Fundamental design elements and contemporary design tools are discussed. Computer literacy is expected.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Coop Edu Computing
data.description: Cooperative Internship for Computer Science and Information Technology majors. May not be used for Computer Science or Information Technology elective credit. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Win Programming - It
data.description: Application development techniques in Windows: Classes, Objects, Controls, Forms and Dialogs, Database, and Multitier Application Architecture.  Students cannot receive credit for both COP 4005 and COP 4226. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Systems Programming
data.description: Programming in C and advanced programming in Unix environments, including multiprocessing and multithreading. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Algorithm Techniques
data.description: Basic algorithm design, including greedy algorithms, divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, randomization, and backtracking. Graph, string, numerical, geometric, and optimization algorithms.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Prin Of Prog Lang
data.description: A comparative study of several programming languages and paradigms. Emphasis is given to design, evaluation and implementation. Programs are written in a few of the languages. This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Operating Syst Princ
data.description: Operating systems design principles and implementation techniques. Address spaces, system call interface, process/threads, interprocess communication, deadlock, scheduling, memory, virtual memory, I/O, file systems. Prerequisites:  COP 4338 AND (CDA 3102 OR CDA 4101) This course will have additional fees.

data.subject: COP
data.name: Mobile Application Development
data.description: Design and development of mobile applications. Introduction to the mobile application frameworks, including user interface, sensors, event handling, data management and network interface. Prerequisites:  (CEN3721 and COP4814) or (CAP4101 and CEN4010)

data.subject: COP
data.name: Info Retrieval
