data.description: Research activities required for Doctoral students in special education prior to candidacy and dissertation. Serves as a bridge between courses and the comprehensive examination. Prerequisite: Doctoral standing.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Analysis Eng Syst
data.description: Statistics and probability analysis of materials and fluids experiments, structural and fluid system modeling and analysis using lumped parameters; numerical methods to find solutions. Prerequisites:  MAC2312, and (EML2032 or EEL 2880 or COP 2210 or COP 2250 or BME 2740)

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Applied Mechanics
data.description: Statics and dynamics of solids and fluids. Science of engineering materials. Open to non-mechanical engineering students only.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Eng Mecha Of Materia
data.description: Analysis of axial, torsional, bending, combined stresses, and strains. Plotting of shear, moment and deflection diagram with calculus applications and interpretations.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Materials Testing
data.description: Introduction to measurements of basic mechanical properties of materials. Experiments include axial tension, compression, torsion, flexure, and the response of simple structural elements.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Fea In Mech Engr
data.description: Finite Element Analysis is developed as a means to determine stress and deformation levels as well as temperature and heat flux levels in solids. Application by means of commercial software.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Finite Elment Method
data.description: Matrix techniques and variational methods in solid mechanics; single element, assemblage and generalized theory; non-linear analysis; applications in structural and soil mechanics, torsion, heat conduction and hydro-elasticity, etc.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Fem In Me
data.description: Utilize the finite element method to solve problems in heat transfer, fluid dynamics, diffusion, acoustics, vibrations, and electromagnetism, as well as the coupled interaction of these phenomena.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Structural Dynamics
data.description: Fundamentals of free, forced, and transient vibration of singles and multidegree of freedom structures, including damping of lumped and distributed parameters systems. Graduate students have to do a project.

data.subject: EGM
data.name: Adv Comp Analysis
data.description: Modeling of vibrational and dynamic systems including solution of governing equations by analytical and numerical techniques.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Engineering Orient
data.description: Introduction to aspects of the engineering profession. Computer tools and basic engineering science. Team-based engineering projects.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Engineering Drawing
data.description: Laboratory experiences in the principles and practice of idea development and expression through free hand sketching and conventional instrument drafting. A beginning course for students with no prior drafting experience.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Intro to Cir. & Elec. HW
data.description: Introduction to resistive circuits, laws governing circuits, electronic switches, logic gates, electronic memories, standard input and output ports.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Statics
data.description: Forces on particles, and two and three dimensional rigid bodies, equilibrium of forces, moments, couples, centroids, section properties, and load analysis of structures; vector approach is utilized.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Dynamics
data.description: Study of the motion of particles and rigid bodies, conservation of energy and momentum. A vector approach is utilized.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Thermodynamics I
data.description: Fundamental concepts of basic thermodynamics including first and second law topics, equations of state and general thermodynamic relationships.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Materials Eng
data.description: A study of materials used in engineering. Includes atomic structure phase diagrams and reactions within solid materials.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Engineering Economy
data.description: Assist students to develop competency in the fundamentals of engineering economics for all engineering disciplines. The methods of economic analysis in general engineering applications include: decision analysis techniques, time value of money calculations, essential techniques in economic analysis of alternatives, depreciation, corporate income tax considerations, and criteria for decisions under various constraints.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Human-centered Design
data.description: A collaborative, projects-based course in human-centered design and systems analysis. Should be taken one semester prior to or concurrently with EGN 4943, EML 4905, or equivalent courses.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Coop Ed in Eng
data.description: The cooperative education in engineering course is for current interdisciplinary engineering students to pursue an experiential education opportunity at an organization focused on their area of study. Prerequisite: Junior standing

data.subject: EGN
data.name: CENGR Internship
data.description: N/A

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Env Eng for Global Sustain
data.description: This course examines the effects of modern humans on the environment and explores the role of engineers in creating an environmentally sustainable future. Also serves as a global learning course. Prerequisites: ENV 3001 or PHY 2048 and CHM 1045

data.subject: EGN
data.name: ID Capstone Des Proj II
data.description: A senior-level capstone design experience focusing on prototyping, testing, iterating, examining the global and local implications of your project, and manufacturing a final product. Prerequisite: EGN 3910, EGN 4943

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Design of Tall Bldg
data.description: The course analyzes different modern high-rise structural systems, and includes the dynamics of wind and earthquakes to efficiently design very tall buildings and their ancillary structures.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Seminar on STEM Edu Res
data.description: Weekly interactive and engaging presentations featuring faculty, students and guest speakers sharing research topics in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) topics.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Advanced Special Topics
data.description: An advanced special topics course for PhD students to pursue and study areas in engineering or computing education at an advanced level that otherwise would not be offered.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Teach Pract Eng Comp Ed
data.description: Structured application of educational theories and pedagogy through classroom teaching experiences and weekly learning community meetings. Requires students find a faculty teaching mentor.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Graduate Research
data.description: Doctoral research prior to candidacy. Repeatable.

data.subject: EGN
data.name: Dissertation Res
data.description: Research towards completing doctorate research upon completion of their comprehensive exams. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Intro To Engineering
data.description: This course will provide a broad exposure, 'birdseye' view, of the engineering profession to entering freshmen.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Ethics/Legal Aspects
data.description: Codes of ethics, professional responsibilities and rights, law and engineering, contracts, torts, evidence.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Foundations of IDE
data.description: This project-based course introduces students to interdisciplinary engineering work and human-centered design. May not be taken concurrently with or after Senior Design.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: ENGR Prof. Development
data.description: This course will equip engineering students with an understanding of core competencies that engineers are expected to possess in an increasingly globalized context.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Enterprise Sys Conf
data.description: Enterprise systems overview; major enterprise functions; standard operation procedures; system configuration and parameters; master data; user interfaces and reports; and hands-on experience. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Enterprise Sys Intg
data.description: Enterprise architectures; work flow modeling and design; systems integration methodology; vertical and horizontal integration; master data analysis and integration; and hands-on experience. Prerequisite: EGS 5620.

data.subject: EGS
data.name: Equity in STEM Education
data.description: An analysis of diversity and inclusion through research, policy and practice within science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education for the private and public sectors.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Manuf Processes
data.description: Study of interrelationships among materials, design and processing and their impact on workplace design, productivity and process analysis.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Tqm For Engineers
data.description: Study and application of quality management concepts and statistical quality techniques within the framework of continuous improvement methodologies. Prerequisite: EIN 3235 Evaluation of engineering data or equivalent statistics course or permission of instructor

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Ind Fin Decisions
data.description: The use of financial techniques and data in planning, controlling and coordinating industrial activities. This course will familiarize the student with accounting concepts and analytical methods.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Advanced TQM
data.description:
Advanced concepts in Quality Management including experimental design for scientific
management, QFD, Benchmarking, Measurement Systems, regression analysis in quality, and quality loss functions. Prerequisites: EIN 5226

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Adv Prod Plan/Contr
data.description: Analytical and algorithmic planning methodologies, planning and scheduling technologies, sequencing rules, control strategies, and line balancing methods. Prerequisite: EIN 4334.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual supervised study by a faculty. A study plan and a final report are work required. Prerequisite: Departmental approval.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: ISE Internship
data.description: To provide graduate students with work experience under approved industrial supervision.  Prerequisite: Departmental approval.

data.subject: EIN
data.name: Master's Thesis
data.description:
The students following the thesis option should work on his/her thesis through this 
course.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Polymer Sci Engr
data.description: Introduction to molecular structure; property relationships; preparation, processing and applications of macromolecular materials.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Mech & Mat Science
data.description: A mid-level course addressing the selection of engineering materials based on static and dynamic loadings, environmental analysis and the experimental analysis of mechanical systems. Emphasis on metals and composite materials.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Mech & Mat Sci Lab
data.description: Introduction to measurements of basic mechanical properties of materials. Experiments including tension, bending, torsion, fatigue, buckling, strain, and stress visualization.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Phys Prop Of Matls
data.description: The physical properties of materials, including the influence of structure on properties, thermodynamics of solids and phase transformations and kinetics on microstructural development. Prerequisite: EGM 4521C.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Nanomech and Nanotrib
data.description: Mechanical and tribological properties at nano-scale length, fundamentals of nanoindentation and nanoDMA, application of nanoindentation for hard, soft, natural and biological materials. Prerequisites: EGN 3365 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Crystal Xrd
data.description: Principles of crystallography and the use of x-ray diffraction and Raman Spectroscopy to characterize crystalline solids.  Prerequisite: Instructor's permission.

data.subject: EMA
data.name: Polymer Process Eng
data.description: Standard and advanced processing methods, characterization of morphology, and reaction processing. An industry-based case study analysis integrates heat and mass transport, and fluid flow during materials processing; and the economics of materials processing and recycling.

data.subject: EME
data.name: Intro Ed Tech
data.description: Introduction to the use of educational technology. Examination of productivity tools, interactive multimedia, communications, educational software, instructional applications and ethical, legal, social, and professional issues.

data.subject: EME
data.name: Computers In Clsrm
data.description: Learning to use microcomputers in a school setting. Emphasis on evaluating and documenting software; creation of classroom materials leading to development of useful software.

data.subject: EME
data.name: Computers Teach Tool
data.description: This course develops ability to use the microcomputer as an object, medium, and manager of instruction in the classroom.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Intro to CAD for ME
data.description: Introduction to technical graphical visualization and communication for mechanical design; knowledge and skills to use a software package to create multi-view and 3-D Drawings using ANSI standards.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Programming for ME
data.description: Operation of computers and programming languages for mechanical design.  C++ will be used to develop programs for mechanical design problems.  Introduction to Visual Basic and Fortran 90 environments.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Simultn Software ME
data.description: Commercial software to reinforce the concepts of stress, deformation, fluid flow, rigid body dynamics, heat transfer and to optimize solid model designs via multi-disciplinary computational analysis. Prerequisite: EML 1533 or permission of the instructor. Corequisites: EMA 3702 and (EML 3126 or CWR 3201)

data.subject: EML
data.name: Transp Phenon
data.description: Fundamental principles of transport phenomena; Governing Equations; Compressible Flow.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Transp Pheno Lab
data.description: Experiments illustrating the principles of transport phenomena: wind tunnel, shock tubes, airfoils.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Systems Dynamics
data.description: Introduction to modeling of mechanical systems; derivation of system equations and response of fluid, thermal, and vibrational systems. Available solution methods will be discussed.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Instrumentation Lab
data.description: A practical study of common instrumentation elements and measurement systems used in mechanical and electro-mechanical applications.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Energy Systems
data.description: Review of theory and engineering aspects of conventional and renewable energy conversion and storage systems, fossil fuels, and nuclear power plants and renewable energy technologies.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Mech Design I
data.description: Design of basic machine members including shafts, springs, belts, clutches, chains, etc.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Heat Transfer
data.description: Study of the fundamentals of heat transfer including conduction, convection, and radiation. Computer applications and design problems emphasized.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Mech Vibrations
data.description: Theory and application of mechanical vibrations. Includes damped and undamped vibrations with one or more degrees of freedom computer methods emphasized.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Int. Combust. Engine
data.description: Engine types, characteristics and operation. Performance factors, fuel combustion, power cycles. Knock and engine variables.  Exhaust emissions. Fuel Metering. Compressors and turbines.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Mech Design II
data.description: Continuation of design analysis of elementary machine elements, including lubrication bearings, and gearings. Introduction to advanced analysis techniques.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Ethics Dsn Proj Org
data.description: Organization to include problem definition, goals, survey, conceptual and preliminary design, ethics and cost components, social and environmental impact, presentation to enhance communication skills. Corequisites:  EGM 3311, EML 4140, EML 3500, and senior standing

data.subject: EML
data.name: Design Optimization
data.description: Conceptual formulations and methods using gradient-based and evolutionary algorithms for single-objective and multi-objective unconstrained and constrained optimization. Use of response surfaces and commercial software.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Des Therm Fluid Sys
data.description: Design of thermal and fluid systems and components. Piping networks, duct works. Selection of pumps and fittings. Basic design of heat exchangers, turbomachinery, pumps, and fans.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Comp Thermo Fluid
data.description: Introduction of numerical methods for compressible and incompressible flows and heat transfer.  Topics include explicit and implicit schemes, accuracy and stability in different coordinate systems.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Intro Mechatronics
data.description: This course will introduce computer controlled precise motion generation in smart machines. Prerequisites:  EEL3110C or (EEL 3110 AND EEL 3110L)

data.subject: EML
data.name: Modeling Of Robots
data.description: Robot models in terms of geometric parameters. Kinematic and dynamic modeling of robots. Static and dynamic force equilibrium. Robot programming, control algorithms, simulations.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Sensor/Signal Proc
data.description: This course will introduce the basic sensors and signal processing techniques for design and development of smart products.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Robot Design
data.description: Robotic arm and mobile platform design including a review of major design components such as actuators, sensors, and controllers.  Computer-based design, analysis and hands-on projects.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Senior Design Proj
data.description: Project statement, in-depth survey, conceptual and structural design, analysis, statistical and cost analyses, ethical, societal and environmental impact, prototype construction, final presentation.

data.subject: EML
data.name: UG Research Exp
data.description: Participate in funded research in the areas of nanotechnology, advanced materials, mechanics, mechatronics, robotics, thermal and fluid sciences and computational engineering.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Special Topics/Proj
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports on independent investigations selected by the students and professor with approval of advisor.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Co-Op Wk Experience
data.description: Supervised full-time work experience in engineering field. Limited to students admitted to the Co-op program with consent of advisor. Evaluation and reports required.

data.subject: EML
data.name: AI-ME
data.description: N/A

data.subject: EML
data.name: Int Thermodynamics
data.description: Thermodynamic approach to processes and engines; alternative formulations and Legendre transformations; Maxwell relations, first and second order phase transitions. Prerequisite: EML 3101.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Int Heat Transfer
data.description: Multidimensional heat conduction under steady and transient conditions. Heat, mass and momentum transfer. Radiation heat transfer. Gas radiation. Free and forced convection. Prerequisite: EML 4140.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Fund of Microfab
data.description: Science of miniaturization will be introduced. Materials choices, scaling laws, different options to make very small machines and practical applications will be emphasized. Progress related to state-of-the-art BioMicroElectro Mechanical Systems will be presented.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Smart Mach Des Dev
data.description: Design of independently operating smart electromechanical systems (most consumer products) which monitor their environment, give decisions, and create motion. Prerequisites: EML 4804 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Optimization
data.description: Multi-disciplinary numerical analysis combined with single objective and multi-objective unconstrained and constrained optimization and sensitivity analysis techniques to optimize the design.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Int. Fluid Mech.
data.description: Basic concepts and scope of fluid dynamics; non-inertial reference frames. Two-dimensional potential theory. Applications to airfoils. The Navier-Stokes equations; selected exact and approximate solutions. Prerequisite: EML 3126.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Sensors/App Mach Int
data.description: Sensors, signal analysis techniques, and error compensation methods will be introduced for machine intelligence. Production Machine Modeling and Design. Prerequisites: EML 4804, EML 4503, or equivalent, or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: EML
data.name: AMLME
data.description: N/A

data.subject: EML
data.name: Adv Dgn Of Robots
data.description: Kinematic analysis of mechanisms and robot arms, geometric configurations, analytical and numerical methods in kinematics. Prerequisites: EML 3222, EML 4806, and EML 4501.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Ind Studies
data.description: Individual research studies available for qualified graduate students. The work is to be performed under the supervision of an advisor. A report is to be submitted. Students may register for 1 to 3 credits per semester. Prerequisite: Advisor's permission.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Graduate level research carried out under the supervision of a faculty member.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Graduate Seminar
data.description: Different problems in Mechanical Engineering and results of ongoing research will be presented and discussed by invited experts. The seminar will expose the students to advances in existing and emerging areas of research. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Mech Mtrls Intrnshp
data.description: Graduate students gain work experience through supervised internship in industry. The student prepares an internship program proposal, and the work performed is documented in a report and presented. Prerequisite: Permission of the student's thesis advisor.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Masters Thesis
data.description: Master's thesis in any advanced topic, a report is to be submitted and an oral presentation is to be made. Students may register for one to six credits per semester. Total of six credits to be earned for the Master's Degree. Prerequisite: Advisor's permission.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Ph.D. Seminar
data.description: Various subjects in Mechanical Engineering and results of ongoing research will be presented and discussed by invited experts. The seminar will expose the students to advances in existing and emerging areas of research. Prerequisite: Ph.D. students only.

data.subject: EML
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Doctoral research leading to Ph.D. Mechanical Engineering dissertation. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing and Rhetoric I
data.description: The first in a two-course sequence introduces the principles of college-level writing and research. Students write for multiple rhetorical contexts, with emphasis on critical thinking and revision. Written work meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing and Rhetoric II
data.description: The second in a two-course sequence expands upon the writing and rhetorical strategies learned in ENC1101 and furthers students abilities to write and research arguments. Written work meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Essay Writing
data.description: A course in writing short descriptive, analytic, and argumentative essays. Does not fulfill core curriculum requirement. Students who have completed ENC 1101 or ENC 1102, or both, cannot receive credit for this course.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Prof and Tech Writing
data.description: Principles and practices of effective workplace writing. Students learn audience analysis in order to become more effective writers. Genres include memos, business letters, proposals, and reports. Written work meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Prof Tech Writing Comp
data.description: Introduces students to the expectations of written and verbal communication in the computer science profession; explores the ways in which technology and media help shape professional communication.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Adv Writing & Res
data.description: Provides instruction in the concepts and methods of critical response and argumentation, and in the formulation, analysis, and presentation of original research in extended academic papers. Written work meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Intro Writing Studies
data.description: Examines key questions in Writing Studies: What does it mean to be a writer? How do rhetoric and writing relate? What changes can writing make in diverse public, private, and professional contexts?

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing as Social Action
data.description: Writing for academic and public settings. A significant part of the course will consist of students doing writing-related volunteer work in the community.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing about Environment
data.description: Analysis and evaluation of a variety of marine coastal-themed texts mainstream articles, scientific articles, and novels. As well as develop a researched advocacy campaign.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Rhetorical Theory/Practice
data.description: An overview of various rhetorical traditions in order to help students understand and improve their discourse practices at school, work, or in technological spaces.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing Across Borders
data.description: This course explores the implications of both Western and Eastern rhetorical theories and practices for written communication in the age of globalization.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing and New Media
data.description: Provides intensive instruction on composing in new media formats with an eye on computer and network-based presentation, especially internet publication.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Legal Writing
data.description: Introduces students to writing and reasoning common in law school and legal practice. Course emphasizes clear, effective, and concise prose and focuses on objective and interpretive analytical skills.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: The Processes of Writing
data.description: Study of theoretical and practical aspects of one-to-one writing consultations. Students will learn the skills necessary to improve their writing and peer review skills.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Interdisciplinary Writing
data.description: For students who will become Peer Writing Fellows for Gordon Rule classes in various disciplines. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Community Writing Course
data.description: Developing the necessary rhetorical and analytical skills in order to compose written works that reflect writer's concerns as member of a community.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing About Film
data.description: Introduces students to writing critical reviews and analyses of film narrative.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Writing Exile Experience
data.description: Advanced writing and research course where students learn to write rhetorically through their close readings of exile narratives, writing and research projects. This class has a service component.

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Rhetoric of Food
data.description: An upper-division writing course in which students analyze rhetorical contexts related to food in order to better understand how language conditions our relationships to food today. Prerequisite: ENC 1102 or equivalent or ENC 2304

data.subject: ENC
data.name: MaterialCulturalW&R
data.description: Investigates what it means to write about material culture through a consideration of interdisciplinary scholarship in the fields of writing & rhetoric, literature, & material/cultural studies. Prerequisites: ENC 1101 and ENC 1102 or equivalent; or ENC 2304

data.subject: ENC
data.name: Special Topics Comp
data.description: Allows students to refine nonfiction writing skills in a variety of genres. May be repeated.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Approaches To Lit
data.description: Introduces critical approaches to the study of literature. Students will develop a vocabulary for reading, discussing, and writing about a variety of texts. Meets state composition requirement.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Contemp Lit Theory
data.description: An examination of the works of recent literary theorists.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Studies In The Film
data.description: Intensive examination of the work of a particular nation, group, or director. May also explore various film genres, e.g., documentary, horror, the Western. With change of content, may be retaken for credit.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports on independent investigations.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Co-Op Ed In Eng
data.description: A student majoring in English may spend one or two semesters fully employed in industry or government in a capacity relating to the major. May be repeated. (Pass/Fail Only). Prerequisite: Permission of the department.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Lit Crit & Schol
data.description: Techniques and goals of humanistic research, bibliography, and critical commentary.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Literary Theory
data.description: An introduction to issues in the nature of literature, the philosophy of criticism, and methods of interpretation. The theoretical foundations for literary study. Prerequisites: Admission to the graduate program in English or by permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Form And Theory
data.description: Various approaches and theories of practice in the major genres of imaginative writing, including development and articulation of the creative esthetic. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, reports on independent investigations, with the consent of the chairperson.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Thesis/Diss Wksp
data.description: A workshop providing practice in the type of writing, research, and analytical skills required for successful graduate study. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Spec Top In Pedagogy
data.description: The pedagogy of teaching a designated area of college and university English, such as Shakespeare, American literature, film studies, creative writing, or linguistics. Course content and organization to be determined by the individual professor. Course does not meet certification requirements.

data.subject: ENG
data.name: Coll Comp Practicum
data.description: Practical experience in the teaching of English at the university and college level through supervised activities to include tutorials, evaluating, and commenting on student essays, supervised classroom discussion and teaching. Course does not meet certification requirements.

data.subject: ENL
data.name: Modern Brit Lit
data.description: Focuses on 20th Century British literature but includes genres of the modern and post modern periods. Repeatable with a change of topic. Prerequisites: ENC1101 and ENC1102 or ENC 2304

data.subject: ENL
data.name: Major British Writer
data.description: Each section will consider the lifework of an author such as Chaucer, Spenser, Milton, Pope, Wordsworth, Dickens, Browning, Joyce, or others. May be repeated with change of content.

data.subject: ENL
data.name: Periods In Eng Lit
data.description: Individual sections will read a group of literary works from one specified period of English literature, such as the Medieval, Renaissance, Victorian, twentieth-century and contemporary periods. May be repeated with change of content.

data.subject: ENL
data.name: Major Brit Lit Fig
data.description: Each section will consider the lifework of an author such as Chaucer, Spenser, Milton, Pope, Wordsworth, Dickens, Browning, Joyce, or others. May be repeated.

data.subject: ENT
data.name: Entrepreneur: New Bus Develop
data.description: Designed for those wanting to start or grow a business. Students analyze unstructured business situations and use critical thinking and business development principles to develop the solutions.

data.subject: ENT
data.name: Intl Entrepreneurship
data.description: This course provides a foundation in international entrepreneurship, focusing on the experiences of small as well as large entrepreneurial firms. Cross-national and cross-cultural business practices are analyzed.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Intro Enviro Engrng
data.description: Introduction to environmental engineering problems; water and wastewater treatment, air pollution, noise, solid and hazardous wastes. Prerequisites: CHM 1045, CHM 1045L, and MAC 2312 or MAC 2282 Corequisite:  ENV3001L

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Envir Lab I
data.description: A corequisite to ENV 3001. Practical applications of the theory learned in the course and experience in detecting and measuring some environmental problems. Prerequisites: CHM 1045, CHM 1045L, CGN 2420, and MAC 2312 or MAC 2282 Corequisite:  ENV 3001.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Air Pollution Engr
data.description: Factors contributing to air pollution: pollutants and their effects, sources, chemical transformations, and meteorology. Regulatory framework and design principles of emissions control technology.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Chem Env Eng
data.description: A practical basis for applying microbial and physicochemical principles to understand reactions occurring in natural and engineered systems including water/wastewater treatment processes. Prerequisites: CHM 1045 and CHM 1045L

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Wastewater Trtmt Eng
data.description: Collection and transportation of wastewater, design of sanitary and storm sewers. Physical, chemical, and biological principles of wastewater treatment.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Reactor Design
data.description: A theoretical and practical basis for reaction kinetics to understand multi-phase reactions, analysis and design of batch and continuous flow reactors. Prerequisites:  ENV 3001

data.subject: ENV
data.name: ENV Senior Design
data.description: Team design project involving applications of fundamental environmental engineering concepts to project design, specifications, contracts and implementation. Emphasis on written and oral communication.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Environmental Eng Seminar
data.description: Basic principles and applications of environmental engineering, including environmental science, solid and hazardous waste, water resources, water supply, wastewater, and air quality for environmental engineering students.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Air Quality Managemt
data.description: Technical and regulatory aspects of air quality management. Emissions inventories, ambient monitoring, and models used to evaluate the impact of pollutants on local, regional and global air quality.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Des Wstwater Trea
data.description: Wastewater collection systems. Integration of unit operations into the planning and design of treatment plants, including sludge handling and disposal. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Chem Env Eng
data.description: Basis for applying microbial and physicochemical principles to understand reactions occuring in natural and engineered systems including water/wastewater treatment processes. Includes laboratory project.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Reactor Design
data.description: A theoretical and practical basis for reaction kinetics to understand multiphase reactions, analysis and design of batch and continuous flow reactors. Projects on analysis of reactor design and operating data.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Water Quality Managm
data.description: Predicting and evaluating the effect of human activities on streams, lakes, estuaries, and ground waters; and the relation of human activities to water quality and protection of water resources. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Specific aspects of environmental technology and urban systems not available through formal course study. Open to academically qualified students only.

data.subject: ENV
data.name: Thesis
data.description: Research for Master's thesis.

data.subject: ENY
data.name: Entomology
data.description: Explorations of the morphology, physiology, behavior and metabolism of insects in the context of their evolutionary, environmental and economic significance.

data.subject: ENY
data.name: Entomology Lab
data.description: Explorations of the morphology, physiology, behavior and metabolism of insects in the context of their evolutionary, environmental and economic significance.

data.subject: ESC
data.name: Intro to Earth Science
data.description: Survey of Earth science including earth materials, surface and internal processes, earth history, oceanography and atmospheric science. Students cannot get credit for both this course and GLY 1010.

data.subject: ESC
data.name: Intro to Earth Science Lab
data.description: Survey of Earth science including earth materials, surface and internal processes, earth history, oceanography and atmospheric science. Students cannot get credit for both this course and GLY 1010L.

data.subject: ESE
data.name: Sec Sch Curr
data.description: Examination of programs, trends, and developments in curriculum and instruction in the secondary school. Consideration and evaluation of innovations.

data.subject: ESI
data.name: Eval Engr Data I
data.description: Analysis of industrial data and subsequent characterization of industrial processes. Prerequisites: MAC 2311 or MAC 2281, or instructor permission.

data.subject: ESI
data.name: Forecasting and Dmdn Mgt
data.description: Forecasting overview. Times series methods. Regression methods. Advanced forecasting models. Demand planning. Pricing and revenue optimization with capacity constraints. Case studies. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ESI
data.name: Appl Of Or In Mfg
data.description: Overview of OR techniques. Manufacturing system and product selection. Shop loading, resource allocation, production scheduling, job sequencing, and plant layout problems. System performance evaluation. Prerequisite: ESI 3314.

data.subject: ESI
data.name: Adv Eng Proj Mgmt
data.description: This course covers entire phases of project management including selection, planning, budgeting, scheduling, monitoring, and control. It focuses on the management of engineering projects through case studies and independent research assignment. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: West Civ: Early Eur
data.description: Examines key developments of Early European Civilizations, from the earliest history through the classical period.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: West Civ: Med/Mod
data.description: Examines key developments of European Civilizations, from the medieval through the early modern periods.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Ancient Rome
data.description: The formation of the Roman republic, its rise to domination in the Mediterranean, its transformation into the Roman Empire, and its final disintegration. The political history, culture, values, social dynamics, and enduring force of the Roman civilization.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Saints/Relics/Miracl
data.description: Synthetic view of medieval Europe through the lens of saints veneration. Topics include saints as patrons, miracles and magic, pilgrimage, bureaucratic canonization, gender and mysticism.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Nazism & Holocaust
data.description: The history of the Third Reich and the Holocaust. The development of the German State and the emancipation of the Jews; the rise of racial antisemitism; Hitler and the emergence of Nazism as a political force; the 'Final Solution' and European and American responses.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Renaissance Reformation
data.description:
Covers the religious, political, cultural, and social history of Europe from 1300-1650,
focusing on the Renaissance and Reformation movements, including Protestant and Catholic Reformations.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Viking Society
data.description: The political, cultural, economic, and religious development of Viking society, 600-1300 C.E.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Topic-European His
data.description: An examination of selected topics or themes in early modern and modern European history. The themes will vary from semester to semester. With a change in content, the course may be repeated. (The theme will be announced in the yearly schedule).

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Modern Germany
data.description: A survey of German history from the unification movement through WWII. Topics discussed include Hitler's relation to the German past, liberalism, modernization.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Victorian Britain
data.description: Examines key cultural, political, and social developments in nineteenth-century Britian and its empire while introducing students to landmark scholarship on gender, class, and race in the Victorian era.

data.subject: EUH
data.name: Rdgs In Eur Hist
data.description: Students read books from different historiographical traditions and with conflicting interpretations about an important subject in European history. Subjects will vary according to professor. Course may be repeated with departmental approval. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Intro Environmental Scien
data.description: This course emphasizes scientific knowledge in global context about the environment including nutrient cycling, pollution, desertification, climate change, energy, water resources, biodiversity loss.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Intro Environment Sci Lab
data.description: Laboratory analysis and field trips on topics and concepts covered in Introduction to Environmental Sciences.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Climate Ch Glob Env & Soc
data.description: A broad introduction to impacts of climate change on social/economic processes and global environment with historical perspectives.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Energy Flow
data.description: A course examining energy use and efficiency, nuclear and renewable energy sources, and their environmental impacts.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Evr Sci-Pollution
data.description: An environmental science course for science majors focusing on human impacts on the environment, especially water and nutrient cycling, resource use and pollution.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Ecology Of S. Fla
data.description: A course for non-science majors, offering an introduction to the ecology of South Florida through lectures and a series of field trips into several unique ecosystems, such as the Everglades, hardwood hammocks, and coastal regions. The course also deals with natural resource conservation, wildlife management, endangered species, and wilderness issues.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Ecol S Fla Lab
data.description: A course for non-science majors, offering an introduction to the ecology of South Florida through lectures and a series of field trips into several unique ecosystems, such as the Everglades, hardwood hammocks, and coastal regions. The course also deals with natural resource conservation, wildlife management, endangered species, and wilderness issues.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Nat Res Valuation Econ
data.description: The market and non-market valuation of natural resources and how their values are used for different resource allocation decisions. Also covers economic bases of natural resource policies.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Climate Change Policy
data.description: Introduction to policies governing climate change mitigation. Examines the impetus for, specific mechanisms used to implement, and effectiveness of both national and international policies.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Sustainable Agricul
data.description: Analysis of sustainability of modern agricultural systems under a variety of ecological economic and cultural settings. Familiarizes students with socioeconomic, urban policy, sustainable agriculture.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Restoration Ecol
data.description: Principles and practices of environmental restoration, recreation and enhancement. Examines ecological theory that relates to restoration through case studies from southern Florida.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Restoration Ecology Lab
data.description: This lab is to illustrate concepts and applications of ecological restoration theories through visitations to and participations in various ecological restoration sites in South Florida.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: U.S. Env Policy
data.description: Introduction to U.S. environmental policy. Reviews primary U.S. environmental legislation and the role of regulation.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Coastal Marine Enviro Pol
data.description: Examine policies that govern the utilization and protection of coastal and marine areas. Focus on the political, social, environmental and economic constraints that shape the policy process.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: GLOBAL WATER ENVIRON
data.description: This course explores the status, trends of use, management and conservation of global water resources.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Pop & Environment
data.description: A study of co-evolutionary relationships between humans and their environment and subsequent impacts on human populations across time.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Soils & Ecosystems
data.description: A review of basic soil science concepts; analyses of basic physical and chemical properties of soils, emphasizing soils in South Florida ecosystems.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Soils & Ecosyst Lab
data.description: Laboratory exercises provide soil characterization techniques used in soil science and complement the lectures by carrying out experiments illustrating soil science cincepts, soil formation, soil properties, and soil nutrients cycling.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: So Fla Ecosystems
data.description: In-depth study, using case study approach of the major ecosystems of South Florida, the environmental issues facing them, and the management strategies employed to sustain their natural resources. Prerequisites: BSC1011, BSC1011, or permission of instructor.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Undergrad Intern Env Stud
data.description: Direct experience working in areas of environment or sustainability in government, industry, non-profit or research with approval of Faculty supervisor. May be repeated for credit. (Graded Pass/Fail) Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Water in Env and Dev
data.description: Examines the theory and practice of integrated water resources management, focusing on science, policy, and socioeconomic themes evaluated through case studies from different regions of the world. Emphasis given to environmental elements.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Adv Restoration Ecology
data.description: Restoration planning, endangered species reintroduction, disturbed land reclamation, ecosystem restoration, challenges of climate change on ecological restoration. Prerequisite: One course or more in ecology.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: A graduate-level course dealing with selected environmental topics. The content will not necessarily be the same each time the course is offered.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Nat Res Conserv and Policy
data.description: Interdisciplinary course focusing on diverse conservation issues and policy aspects of managing and conserving natural resources.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Supervised research toward completion of the student's program of study. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of Major Professor.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Master's Thesis
data.description: Completion of Master's Thesis. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of Major Professor.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: GIS in Water Resc
data.description: Spatial analysis of watersheds and modeling of hydrological processes with emphasis on surface runoff, evapotranspiration and sub surface flow.

data.subject: EVR
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Research directed towards completion of the doctoral dissertation. To be taken every semester by the candidates if the Ph.D.

data.subject: EVT
data.name: Intr Voc Spec Needs
data.description: Knowledge of historical developments, legislation, instructional strategies, and program alternatives required to instruct special needs students in vocationally related environments.

data.subject: EXP
data.name: Motivation & Emotion
data.description: Introduces several perspectives from learning theory, perception, and personality theory to explore ways in which people move through their physical and social environment.

data.subject: EXP
data.name: Memory&Mem Improvmt
data.description: This introduction to human memory considers the topics from a number of points of view. The following issues are addressed: the nature of memory and its phenomena; the capabilities and limitations of an ordinary and an extraordinary memory; and the skills that can aid an ordinary memory.

data.subject: EXP
data.name: Sensation & Percep
data.description: Basic concepts in sensation and perception are explored, with an emphasis on models of peripheral and central neural processing. Topics such as receptor function, brightness and color vision, movement and object perception, perceptual memory and pattern recognition are considered. Psychophysical techniques, such as subjective magnitude estimation and signal detection theory, are covered. (Lab fees assessed) Prerequisites: PSB 3002 or PSB 3007.

data.subject: EXP
data.name: Cognitive Processes
data.description: This course will explore areas of human 'mental' behavior. These may include: aspects of memory, metacognition, perception, attention, imagery, problem solving, decision-making, and language.

data.subject: EXP
data.name: Cog Neuroscience
data.description: Investigation of the relation between mind and brain. Discuss literature from both patient studies and from the growing research in neuroimaging. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Intro Portfolio Dev
data.description: To provide students with a comprehensive overview of academic policies, procedures, and requirements for submitting a Prior Learning Assessment portfolio. Course is repeatable. Prerequisite: Instructor Approval

data.subject: FES
data.name: Disaster Response
data.description: An understanding of the characteristics, functions, and resources of an integrated disaster response system are covering in conjunction with the rules of various emergency management services.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Envt. Disaster Mgt.
data.description: This course will provide you with the knowledge & skills needed to plan for, respond to & recover from natural or man-made disasters.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Prior Learning Assessment
data.description: PLA is college-level learning demonstrating knowledge, skills, & competencies obtained as a result of prior learning experiences through certifications, licensures, veteran status, workplace skills. Prerequisite: Instructor Approval and FES 1950

data.subject: FES
data.name: Disaster Mngmt. Capstone
data.description: N/A

data.subject: FES
data.name: Disaster Prepare Plan Meth
data.description: Provides a fundamental understanding about the importance of preparedness and planning, reasons for planning and identifies the people and organizations that may be involved in the planning process.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Humanitarian Assis/Coord
data.description: Focused on the role and responsibilities of the organizations engaged in humanitarian assistance.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Disaster Health Readiness
data.description: This course examines the efforts to provide humanitarian assistance from the perspective of the humanitarian agency and professional health worker in the field.

data.subject: FES
data.name: Crisis Communications
data.description: This course introduces students to the principles and practical tools of crisis communications during emergencies.

data.subject: FIL
data.name: Film Appreciation
data.description: For the beginning student of filmmaking. Survey of the origins and development of cinematography as an art form. Presentation and technical analysis of selected films.

data.subject: FIL
data.name: Intro Film Studies
data.description: The first required course for the Film Studies Certificate Program. Introduces students to cinema as an institution as well as its role as textual narrative. Provides students with an understanding of the ways films can be analyzed and understood.

data.subject: FIL
data.name: Holocaust Cinema
data.description: An interdisciplinary survey of cinematic representations of the Holocaust from the 1940s to the present, addressing ethical challenges such as Holocaust comedy and the representation of atrocity.

data.subject: FIL
data.name: Intern Film Studies
data.description: Students enrolled in the Film Studies Certificate Program work at the FIU Film Society and related film activities on archival research as well as working on organizing various aspects of the FIU Miami Film Festival including the concurrent seminars.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Intro to Business Finance
data.description: An introductory course offering a survey of financial markets and institutions, managerial finance, investments, and personal financial issues. For non-business majors only. Prerequisite: a) Business Minors or b) Biological Sciences (Bioentrepreneur Track) Majors or c) Mathematics (Business Track) Majors.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Per Fin Mgt
data.description: An introductory course to help individuals achieve their personal financial goals. Topics include personal budgeting, taxes, credit, major expenses, insurance, investments, and retirement planning.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Financial Management
data.description: A study of financial decision making in the corporate form of enterprise. An analysis of the sources and uses of funds. Emphasis is placed on working capital management; capital budgeting techniques; short and long term financing; and capital structure and the value of the firm. Prerequisites:  ACG3301, QMB 3003 or ((STA2023 or STA2122) and (MAC2233 or (any Calculus I or higher course)) or equivalents with a grade of 'C' or higher, minimum 45 credits earned, Business Students Only

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Intermed Fin Mgmt
data.description: Advanced theories and applications underlying financial decision making. Topics may include valuation of assets and liabilities, advanced time value, mortgage math, commercial loans, capital budgeting, cost of capital, capital structure, dividend policy, restructuring, mergers and acquisition, bankruptcy, cash management, and agency theory.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: SMIF Fixed Income
data.description: Course will involve practical applications of finance skills to the management of a portfolio of real money and analysis of actual equities for purchase by the FIU Student Managed Investment Fund. Prerequisites: A grade of 'C' or higher in FIN 3503, Business Students only

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Financial Mkts & Ins
data.description: Financial markets and the role of financial intermediaries in these markets. Emphasis will be upon the objectives and policies of financial intermediaries within the constraints of law and regulatory authorities.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Commercial Bank Mgt
data.description: The management of bank assets and liabilities; specialized banking functions; and the role of the commercial bank in financing business.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Credit Anal & Ln Eva
data.description: Topics to include: introduction to commercial lending; secured lending; accounts receivable financing and factoring; inventory financing; introduction to lending vehicles; short term lending; domestic taxation; consolidations; forecasting and intermediate term cash flow lending; term loan agreements/covenants; subordinations and guarantees; foreign exchange; international transactions and leasing.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Fin Rsk Mgmt-Fineng
data.description: A survey of financial instruments used for financial risk management, including forwards, futures, options and swaps. Emphasis is on identification of financial risks and designing optimal risk management program.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Securities Analysis
data.description: The examination of the determinants of the values of common and preferred stocks, bonds, and warrants. The timing of security purchases and sales and an introduction to portfolio construction techniques.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Intl Fin Mgmt
data.description: Capital budgeting operational analysis and financial decisions in the multinational context. Working capital management and intra firm fund transfers. Measurement and evaluation of the risk of internationally diversified assets.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Intl Banking
data.description: Objective of course is to provide student with an understanding of nature of international banking and the major cultural, economic, social, and legal environments in which international banking operates.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Lat Am Fin Mkt & Ins
data.description: This course examines the Latin American financial climate and especially financial markets and institutions. Topics include evolution of the money and capital markets, regulation, banking innovations, the role of foreign banking, integration and globalization of banking.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Global Priv Banking
data.description: This course seeks to provide the students with an understanding of the nature of the global private banking, its role in preserving, augmenting and protecting wealth and how it is shaped by a sometimes-controversial need for confidentiality.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Financial Crime
data.description: The course provides a solid understanding of the crimes committed in financial markets. The origin and development of financial crimes will be covered. The foundation of the course will be based upon a study of the following: identity theft, mortgage fraud, money laundering, foreign exchange crimes, check cashing and wire transfer companies, capital flight issues, tax evasion, import duty fraud, insurance fraud, underground economy, insider trading, terrorist financing, Hawala banking, international trade-based money laundering, and illegal offshore center activity. Also the role of all domestic and international regulatory/enforcement agencies in detecting and preventing financial crimes will be discussed.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Int'L Corp Finance
data.description: The study of topics of research interest to international financial decisions. Topics include foreign exchange risk, international financial markets, and foreign exchange market efficiency.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Sem Fin Mkts & Inst
data.description: Examines recent developments in economic and financial theories as applied to topics such as the structure of financial markets and the economics of information and financial institutions. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Found Of Fin Models
data.description: Introduction to mathematical and economic models underlying the development of modern finance theory. Includes discrete and continuous time models in finance using stochastic calculus. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: FIN
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Original research that is supervised by a faculty committee and defended openly before the university committee.  Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: FLE
data.name: Meth Fl Elem Sch
data.description: Development of instructional skills, techniques and strategies for teaching modern languages in the elementary school.

data.subject: FLE
data.name: Dir Stud For Lang
data.description: The student plans and carries out an independent study project under direction. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

data.subject: FLE
data.name: Sem Sec Lang Testing
data.description: Advanced study and research on current topics and issues in the field of second language education. Variety of topics to include language testing. Language proficiency, language and society, bilingual-bicultural education, and error analysis and the language learner.

data.subject: FOL
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Project, field experience, readings, or apprenticeship.

data.subject: FOL
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Readings and discussion of literary/linguistic topics to be determined by students and teacher.

data.subject: FOL
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Project, field experience, readings, or research.

data.subject: FOS
data.name: Food Science
data.description: Physical and chemical changes in food occurring as a result of various methods of processing, preparation, and storage.

data.subject: FOS
data.name: Food Science Lab
data.description: Experimental laboratory in the physical and chemical characteristics of food.

data.subject: FOW
data.name: Spec Topics Lan/Lit
data.description: Content and objectives to be determined by students and teacher.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: French I
data.description: Course designed specifically for beginning university students with no previous language study. Emphasis on oral French and on acquiring basic language skills.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: French II
data.description: Emphasis on oral French and on acquiring basic language skills.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: Intermediate French
data.description: Provides intermediate training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills. Prerequisites: One year prior study at college level or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: Interm Fr Convers
data.description: Development of oral skills through skits, debates, and hypothetical situations. Open to non-native speakers. Prerequisites: One year prior study at college level or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: Rev Gram/Writing I
data.description: Practice in contemporary usage through selected readings in culture and civilization. Development of writing and speaking ability in extemporaneous contexts. The course will be conducted exclusively in the target language.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: French Phonetics
data.description: An introductory course in French linguistics. Includes the International Phonetic Alphabet and a systematic inventory of all the sounds of French, with refinement exercises in the language laboratory.

data.subject: FRE
data.name: Francophone Cinema
data.description: Introduces to Francophone cinema. While comparing movies from France and Francophone world, students explore various issues such as language, race, and postcolonial politics.

data.subject: FRW
data.name: Francophone Lit and Culture
data.description: This survey course examines the main literary movements and texts of the French and Francophone world from the Middle Ages to the present, while preparing students to take advanced literature courses.

data.subject: FRW
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Project, field experience, readings, or apprenticeship.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Intl Bak, Conf & Des
data.description: Provides a professional understanding and foundation of management for food production in a pastry department or industrial baking facility within the foodservice industry.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Intro Comm Food Serv
data.description: Study of basic and intermediate commercial food production management skills required in menu design. This knowledge will be applied in the production of appetizers, salads, main course items, and desserts.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Instl Fd Serv Prod
data.description: Theory and application of commercial and institutional foodservice in an industrial environment, including large scale purchasing procedure, training in large production equipment, on-the-job training.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Internatnl Cuisine
data.description: An opportunity for food aficionados to explore modern interpretations of international classic cuisine. Includes lecture, demonstration and preparation of favorite international dishes from restaurant menus around the world. Open to non-majors.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Purchasing/Menu Plan
data.description: Basic information on sources, grades and standards, criteria for selection, purchasing, and storage for the major foods, including the development of specifications. Consideration of the menu pattern with particular emphasis on costing, pricing, and the work load placed on the production staff. Item analysis and merchandising features are emphasized.

data.subject: FSS
data.name: Adv Food Prod
data.description: A course in advanced food production and service techniques to provide the student with realistic production, service and managerial experience. Students will be rotated through production and service stations and, as managers, will be required to plan menus, supervise preparation and service, handle customer relations, and keep accurate accounting records on the profit and loss phases of the operation. Staffing, merchandising, and cost control procedures are integral parts of the course.

data.subject: GEA
data.name: Wrld Regional Geogra
data.description: A systematic survey of the major regions and countries of the world, with regard to their physical, cultural, and political characteristics. Emphasis upon climate, natural resources, economic development, and population patterns.

data.subject: GEA
data.name: People Envir Lat Am
data.description: Introduction to the physical, cultural, and political geography of Latin America. Emphasis on population patterns and problems of population growth, systems of land use and tenure, economic development, natural resources, and agriculture.

data.subject: GEA
data.name: People Envir of Eur
data.description: Introduction to the physical, cultural, and political geography of Europe emphasizing the evolution of the states and the geographical factors facilitating the integration movement.

data.subject: GEA
data.name: People Envir Mdl East
data.description: Introduction to the physical, cultural, and political geography of the Middle East. Emphasis on population patterns, natural resources, and economic development.

data.subject: GEB
data.name: Intro To Business
data.description: Looks at the business arena by examining the role/function of business, types of businesses, managerial functions, marketing principles, financial management, technology, ethics and global influences.

data.subject: GEB
data.name: Career Management
data.description: Systematic approach to career development by identifying and evaluating their interests, skills, and values. Students will develop career management skills. Prerequisites: Minimum of 45 credit hours earned, and Business students only

data.subject: GEB
data.name: Writing the Business Plan
data.description: Students (a) write 2 business plans for a new business - one to raise equity and the other to obtain debt, (b) analyze successful plans, and (c) obtain understanding of investor perspectives and demands.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Intro To Geography
data.description: Leading concepts of human and environmental geography. Physical, cultural, economic and political factors in the spatial patterns of natural and human systems.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Geograph Global Change
data.description: Explores uneven geographies of development & urbanization, colonial era to present day. Emphasizes interconnected & contested nature of social, environmental, political, economic, & cultural change.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Earth Resources
data.description: Geological occurrence, extraction and uses of mineral and energy resources, and associated global environmental, economic, social and political problems through time.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Global Food System
data.description: Analyzes the spatial organization of the global food system and its importance to world economic development.  Explores food security, trade, and environment.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Marine Geography
data.description: Examination of the human and physical components of marine geography, including marine processes, coastal development, and the issues of managing marine resources.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Crit Geopolitics
data.description: Explains to students new methods of critical geopolitical analysis and how they impact human political affairs across landscapes and territories.  Allows students to develop analytical work and research in the field.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Directed independent research in systematic geography. Requires prior approval by instructor.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Adv Political Ecology
data.description: People are often engaged in conflict over nature and the landscapes where they would live, work, and recreate. Seminar illuminates roles of geography, history, and power in these conflicts. Prerequisite: Graduate status.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Directed Ind Studies
data.description: Supervised readings and/or field research and training.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Crit Geopolitics
data.description: Examines the school of thought that emerged in the 1980s challenging hegemonic ways of representing the world. Topics include feminist geopolitics, war on terror, critical geopolitics in Latin America. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Doctoral Exam Preparation
data.description: Preparation for the preliminary doctoral exam under the direction of a faculty member. Hours may vary. Prerequisite: Permission of major professor.

data.subject: GEO
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Completion of doctoral dissertation. Hours may vary. Prerequisites: Permission of major professor and doctoral candidacy.

data.subject: GER
data.name: German II
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: GER
data.name: German Oral Comm Skills
data.description: Designed to develop different types of oral communication in German: storytelling, debates, inquiries, complaints etc.

data.subject: GER
data.name: German Lang Through Film
data.description: Designed to strengthen students' linguistic skills in German and to introduce them to modern German culture through film. Prerequisite: any GER 2000 level course.

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Cartogr, Mapng in Geograp
data.description: Introduction to the history of cartography and map production.  Descriptions of map errors, maps as science and as art. Also more technical map creation with aerial photography and satellite images.

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Introduction To Gis
data.description: Introduction to GIS concepts and specialized software. Topics include: cartographic basics, spatial datasets, attributes, map production, spatial statistics and analysis, and obtaining GIS data.

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Applications Of Gis
data.description: Introduction to geographic spatial analysis using a variety of data.

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Geospatial measurements
data.description: Students will be introduced to state-of-the-art field geospatial measurement techniques that will prepare them to conduct advanced research in their senior year and graduate school.

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Advanced Spatial Analysis
data.description: An advanced course in the analysis and modeling of geospatial data. Topics include: point, line and raster pattern analysis, geostatistical surface estimation, map algebra, and suitability modeling. Prerequisites: GIS 2040 or CGN 3043 or GIS 3048 or CGN 4321 or other introductory course in GIS

data.subject: GIS
data.name: Adv. Geospatial Measure.
data.description: Students will learn state-of-the-art field measurement techniques used in Earth and Environmental Sciences that will prepare them to conduct advanced graduate research.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Physical Geology
data.description: Survey of Geology including Earth materials and structure, internal processes, surface processes, groundwater and climate change. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and ESC 1000.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Physical Geology Lab
data.description: Survey of Geology including Earth materials and structure, internal processes, surface processes, groundwater and climate change. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and ESC 1000L.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: The History Of Life
data.description: Interaction of biological and geological principles and processes, history and ecology of past life, and major events such as the marine invasion of land, mass extinctions, and the Ice Age.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: History Of Life Lab
data.description: Interaction of biological and geological principles and processes, history and ecology of past life, and major events such as the marine invasion of land, mass extinctions, and the Ice Age.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Environ Geology
data.description: The composition and structure of the earth, the internal and external forces acting upon it and the resulting surface features. Case studies and general principles illustrated from South Florida and the Caribbean. Field trips expected. No prerequisites.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Envrnmtl Geol Lab
data.description: The composition and structure of the earth, the internal and external forces acting upon it and the resulting surface features. Case studies and general principles illustrated from South Florida and the Caribbean. Field trips expected. No prerequisites.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Earth thru Time
data.description: Evolution of the Earth through its 4600 million year history, the fossil record and the geologic time scale. Major geologic events of the past and their effects on organic evolution.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Remote Sens Earth
data.description: Remote sensing methods for the exploration and investigation of geologic processes and earth resources; airphoto interpretation, processing and analysis of multi-band digital satellite imagery; GIS.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Geology Excursion
data.description: A one to three-week field excursion in a region of interest to demonstrate the occurrence, appearance and processes of various geological phenomena. Course may be repeated.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Petrology
data.description: Origin, composition and classification of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. Observational, theoretical, and experimental studies of rocks.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Petrology Lab
data.description: Identification of rocks using macroscopic and microscopic techniques. Application of electron microprobe.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Intro Hydrogeology
data.description: Principles of groundwater flow, determination of aquifer properties, geologic factors influencing groundwater flow and quality, legal/regulatory framework for hydrogeology.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Internship in Geoscience
data.description: Practical geological, geophysical, or hydrological work experience at local companies, non-profits, or government agencies supervised by a faculty member. May be repeated for credit. (Pass/Fail Only) Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Ap Remote Sensing
data.description: Application of remote sensing and image analysis in the earth sciences; qualitative and quantitative satellite image and air photo interpretation. Emphasis is on use of computer processing packages. Prerequisites: GLY 1010 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Gis Analys Earth Sci
data.description: Application of GIS technology to spatial problems in the Earth Sciences. Topics include: spatial statistics, sampling theory, surface estimation, map algebra, and suitability modeling.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Adv Field Excursion
data.description: A study of the geology of a selected region of the world followed by 10-12 day field trip in order to study the field relationships of the geologic features. Special emphasis is given to stratigraphic, structural and tectonic relationships of lithic package. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Hydrogeology
data.description: Physics of flow in geological media. Saturated and unsaturated flow, groundwater and the hydrologic cycle, estimating hydraulic parameters of aquifers, introduction to chemical transport.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Chem Hydrogeology
data.description: Quantitative analysis of hydrologic, geologic, and chemical factors controlling water quality and the transport and fate of organic and inorganic solutes in the subsurface. Prerequisite: GLY 5827.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Research apprenticeship under the direction of a professor or a thesis advisor. Prerequisites: Full graduate admission and permission of the instructor.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Thesis
data.description: Field and/or laboratory research project toward thesis. Selected in consultation with major professor. Prerequisite: Permission of the major professor.

data.subject: GLY
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Field and/or laboratory research directed towards completion of the doctoral dissertation. Selected in consultation with major professor. Prerequisite: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Molecular Microbiology
data.description: This course introduces the general principles of infectious diseases and the host response to infection. Prerequisites: Currently enrolled in the HWCOM Ph.D. program and permission of the course director.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Physiology and Immunology
data.description: This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts of physiology and immunology from a biomedical perspective that will assist in evaluating pathology and therapeutic target options. Prerequisites: Currently enrolled in the HWCOM Ph.D. program and permission of the course director.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Biostatistics
data.description: This course provides an introduction to the elements and foundations of epidemiology and biostatistics. Prerequisites: Currently enrolled in the HWCOM Ph.D. program and permission of the course director.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Prof Skl Med Scie II
