data.description: Provide students with a small structured learning environment in which to analyze the relationships between concepts and develop the ability to evaluate and integrate information. Prerequisite: Enrollment in the HWCOM Graduate Certificate Program in Molecular and Biomedical Sciences.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Graduate Seminar
data.description: A weekly seminar/discussion course consisting of research presentations by students, faculty, and visiting scientists in the area of biomedical sciences will form part of a recurring credit. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Supervised Teaching
data.description: Students will assist the faculty members who teach either graduate or medical students. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Laboratory Rotation
data.description: Laboratory rotations in specific laboratories of the HWCOM graduate program faculty that will eventually lead to the choice of a thesis laboratory. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Qualifying Examination
data.description: The purpose of the Qualifying Examination is to confirm the readiness of the graduate student to conduct Ph.D. research. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment. Corequisites: Completion of all mandatory courses.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Preliminary Proposal
data.description: The student submits preliminary research proposal approved by his/her committee. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Research Credits
data.description: Research conducted in the Ph.D. advisor's laboratory. May be repeated. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Dissertation Research
data.description: Research towards the completion of a doctoral dissertation. May be repeated. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment. Corequisites: Completion of GMS 6961, GMS 6964 and permission of the major professor.

data.subject: GMS
data.name: Dissertation Defense
data.description: Dissertation defense seminar. Prerequisite: HWCOM Graduate School Enrollment. Corequisites: Permission of major professor and graduate committee.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Typography
data.description: Aims to familiarize students with the typographic terms, classical and contemporary fonts and technologies. Students will create typographic compositions and systems while learning to appreciate typography.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Graphic Design I
data.description: Foundation skills for the graphic design discipline. Students build their vocabularies in visual communication, working with basic design elements and principles.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Illustration
data.description: Aims to provide students with the skills to illustrate using a variety of mediums from traditional to digital illustrations. It is an introduction to visual storytelling.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Graphic Design II
data.description: Intermediate level concepts for the graphic design discipline. Students articulate their vocabularies in visual communication, working with complex design concepts.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Thesis I/Portfolio
data.description: This course provides the skills to create your printed and web-mobile design portfolio as collateral pieces to send to prospect employers.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Graphic Design III
data.description: This course offers advanced concepts for the graphic design discipline. Students master their vocabularies in visual communication, working in complex design concepts.

data.subject: GRA
data.name: Internship
data.description: Students will complete an internship aimed at experiential learning in the context of an art or design related profession.

data.subject: HAI
data.name: Haitian Creole I
data.description: Course designed for students with no previous training in Haitian Creole. Emphasis on oral Haitian Creole and on acquiring basic language skills.

data.subject: HAI
data.name: Creole Transl/lnterpret
data.description: Continues the translated text analysis initiated in the Introduction to Haitian Creole Translation course and provides students with interpretation techniques for oral production. Prerequisite: HAI 3204 or Professor's permission

data.subject: HAI
data.name: Haitian Read/Comp II
data.description:
Reinforces writing and grammar skills acquired in HAI 2320 and develops
a more critical thinking ability for all types of literary and scientific texts. Prerequisite: HAI 2320 or Instructor's permission.

data.subject: HAI
data.name: Haiti: Cult/Lang
data.description: Provides, from a multidisciplinary perspective, a general understanding of the Haitian culture and language.

data.subject: HBR
data.name: Biblical Hebrew II
data.description: A continuation of Biblical Hebrew I.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Intro to Hosp and Tour
data.description: A survey course providing an overview of the industry, its history, problems, and general operating procedures in the fields of hotel, foodservice, travel, and tourism.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Global Bev Intro
data.description: This introductory course refines the student's knowledge of beverages served throughout the world, focusing fundamental knowledge of wine, beer, spirits, production, flavor characteristics, & society. Prerequisite: Minimum age 18.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Pathway I
data.description: Designed to provide students with a comprehensive overview of academic policies, procedures, and requirements for matriculation and graduation from the Chaplin School of Hospitality and Tourism Management.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Fnd & Path Glbl Sust Tour
data.description:
Seminar course for first-term GST students provides important foundations of sustainable tourism and tourism industry. Course helps students create individual paths through the program to maximize opportunities for personal growth and
professional success

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Human Resources for Hosp
data.description: An overview of human resources management in hospitality industry designed to improve and advance student's skills through understanding of both hourly and management human resource policies.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Accounting for Hosp
data.description: Introduction to the principles of accounting as they apply to the hospitality industry.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hospitality Info Tech
data.description: This course covers current computer applications in the hospitality industry including information technology specific to hotel and restaurant accounting, finance, marketing, and management.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Sustainability Team Mgmt
data.description: This beginner level course teaches students how to understand, create,communicate and manage a green team in an organization and create a playbook for sustainability victories.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: PATHWAY II
data.description: This course exposes students to all career services offered by CSHTM. Students will review career/education goals in line with strengths, skills and values, and will leverage all career services.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Personal Empower in Hosp Ind
data.description: Student will increase their interpersonal skills in a business setting by applying a set of tested techniques that will increase their professional success. They will develop personal strengths.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Dining Services Mgmt
data.description: Analysis of principal operating challenges facing managers in the many ways dining services are delivered to guests. Various control systems necessary for profitability and quality are examined.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hsptly Prop Mgmt
data.description: The problems of cost and operation of pest control, security, parking, general cleaning and upkeep, laundry, fire prevention, pools, tennis courts, and care of guest rooms and public space, with emphasis on equipment, personnel, and modern innovations. The housekeeping and property management function of the hotel.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Entertainment Tour Mgt.
data.description: planning a tour, budgeting, marketing/publicity/branding, concert brokers, ticketing agencies, and revenue streams

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Operations Control
data.description: Focuses on controlling expenses and revenues of a full-service lodging operation using qualitative and quantitative techniques. Based on using the uniform system of accounts for the lodging industry.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hosptly Mktg Mgmt
data.description: Examines marketing principles, theories and concepts and the use of management principles and techniques of analysis, planning, implementation and control to maximize marketing effectiveness in hospitality organizations.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hospitality Law
data.description: Introductory course in hotel/restaurant law with an emphasis on risk management and security. The student is introduced to the laws, rules and regulations applicable to the hospitality industry worldwide.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Sus Tourism Pract
data.description: Sustainability in the global tourism industry is examined through certifying organizations, destinations, international stakeholders. Global impacts and indicators are discussed.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Gbl Trav & Tour Dev
data.description: This course examines tourism as a global industry. Through the analysis of different forms of tourism, both positive and negative, students will understand the interrelatedness of the tourism industry.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Internl:Travl+Touris
data.description: Study of the global tourism industry, organizations, tourist behavior, history and globalization. Economic, socio-cultural and environmental impacts on destinations and culture are examined.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Planning Meetings
data.description: Introduction to the meeting and convention industry, concentrating on specific and practical research, planning, supervision and control guidelines used by today's Professional Meeting Planner.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Conv & Trd Shw Mgmt
data.description: A course concentrating on organizing, arranging and operating conventions, trade shows, and expositions. Emphasis is placed on the modes and methods of sales used in booking conventions and trade shows, as well as the division of administrative responsibility in their operation.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Intro to Events Mgt.
data.description: An introduction to the conceptual management and operational activities of special events.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Cruise Oper & Mgt
data.description: Overview of cruise industry: its history and evolutions, operating and marketing procedures, career opportunities, ship profiles, itineraries, and ports of call. Guest speakers and optional field trip included.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Social Event Planning
data.description: Designed to focus the basic concepts of event planning as they specifically apply to the area of social events and weddings, including infrastructure design and budget management.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Bev Mkt & Distribution
data.description: Identify and analyze the key segments for targeting and positioning of alcoholic products for the beverage industry. Emphasis on suppliers, retailers, duty free segment, and on-premise accounts.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Spirits Fundamentals
data.description: A comprehensive study of the beverage industry; history of alcohol, prohibition and its impact on the hospitality industry, the development of the beverage industry in the United States. Prerequisite: Minimum Age 18.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Brewing Science
data.description: A hands-on overview of the scientific principles and operation of craft breweries, and microbrewery technology. Relevant chemical, biological, and physical processes will be examined. Prerequisite: Minimum age 21.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Northern Hemis. Wines
data.description: Explore the wine regions of the northern hemisphere. Including: Europe Classic Regions and North America. Tasting techniques and evaluation methods. Prerequisite: Minimum age 18.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Wine Sensory & Perception
data.description: This course is intended to increase the fundamental knowledge of wine, basic production methods, tasting techniques, and flavor characteristics. Prerequisite: Minimum age 18.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Wine & Vineyard Ops
data.description: The science of wine production and vineyard operations. The biological and chemical aspects of wine-making, wine quality and logistics. Understanding vineyard management and basic agriculture. Prerequisite: Minimum age 18.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Intro Food and Wine Pairing
data.description: An introductory study of how wines pair with foods. Small portions of simple foods will be paired with an assortment of red and white, dry to sweet wines. Prerequisite: Must be 21 years or older.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Global Food and Culture
data.description: Study of the ways in which global issues influence the how food functions in the global community.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Intensive Pod in Hosp. In.
data.description: This course will provide intensive instruction on a particular topic or skill not otherwise offered in the curriculum. This course is repeatable.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Intern Hsptly Mgmt
data.description: Practical training and experience in all the major phases of hospitality operations and visitor industry. Reports are required. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Mng Service Org
data.description: In-depth study of management issues relating to service and quality assurance in the service industry. Examines service linkages to marketing operations and human resources.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Sr. Sem. Hosp. Mgmt.
data.description: Student groups identify and research a major problem of a hospitality enterprise. Discussions will focus on problems and solutions. Final report required.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hosp Facil Environ System
data.description: A comprehensive survey of engineering, maintenance, and efficiency controls in hotels, restaurants. Emphasizes the importance of Operations Facilities Engineering Management and the environment.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hosp Analytics & Rev Mgt
data.description: Detailed study of methods used in serving and tracking guest history and yield management in the hospitality industry. Demonstrates state-of-the-art technology and concepts.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Fin Anal Hosp Indust
data.description: Facilitates understanding and use of financial analysis in the hospitality industry. Topics include decision-making based on ratio analaysis, leverage, financing sources and other financial issues.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Mgmt Acct Hosp Ind
data.description: Advanced study of the decision-making process involved in the hospitality industry. Emphasis on budgeting, pricing decisions, cost-volume-profit analysis and capital budgeting.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Hosp/Tour Internet
data.description: This course provides working knowledge of the structure of the internet and web site hosting. Current principles of on-line marketing are examined in detail. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Group Business Sales/Svs
data.description: Examines the practices of selling and servicing space by hotels, convention centers, arenas/halls to convention and events producers. Includes how to reach, sell and service these important groups and people.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Tour Dest Mkt
data.description: Comprehensive study of strategies and advanced techniques used in marketing tourism destinations and products. Marketing plan developed.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Mngg High-Funct Teams
data.description: Course covers factors contributing to effective teams. Students will experience and process activities to help group members build skills for teamwork. This is an experimental course requiring a high level of participation.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Advanced Events Mgt
data.description: This course focuses on advanced planning and managing of special events, from ideas and concepts through the actual event implementation and follow-up. Students will have the opportunity to focus on detailed elements of event management.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Catering Mgmt
data.description: A study of the techniques, logistics, and responsibilities involved in the management of on-premise and off-premise, catering companies.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Culinary Innov and Entrepren
data.description: A unique course allowing the opportunity for students with advanced culinary skills to learn the art and science of managing culinary innovation and entrepreneurship.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Foodservice Trends
data.description: Advanced level course covers management issues relevant to current trends and challenges facing the foodservice industry.  Topics covered will vary as appropriate for current situations.

data.subject: HFT
data.name: Adv Intern Hsptly
data.description: The Advanced Internship is a practical hospitality/tourism work experience structured to provide exposure to management and training functions, job rotation tasks and/or projects not previously performed. Minimum 300 hours/ten weeks field experience. Prerequisites: Documented completion of 1,000 hospitality related work hours of which 500 hours must be completed while enrolled at FIU. Permission of an advisor.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Jun Sem: Approaches Hist
data.description: Covers methods, theories, and practices used by historians. Topics vary. Required for majors before enrolling in HIS 4935.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: History Through Things
data.description: Explores material culture, art, and design in the modern era. Topics studied include consumerism, modernity, and daily life with emphasis on museum collections.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Biography as History
data.description: Biography as an approach to history. Life stories as ways of examining different national or regional histories within a particular historical context. May be repeated with a change in content.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Independent Studies
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings and reports on independent investigations, with the consent of the instructor.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Senior Seminar
data.description: A seminar to be taken by all history majors, to provide experience in research, writing, and critical analysis.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: History Internship
data.description: Gain hands-on experience in archives, libraries, museums, or public history projects. Prepare for a number of careers or fields of study. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Permission of the department required.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Pub Hist Theory Practice
data.description: Theory and methods of history in non-academic settings, with practical interactions with professional and institutions such as museums, monuments, archives, parks, and government. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. May be repeated with approval of Graduate Program Director.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: History Memory Public
data.description: Critical examination of theories and texts on museums, monuments, archives, historical sites, community organizations, and/or oral histories. Specific topical focus to be determined by instructor. Prerequisite: Graduate standing, may be repeated with approval of Graduate Program Director.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Comparative History
data.description: A study of specific topics in history that cut across regional, national, and chronological lines. The topics will change from semester to semester, and with a change in content, the course may be repeated. (The topic of the course will be announced in the yearly schedule). Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Independent Studies
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings and reports on independent investigations, with the consent of the instructor. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Historical Methods
data.description: A seminar designed to introduce the beginning graduate student to the technical aspects of the study of history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: Public Hist Intern
data.description: Offers hands-on experience in public history and museum studies to students in public history option.

data.subject: HIS
data.name: PH.D. Dissertation
data.description: Completion of Doctoral Dissertation. Prerequisite: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: HLP
data.name: Teach Elem Hlth/Pe
data.description: Provide content and methods needed to understand and teach health and physical education to elementary students of diverse backgrounds.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Train Team Bldg
data.description: Students will learn leadership skills to facilitate team building activities in order to improve group communication, trust, problem-solving, and productivity.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: With permission from the Associate Dean, students may engage in independent research projects and other approved phases of independent study. Prerequisite: Permission.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Intensive Pod in Hsp. In.
data.description: This course will provide intensive instruction on a particular topic or skill not otherwise offered in the curriculum. This course is repeatable.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Mega Event Mgt
data.description: Leadership in large scale event production requires coordinating and supervising a plethora of trained and untrained personnel. Structure, methodology and planning are examined.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Manag Self/Others
data.description: Students will increase managerial effectiveness by learning and applying a model for enhancing self-esteem and integrating that model into their managerial philosophy for the hospitality industry.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Org Behavior Hosp & Tour
data.description: Study of human behavior in organizational settings, the interface between human behavior & organizations; reflecting several levels of analysis & a wide variety of interactions.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Industry Resrch Analysis
data.description: Explore emerging domestic & global issues using content analysis & other methodologies to identify & analyze relevant industry problems facing management in the hospitality & tourism industry.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Global Issues Hosp & Tour
data.description: This course synthesizes theories & concepts of globalization, multinational strategy & international business studies by providing students an opportunity to develop analytical & interpretive skills.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Strat Mgmt Hosp/Tour
data.description: Adv. course focusing on thinking strategically & anticipating the future in global economy defined by uncertainly requiring knowledge in strategic resource assessment, decision-making & allocation.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Asset Management
data.description: This course will present an overview of the role of hospitality industry asset managers as well as an in-depth study of the techniques and practices employed by them in their representation of ownership.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Hosp & Tech Tech Innov
data.description: Advanced course examining Information Technology and how it's utilized to gain competitive advantage - focusing on general concepts of e-commerce, F&B innovations, lodging and GDS, and analytics.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Hosp/Tour Rev Mgt
data.description: Explores the scope & application of revenue management in service companies within the Hospitality & Tourism industry.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Feas Study Hosp Indu
data.description: In-depth study of the tools and techniques available for evaluating financial feasibility of a hospitality investment. Feasibility study required.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Acct & Fin Mgt
data.description: Specialized accounting & finance tools for analysis as related to the hospitality & tourism industry. Application of budgeting & pricing models, risk/return trade off & capital investment analysis.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Restaurant Develop.
data.description: A study of the procedures to research and develop a restaurant from concept to opening. Emphasis will be on market research, site development, financial feasibility, and the formulation of an operating plan for an individual restaurant. Prerequisite: Must completed 27 graduate credit hours.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Strategic Revenue Mgt
data.description: This course provides a brief review of fundamental microeconomics, and an illustration for determining a customer's willingness to pay. Prerequisite: HMG 6466

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Investment Anal Hosp
data.description: Advanced investment methods and opportunities with emphasis on securities of the hospitality industry, financing techniques, syndication, negotiations.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Event Mkt and Sponsor
data.description: Examines both marketing trends and sponsorship development. In experiential marketing, event design and promotion must reflect the most current developments in marketing, including social media.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Research & Stat Mthd
data.description: A study of basic research and statistical methodology applied to a variety of hospitality industry research projects. Techniques for data collection, interpretation and methods of reporting are the focus.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Mkt & Sales Hosp & Tour
data.description: An examination of the role of marketing strategy and management within the overall strategic planning process of hospitality/tourism organizations.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Hsptly Law Seminar
data.description: New laws and their impact on the hospitality industry are examined. Students research current legal issues and problems and explore the impact of new legislation on the hospitality industry.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Prod, Mgmt & Merch Craft Beers
data.description: Technical and practical aspects of craft brewing and microbrewery technology. Relevant chemical, biological and physical processes will be examined. Aspects of the management of micro-breweries and brewpubs. Prerequisites: Must also take accompanying Lab. Minimum age 21.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: World Wine & Food
data.description: An intensive study of wines from around the world and how they pair with foods. Guest chefs will prepare tapa size portions of food to be paired with local and specific wines. Prerequisite: 21 years old.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Comp Wines Bev Mgrs
data.description: Designed for beverage management students to learn some basic language and scientific concepts emloyed in wine making. The chemical structures, as well as the aromas and tastes of various specific components in wines will be investigated. These components will include those derived from the grape, the process of fermentation and storage, and will include common wine flaws.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Graduate Internship
data.description: Structured hospitality practical training work experience involving training program and job rotations not previously performed. Ten week/300 hour minimum. Report and management project required. Prerequisites: Documented completion of 1000 hospitality related work hours of which at least 500 hours must be completed while enrolled at FIU. Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: HMG
data.name: Hosp and Tour Thesis
data.description: Design and preparation of an original research investigation in the hospitality and tourism discipline. Prerequisites: STA 5206, STA 6166, and STA 6167 and permission of the instructor.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Intro to Hlth Serv Sys
data.description: Students examine the history and current functions of health and social services delivery systems in the United States. Focus is on the components, their interaction and internal/external controls.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Ldrshp and Mgt Hlth Pro
data.description: This course introduces students to an overview of the basic of leadership and management with an emphasis on the roles, functions and skills necessary in the changing health care environment. Prerequisites: ECO 2023, ACG 2021, ACG 3301, CGS 2060, STA 2023 or STA 3145 or department consent.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Cultural Competency in HSC
data.description: Focus on selected systems of beliefs and values of cultural groups to develop cultural competence to minimize barriers in healthcare.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hlthcr Org Beh and Res Mgt
data.description: Analysis of organizational behavior and resource management and the implications for leadership and management of healthcare systems.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Glbl Issues and Trnds Hlthcr
data.description: Developing issues and trends involving global healthcare systems are analyzed to determine their impact on service, delivery, financing, quality measures, evidence-based practice, and accessibility.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Prg Plan Eval
data.description: Basic concepts of planning and evaluation as the fundamental tools of program design and development are examined.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Glbl Hlthcr Sys Policy
data.description: Develop basic knowledge of Global healthcare systems and policies including healthcare outcomes, evidence based practices, sociopolitical systems and roles of various healthcare providers.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hlthcr Fincl Mgt
data.description: This course is an introduction to economics and financial management in diverse healthcare organizations.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Tech In Health
data.description: This online course assists the student in developing information and communication skills using the Internet.  It demonstrates the use of technology in clinical practice, research and education.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hlthcare Qual Mgmt
data.description: Development and evaluation of healthcare quality management techniques including work systems, job analysis, space utilization, inventory control, and operations management.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Legal Aspects of Hlthcr
data.description: Corporate structure and legal liabilities of health care institutions and professionals is studied from a local, state, and federal regulatory position.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Values/Ethics & Conf
data.description: Explores individual and organizational values, related values, related theories, ethical systems and their influence on behavior of individuals in government agencies, law enforcement and health care professions.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Qlty Evdn Bsd Hlthcr Srvcs
data.description: This course incorporates basic research methods, processes and models in analyzing research studies and incorporating current quality standards and evidence-based protocols into healthcare.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: BHSA Admin Internship
data.description: Students who have completed all Health Services Administration program required course work are provided an opportunity to observe and engage in administrative internship in a health care setting.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Intro to Hlth Policy Mgt
data.description: The American health care system is broadly analyzed in social, economic, and political terms, including examination of its major operational and programmatic components as they have evolved in their changing patterns and trends of organizational development.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Mgt Of Ltc Systems
data.description: Organizational, financial, and policy issues in the management of long term care systems.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Eth Dec Hlth Admin
data.description: This course will study ethical principles as they apply to areas of management, supervision and clinical practice in the delivery of health care. Emphasis is on managerial decision-making. Prerequisites: HSA 5125, HSA 6185.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Str Pln & Mkt Hs
data.description: Principles, techniques, and case study applications of strategic planning and marketing in the context of changing environmental, policy, and competitive forces in the health services industry. Prerequisite: Completion of 36 credit hours in program coursework.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Fin Mgt Hlth Sys
data.description: Aspects of modern hospital and health care organization financial management are covered to prepare students for executive roles in policy planning and control responsibilities involving budgeting, auditing, investing, capital financing, etc. Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Fin Reimb Hlth Sys
data.description: In this course financing models for health delivery systems are examined. Reimbursement strategy of Medicare, Medicaid and other third party payers are analyzed.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Mgmt Org Theory HC
data.description: Fundamentals of management and organizational theory with focus on roles and functions of managers, and the influences of organizational structure and design in the dynamic environment of health care systems.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Ldshp Org Beh HC
data.description: Examine leadership and organizational behavior in health care settings.  Personal and profession growth are encouraged through integrative study of individual, group and organizations issues. Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Mgt HR Hlth Prof
data.description: Study of human resource functions and activities necessary to enhance knowledge, competencies, skills, attitudes and behavior and to improve individual and organizational performance in health care organizations. Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hlth Info Systems
data.description: The development and management of health information systems to support managerial decision-making. Emphasis is on the integration of clinical, personnel, and financial data.  Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hosp & Hlth Fac Org
data.description: Administrative theory and management principles are examined in their application to the organizational analysis of hospitals and health care facilities. Prerequisites: HSA 5125, HSA 6185 or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Hlth Law Legal Asp
data.description: The broad range of legal issues in health care and administrative aspects of law that concern health care managers are surveyed for implications concerning malpractice, patient rights, contracts, liability and immunity, taxation, surgical consent, etc. Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Adv Hlth Mgt Res Sem
data.description: Integrates the theoretical and practical knowledge of other courses in the curriculum. Case studies and relevant research provide the substantive framework for analysis of health care issues. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Qual Asses
data.description: The concept of quality and quantity assessment are examined from multiple perspectives: patients, healthcare providers, payors standard setting organization and healthcare policymakers. Prerequisites: Completion of Foundation Courses or minimum of 9 credit hours of program coursework including HSA 5125, HSA 6185, PHC 6065, HSA 6176.

data.subject: HSA
data.name: Pro Seminar Hlth Mgt
data.description: A professional seminar to provide career development skills in preparation for residency or master's project. Prerequisite: Completed 36 credit hours in the program coursework.

data.subject: HSC
data.name: Healthy Lifestyles
data.description: A survey of wellness issues including preventive health care, substance abuse prevention, stress management, sexually transmitted diseases, psychological illness, nutrition and exercise.

data.subject: HSC
data.name: Medical Terminology
data.description: Provides the student with basic medical language skills including, pronunciation, spelling, and definitions as a foundation for developing the degree of competency required to read and understand medical reports and communicate with physicians and other medical professionals.

data.subject: HSC
data.name: Clin Phys Hlth Prof
data.description: An integrated, systems-based approach to the study of human physiology with relevant clinical correlations and case studies.

data.subject: HSC
data.name: Comm Theory H Pro
data.description: Theory and practice of effective communication for health care professionals.  Emphasis on communication between healthcare provider-client; provider-provider; provider-family.

data.subject: HSC
data.name: Fundamentals Of Path
data.description: Study of human diseases/disorders of the immune, cardiovascular, hematopoietic, central nervous, musculoskeletal, respiratory, urinary/reproductive, gastrointestinal and endocrine systems.

data.subject: HUM
data.name: Intro to Humanities
data.description: An interdisciplinary survey of how human beings have perceived themselves and the world around them, through literature, philosophy, religion, music and the arts.

data.subject: HUM
data.name: History Of Ideas
data.description: The historical development of fundamental concepts through an interdisciplinary cultural approach. Nature, freedom, beauty, virtue, alienation, and relativism are traced in literature, art, and philosophy including the social context of developing ideas. Meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Fnd Nutr Sci
data.description: An integrated functional survey of nutrition science as it relates to human physiology, physiological chemistry, food chemistry and biotechnology.  Intended for the non-science major.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Fnd Nutr Sci Lab
data.description: To apply the scientific method to nutrition science as it relates to human physiology, physiological chemistry, food chemistry and biotechnology.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Principls Nutrition
data.description: Nutrients and their interrelationships, requirements of individuals, and food sources. Investigates current controversies, fads/fallacies, and health related issues.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Applied Nutrition
data.description: Study of the scientific principles of nutrition and impact of culture on nutrition and health. Recommended for Junior-Senior non-majors.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: World Nutrition
data.description: Strategies for improving cross-cultural competence in conducting needs assessments, program planning, and implementation in nutrition services.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Nutrition & Biochem
data.description: Study of the relationship of nutrition and biochemistry with emphasis on digestion, absorption, metabolism of nutrients, and determination of norms.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Advanced Nutrition
data.description: Roles of nutrients in metabolic processes. Effects of excesses and deficiencies.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Life Cycle Nutrition
data.description: Nutrient requirements, dietary adequacy, food habits, special nutritional concerns during pregnancy, infancy, childhood, adolescence, and adulthood including aging.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Nutr PA Special Pop
data.description: Study of nutrition and physical activity, nutrition and special populations, especially pediatrics and older adults.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Nutrigenomics
data.description: Nutrigenomics is an emerging discipline that studies both the impact of nutrition on gene expression and the relationship between diet, genetics and disease.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Ethnic Food Habits
data.description: Systematic study of food habits of various cultural groups. Emphasis on methodology, analysis of data, relationship of food habits to nutritional standards, and corrective measures. Includes laboratory. Prerequisite: Competency in food preparation and nutrition. Recommended for non-majors.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Nutrition Assess
data.description: In-depth study of the methodology and application of nutritional assessment. Prerequisites: Advanced Nutrition, physiology, and biochemistry. Prerequisite: HUN 4241 or equivalent, DIE 3244 and lab or equivalent, and DIE 4246 and lab or equivalent.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Func Of Vitamins
data.description: Integration of chemical, biological and physiological functions of vitamins as related to human nutrition. Prerequisites: Advanced Nutrition, Biochemistry, Physiology.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Mineral In Hum Nutr
data.description: The physiological and metabolic functions of selected macro and trace minerals as they relate to nutritional status in humans. Prerequisites: Advanced Nutrition, Biochemistry, Physiology.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Adv Pediatric Nutrition
data.description: This course is designed to apply the principles of physiology, biochemistry and nutrition to Medical Nutrition Therapy for medically compromised infants, children and adolescents. Prerequisite: HUN 6415.

data.subject: HUN
data.name: Nutr Sci Comm Hlth
data.description: Critical examination and synthesis of current human nutrition science topics with emphasis on implications to human health, nutrition, public health policy, and research.  Prerequisites: Nutritional Biochemistry and Pathophysiology.

data.subject: IDC
data.name: CS for Everyone
data.description: Introduction to the breadth and excitement of computing, including its social context, computing principles, and relevance to all disciplines.

data.subject: IDC
data.name: Intro to Cryptocurrencies
data.description: High-level conceptual survey of crypto-currencies and other blockchain technologies for non-CS undergraduates, including techniques, applications, ethics and philosophical issues. Prerequisite: MAC-XXXX or MAD-XXXX or MGF-XXXX (any math course at any level)

data.subject: IDC
data.name: Capstone-DS
data.description: Projects course using Python, SQL, R, and/or other specialized analysis toolkits to synthesize concepts from data analytics and visualization as applied to industry-relevant projects.Prerequisite: CAP 5768

data.subject: IDH
data.name: Honors Seminar II
data.description: The course is designed to encourage students to become self-conscious learners, exploring not only the what, but also the how and why of knowing. The course focuses on the nature of truth and reality and our role in the world each of us has constructed.

data.subject: IDH
data.name: Honors Seminar IV
data.description: A continuation of Seminar III, this course is an interdisciplinary examination of other cultures and multicultural societies. Includes directed individual research projects.

data.subject: IDH
data.name: Honors Seminar VI
data.description: A continuation of Honors Seminar V, this course examines the interplay of various sources of authority in society and our system of values and aesthetics. Includes directed individual research projects.

data.subject: IDH
data.name: Honors Seminar Vii
data.description: The first of a two semester sequence, this course is an interdisciplinary examination of expectations for the 21st Century.

data.subject: IDH
data.name: Honors Independ Stud
data.description: Directed independent study from an interdisciplinary perspective.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: First Yr Sem Sustain
data.description: Seminar course meant for freshmen or 1st year transfer students in the undergraduate Sustainability and Environment program. Topics include: designing plan of study, career development, getting help.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Hlth w/o Bdrs
data.description: This is an undergraduate course to orient students; regardless of their major field of studies, with a global perspective of the interrelatedness of factors affecting health that transcends borders.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Science and Global Life
data.description: This course explores how scientific advances change the lives of communities globally and teach non-science majors basic concepts in energy and electronics that they use in their daily lives.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Science and Global Life Lab
data.description: This course explores how scientific advances change the live of communities globally and teach non-science majors basic concepts in energy and electronics that they use in their daily lives.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: How We Know What We Know
data.description: Merges the skills of global information literacy with the critical perspective to ascertain and measure the authenticity and credibility of information in academic and casual research and writing. Meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Gaining Global Perspectives
data.description: Students learn to socially locate themselves vis-Ã -vis others and how their perspectives affect perceiving and understanding others. Students acquire and apply new perspectives to see as others do.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Diversity of Meaning
data.description: This course will explore the areas of language, gender and culture as they influence affect diverse ways of knowing and meaning and making in real and virtual global networks.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Artistic Expression
data.description: Exploration of the interrelatedness of societies and culture through language, music and art are explored to appreciate how individuals convey thoughts and respond to events from various perspectives.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: VIP Program - B
data.description: Students work in large projects with students from different majors working in real-world projects with university and external mentors. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Sustainability in Action
data.description: Application of sustainability concepts and principles to environmental problems solving in community, business of research settings, emphasizing project management and communication skills.

data.subject: IDS
data.name: IDS Capstone
data.description: Preparation for course-of-study and guided academic/career self-assessment; senior year internship, service learning, or research project. Students complete a portfolio demonstrating applied expertise

data.subject: IDS
data.name: Internship in LS/IDS
data.description:
This variable credit course (0-6 credits) can be used to allow both Liberal Studies and
Interdisciplinary Studies' students to take an internship and use that experience towards their degree.

data.subject: IHS
data.name: FIU BHWET
data.description: Inter-professional and integrated care training of behavioral health clinicians to competently serve the underserved, uninsured, economically disadvantaged and those with chronic health conditions. Prerequisite: Acceptance in BHWET Fellowship Corequisite: For Field Practicum II semester: SOW 6533, SOW 6425 For Field Practicum III semester: SOW 6534 and SOW 6351

data.subject: IND
data.name: INT Design 4
data.description: Investigations in how structure, materiality, and human factors affect the vertical and horizontal composition of space within the interior architecture of small infill urban building projects.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Color Theory and App
data.description: Use of color in the built environment including principal color systems, methods of color harmony, effects of visual phenomena, and various psychological, cultural and historical implications.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Grad Lighting
data.description: Exploration of theories and applications of lighting design. Emphasis on studying research about interactions between light, people and articulation of interior space.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Prof Practice
data.description: Advanced study office administration, contract negotiation, fee structure, professional ethics, client and public relations. Investigations and analysis of business organizations and project management.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Personal Brand
data.description: Learn brand strategy, storytelling, media consistency, brand maintenance, interviews, and personal marketing packages. Covers values of responsibility, accountability and effectiveness.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Sustain Pract I Arch
data.description: Analysis and application of theoretical, practical, and professional issues involved in designing sustainable interior environments.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Structures 1
data.description: Through the study of statics and strength of materials this introductory course provides a scientific basis for analysis of how various structural systems work and withstand loading. Prerequisites: PHY 2053 and MAC 2233 or MAC 1114 or MAC 1147.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Structures 1 Lab
data.description: The lab sessions will supplement lectures through additional practice and hands-on problems that are designed to enhance the application of structural concepts. Prerequisites: PHY 2053 and MAC 2233 or MAC 1114 or MAC 1147. Corequisite: IND 5645.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Examination of the conceptual framework supporting the theory, and research applications in specialized area of interior design. Prerequisite: Program approval.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Design Thinking
data.description: Using literature on design methods, design cognition, cognitive psychology and design protocol studies, students will learn about the various models of creative process in design.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Grad Internship
data.description: Advanced issues in professional practice learned through work experience with design professionals.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Marine vessel design
data.description: N/A

data.subject: IND
data.name: Exhibition Design
data.description: N/A

data.subject: IND
data.name: IND Grad 2
data.description: Advanced design topics explored. Focus on student specialization interest. Emphasis on integration of design process from conceptual formulation and programming to design development and reflection.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Grad 4
data.description: Focus on developing a global approach to designing with awareness and respect for cultural and social differences, and the implications of conducting the practice of design within a world market.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Coursework on a particular aspect of architecture under the direction of faculty in an individual study format. Prerequisite: Program approval.

data.subject: IND
data.name: Masters Project
data.description: The curriculum was reordered and the Master's project is now the terminal studio for all students.

data.subject: INP
data.name: Intro. Ind/Org Psy
data.description: Study of psychological principles and theories applied to the workplace. Focus on job analysis, employee selection, performance evaluation, motivation, training, and organizational stress.

data.subject: INP
data.name: Personnel Psychology
data.description: Techniques and procedures applicable to the selection, placement, utilization, and evaluation of personnel in organizations are considered. The emphasis will be on empirical procedures, rather than the management function in the personnel area. Topics such as quantitative methods and models for selection, criteria analysis, performance appraisal, management training, and job satisfaction are discussed. Prior course in statistics strongly recommended.

data.subject: INP
data.name: Employee Selection
data.description: Study of valid selection tools used in employee selection. Topics cover designing employment interviews, conducting background checks, utility of and applicant reactions to different selection tools.

data.subject: INP
data.name: Organization Psych
data.description: Focuses on the 'organizational' topics associated with the field of industrial/organizational psychology. Includes, leadership, team effectiveness, work and family issues.

data.subject: INP
data.name: Applied Psychology
data.description: An overview of the organizational consulting process, including proposal development, managing projects and client relationships, ensuring information integrity, and understanding ethical issues.

data.subject: INP
data.name: App Psy Training
data.description: In-depth study of principles of behavior and attitude change in organizations. Topics include organization analysis, program design and implementation, and evaluation of results.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intro To Intl Rels
data.description: Introduction to the interactions among international actors: states, international organizations, and transnational groups. Concepts such as power and national interest will be introduced.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Diplomacy
data.description: Covers theory and practice of diplomacy, including negotiation, conflict resolution, ethics and human rights, and economic diplomacy.  Examines both diplomatic history and contemporary foreign policy problems.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Refugees & Migrants
data.description: Examines political and economic challenges stemming from the international movement of refugees and economic migrants. Emphasizes the role of state power, organizations and law in structuring responses.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Conflict Security
data.description: Introduces students to basic theoretical arguments and empirical cases on security, peace and strategic studies. Examines the evolution of conflict resolution and post-conflict reconstruction.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Contem Intl Probs
data.description: Examines selected world and regional issues and problems. Topics vary according to the instructor.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Amer Foreign Policy
data.description: An examination of the legal, administrative, and political structure by which American foreign policies are formulated and implemented. Includes a discussion of the objectives and consequences of United States foreign policy in selected regional, social-economic, and ideological areas. Enables the student to understand the procedures by which foreign policy is made and implemented in the United States.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Rels Of Europe
data.description: An examination of the international, social, economic, and political life of contemporary Europe. Emphasis given to international organizations and the trend toward economic and political integration.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Japan And Us
data.description: Examines the international relationship between two of the most powerful and economically significant states of this and the next century and the international problems they must face together.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Inr Of East Asia
data.description: Examines strategic and economic aspects of international relations among China, Japan, North Korea, and other nations of East Asia.

data.subject: INR
data.name: INR South Asia
data.description: Examines international relations of Indian subcontinent. Looks at basic patterns of international, political, economic, cultural, and ideological relations of the region.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Rel Lat America
data.description: An examination of international, social, economic, and political life of Latin America. Emphasis given to the role of international organizations; regionalism; and the trend toward economic integration.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Rel/Caribbean
data.description: An examination of the international social, economic, and political life of the Caribbean. Includes English, Spanish, and French speaking regions.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Rel No Africa
data.description: An examination of the social, political and economic structure of North Africa and the manner in which its historical development has conditioned international relations within and external to the region.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Rel Mid East
data.description: An examination of the international social, economic, and political life of the Middle East. The role of oil in the region will receive special attention.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Foreign Policy
data.description: Introduces and explores models of foreign policymaking, applied to international strategic, economic, and social problems.

data.subject: INR
data.name: International Law
data.description: Introduction to the legal concepts, framework, and institutions which play a role in international relations theory and practice.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Organizations
data.description: The study of international political, economic, and social organizations and their impact upon the relations between nations. Emphasis on the constitution, voting, membership, security and operation of such organizations, and the settling of international disputes through these bodies.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Inter Pol Econ
data.description: Explores the important concepts, theories, and contending approaches used in the study of international political economy.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Dev Inr Thought
data.description: The nature and characteristics of international relations from antiquity to the end of the First World War. Examination of the religio-philosophical, socio-economic and political ideas and systems associated with them. Study of select historical occurrences and patterns of social change and their interaction with the dynamics of international relations.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Int Prot Hum Right
data.description: Development of the concern of the international community with the rights of individuals and groups and the institutional mechanisms which have been set up for their protection.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Islam In Int'L Rels
data.description: Analysis of the role of Islam in shaping the dynamics of contemporary international relations. Emphasis on ideological, cultural and political role, Islamic movements and states and relations with the West.

data.subject: INR
data.name: INR Scandinavia & Arctic
data.description: Study of the foreign affairs of the Nordic countries (Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark) and relevance of the Arctic. Focus on transnational issues, the role of EU, Nordic and Arctic Councils.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intrntnl Reltn China
data.description: An examination of the development of China's international relations in the 20th century. Special attention to the development of institutional mechanisms for diplomacy and to problems of integrating domestic and foreign policies.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Strat Stds/Natl Sec
data.description: The role of force in international relations is examined. The use and control of force in theory and practice is analyzed. Special attention is paid to contemporary national security issues.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intl Humanit Law
data.description: Provides students with conceptual, legal, and critical understanding of major issues of International Humanitarian Law.  Allows students to develop analytical work and research in this field.

data.subject: INR
data.name: International Law of Sea
data.description: Introduction to the legal and political foundations of the law of the sea. Emphasis on rule of law of the sea treaties, efforts to conserve marine environment, and the resolution of maritime disputes.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Theories Intn'L Rel
data.description: Analysis and conceptualization of the forces and conditions which influence relations among nations. Emphasis is on the provision of an analytical basis for the study of international relations.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Political Economy China
data.description: An introduction to the key issues in contemporary Chinese political economy and its development in a globalized society.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Directed independent research. Requires prior approval by instructor.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Model United Nations
data.description: Students participate in a UN simulation. Attention is given to the workings of the UN, negotiating skills, and critical international issues. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Topics In Intr Rel
data.description: Varies according to the instructor.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Intern Inr Affairs
data.description: Opportunity to gain practical experience in international affairs by working at a consulate, governmental agency, non-governmental organization, private voluntary organization or institute.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Sem Int Politics
data.description: An advanced graduate course designed to give students a specialized knowledge of the classics in international politics. The course traces the development of international politics from Thucydides to the present.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Approaches Area Studies
data.description: Provides students the necessary tools to approach global issues from the comparative perspective of how they play out in different regions of the world.

data.subject: INR
data.name: African Development
data.description: Examines political, economic and social development in Sub-Saharan Africa in an international context. Introduces students to sources for research in African international development. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Int'L Organizat I
data.description: Study of international organizations and their role in international relations. Emphasis on their legal status, rule-making capacities and role in dispute settlement and maintenance of peace.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Directed independent research. Requires prior approval by instructor.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Russian For Policy
data.description: Close analysis of the theoretical foundation and policy evolution of the Soviet/Russian role in international affairs of the 20th century.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Contemporary IR Theory
data.description: Surveys contemporary theories of International Relations, including neorealism, theories of cooperation among states, approaches to international political economy, and critical theories.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Sem Inter-Amer Pol
data.description: Focus  on U.S.-Latin American relations. Attempts to link the theoretical literature on U.S. foreign policy with empirical developments.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Comps Prep
data.description: Students prepare for comprehensive examination under the direction of a faculty member.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Thesis
data.description: Registration for students working on their thesis. Prerequisite: All other course work for the Master's in International Studies.

data.subject: INR
data.name: Pre-Diss Research
data.description: Students develop a dissertation proposal under the direction of a faculty member.

data.subject: INR
data.name: PH. D. Dissertation
data.description: Supervised research on an original research project to be submitted in partial fulfillment of doctoral degree requirements. Prerequisites: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: First Year Sem Earth Env
data.description: Weekly seminar course meant for freshmen or 1st year transfer students in the undergraduate Earth and Environment programs. Topics include: assessing your skills, planning your program, and getting help.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: Senior Sem Earth & Enviro
data.description: Capstone course for graduating seniors in Earth and Environmental science. Includes discussion career pathways and completion of a research project with written and oral presentations. Prerequisite: Senior standing and permission of department.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: Research Internship E&E
data.description: Directed research internship under the supervision of a professor in the student's field of interest. Subject may deal with laboratory work, field work, and/or bibliographical work. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: Earth/Env Grad Seminar
data.description: Weekly seminar emphasizing research- and practice-oriented guest speaker series. Critical examination of current research topics by students, faculty, visiting speakers. Brief student reports. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: Earth/Env Adv Grad Sem
data.description: Weekly seminar emphasizing research- and practice-oriented guest speakers. Critical examination of current research topics by students, faculty, visiting speakers. Student research presentations. Prerequisite: ISC 5151.

data.subject: ISC
data.name: Envrionments Changing
data.description: Interactions of physical, chemical and biological components and processes that have led to recent past and present environmental development, and possible future changes.

data.subject: ISE
data.name: Intl Student Exch
data.description: N/A

data.subject: ISE
data.name: Study Abroad IHE
data.description: N/A

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Info System Mgt
data.description: Course introduces business students to the benefits, deployment, management, and use of information within organizations, particularly business analytics and large stores of data. Prerequisites: (a) ACG3301 and (b) MAC1105 or equivalents with a grade of 'C' or higher, (c) 45 credits earned, (d) business students only.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Intro to Info Systems
data.description: Overview of organizational computer information systems use, to include databases, decision support systems, production planning and control systems, and so on. Not available to business majors. Prerequisite: Business Minors only.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Bus Process Analysis
data.description: Introduction to principles and methods of business process management. Emphasis on role of process models to understand and analyze operations and to drive design of Information Technology solutions. Prerequisite:  (a) 45 credit hours earned and (b) Business Students or Project Management Minors only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Business App Development
data.description: Design, implement, test, debug, and document business applications using a business programming language. Compelling exercises illustrate how applications implement business processes.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Info Systems Internship I
data.description: A program enabling MIS majors to work in jobs significantly related to their major area and career goals. Placement must be approved by instructor.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Systems Analy & Des
data.description: Topics include: information systems concepts; the structure, design, and development of the data base; and techniques and procedures used in the analysis and design of systems projects. Prerequisites:(a) 45 credit hours earned; and (b) Business Students or Project Management Minors only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Manage Digital Srvc Innov
data.description: Investigates advanced practices for managing the IS function. Exposes students to the development of a business case and prototype of a new information technology innovation. Prerequisites: CGS3300 or ISM3011 or ACG4401 or equivalent with a grade of 'C' or higher; 90 credits earned. Corequisites: ISM3230, ISM4113, ISM4210, ISM4220, ISM 4314, ISM4323, and (ISM 3153 or ISM4400) with a grade of 'C' or higher.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Database Applications
data.description: Application of the database technology and concepts to organization problems. Includes database management system (DBMS components; hierarchic, network and relational approaches to DBMS design. Prerequisites: 45 credit hours earned; Business students only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Data Sys Phy Desn
data.description: Essential concepts of database design and management in modern business environments. Students gain hands-on experience and exposure to modern databases and their use cases e.g. Big Data. Prerequisites: (a) 45 credit hours earned and b) QMB3200 'C' or higher c)Business Students only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Business Telecomm Systems
data.description: Application of telecommunication technology and concepts to organizational networks. Includes client-server architecture, distributed computing, network management, and data communication fundamentals.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Project Management
data.description: Covers fundamental knowledge areas related to successful Project Management, to include selection and initiation, work breakdown structure and scope management, scheduling, and cost analysis.Prerequisites: ACG2021 or ACG3024, and Business Students or Project Management Minors

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Info Systems Security
data.description: Provides knowledge and skills to protect enterprise assets by mitigating IS/IT related security risks. Exposure to IS/IT security regulations and compliance, security policies, and incident response.Prerequisites:  45 credit hours earned; Business students only. Corequisite: ISM4220

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Managerial Info Analysis
data.description: Focuses on use of information processing and decision support techniques to provide knowledge workers and decision makers with information to assist in making informed and rational decisions. Prerequisite: 45 credit hours earned; and (b) Business students only or Business analytics Minors only.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Bus Intel Reporting
data.description: A broad overview of managerial, strategic and technical issues associated with BI and reporting techniques. Gather, analyze, understand information processed from business data.Prerequisites:  45 credit hours earned; Business students or Business Analytics Minors only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Business Analytics
data.description: Explores data analysis and statistical methods as well as best practices for continuous iterative investigation of past business performance to gain insights and drive business planning. Prerequisites: (A) 60 credits earned; and (b) QMB3200 or ECO3410 or STA3033 or STA3112 or STA3123 or STA3145 with a grade of 'C' or higher; and (c) Business Students or Business Analytics Minors only

data.subject: ISM
data.name: AI for Business
data.description: This course covers the knowledge and skills required to develop and assess the opportunities and limitations of artificial intelligence business solutions. Prerequisite: CGS 3300 or ISM 3011 or ACG 4401 grade of C or higher b) ISM 3230 or ISM 4400, grade of C or higher Corequisite: ISM 4211, ISM 4420 and ISM 4402 grade of C or higher.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Blockchain for Business
data.description: This course covers the knowledge and skills required to develop and assess the opportunities and limitations of blockchain business solutions. Prerequisites: CGS 3300 or ISM 3011 or ACG 4401 grade of C or higher b) ISM 3230 or ISM 4400, grade of 'C' or higher Corequisite: ISM 3143 and ISM 4113 grade of C or higher.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Info Systems Internship II
data.description: A continuation of ISM 3949. A program enabling MIS majors to work in jobs significantly related to their major area and career goals. Placement must be approved by instructor.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Systems and Software Eng
data.description: Doctoral seminar examining research and theory on the acquisition, development, implementation of information systems.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Sem Research On Ict
data.description: This seminar will examine research on emerging information technologies, their application, and their implications for organizations and strategy.

data.subject: ISM
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Original research that is supervised by a faculty committee and defended openly before the university committee. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Fundamentals Ntl Security
data.description: An examination of the national security apparatus of the United States and the manner in which the US responds to key related controversies.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Spec Top Foreign Policy
data.description: Focuses on major contemporary foreign policy issues facing the United States and how the United States responds to them.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Issues in Global Policy
data.description: Examines the most pressing issues facing governments, businesses and society in the global arena. May be retaken for credit.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: F. Global Cyber Policy
data.description: Provides a foundational understanding of the technical and non-technical considerations influencing global cybersecurity policy.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: ISS Public Policy Intern
data.description: Supervised work experience with federal, state, local government, or in a public non-profit organization. Involves professional and technical job duties depending on the employer.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Effective Govt Communication
data.description: Improves communications for governmental professions, enhancing research and effective writing skills and developing briefing techniques.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Nat'l Security Essentials
data.description: An examination of the U.S. national security structure, current security-related controversies and potential U.S. responses to security threats.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Visual Methods
data.description: Interdisciplinary course explores use of visual methods in social sciences research, focusing on documentary film and PhotoVoice techniques.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Res Meth and Design
data.description: Logic and procedures in conceptualizing and conducting empirical social research. Emphasizes the relationship of research design and methods to theoretical perspectives. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: ISS
data.name: Proposal Writing
data.description: Development of skills in writing research proposals. Prerequisites: Graduate standing in the department and three semesters of completed graduate studies, or instructor's permission.

data.subject: ITA
data.name: Italian I
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: ITA
data.name: Italian II
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: ITA
data.name: Italian for Business
data.description: Designed for intermediate students of Italian who wish to further their linguistic knowledge in specific areas of business.

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Intro Reporting & Writing
data.description: Intro to news reporting/writing developing digital skills in journalistic setting. Instruction on sourcing, interviewing, data gathering/presentation, civic governance and public records search. Prerequisite: ENC 1101 and ENC 1102

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Intro To Journalism
data.description: Study and analytical discussion of the history of journalism in America, including its current practice, through intensive readings of primary historical sources as well as broad, direct exposure to current news sources.

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Digital Journalism
data.description: Teaches the fundamentals of news writing, reporting, interviewing, public records and arithmetic for journalists and the basic skills required for digital journalism.  Prerequisites: MMC 3003, MMC 3123, JOU 3003, and 2.85 cumulative GPA  Corequisite: JOU 3003

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Advanced Digital Journ
data.description:
Students will write and produce digital feature stories: human interest, trends,
personality profiles, sidebars, backgrounders, color. Prerequisites: MMC 3003, MMC 3123, JOU 3003, JOU 3117, RTV 3531, 2.85 cumulative GPA

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Int Journalism Newsroom
data.description: Students will conceptualize and produce a digital publication, including layout, photography, video, audio and data visualization. Prerequisites:  MMC 3003, RTV 3531, JOU 3117, (DIG 4293 or VIC 4001), JOU 3300, (JOU 4108 or VIC 4001), 2.85 cumulative GPA

data.subject: JOU
data.name: Investigative Journalism
data.description: The emphasis in this class is on the new media and the possibilities of combining basic news reporting and writing skills with new electronic resources and tools available to journalists.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Japanese I
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Japanese II
data.description: Provides training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Interm Japanese I
data.description: Provides intermediate training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills. Prerequisites: One year prior study at college level or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Interm Japanese II
data.description: To help students maintain and further improve their speaking, writing, listening, and reading skills in Japanese in more complex situations.  Students learn how to use useful expressions of experience and thought in advanced level of Japanese.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Adv Japanese Composition
data.description: A writing-intensive course for advanced students. Provides composition training through analysis of Japanese as used in newspapers and short stories.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Adv Japanese I
data.description: Continuation of Intermediate JPN II which provides the beginning level of advanced training in the acquisition and application and application of the language skills.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Jpn Culture/Society
data.description: This course will examine Japanese culture, societal life, class and gender, and the way of the Samurai. It will explore not only the traditional arts but also current social concerns.

data.subject: JPN
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Designed for advanced Japanese language proficiency utilizing specialized research projects, field experience, readings and other area studies.

data.subject: JRM
data.name: Contracts & Business Law
data.description: This course provides an overview of law within the business environment. It is designed to enable the student to develop an understanding of the terms and concepts that govern basic Contract/Business Law. Prerequisite: Juris Master students only

data.subject: JRM
data.name: Regulation Health Ins
data.description: This course will explore the obligations of large and small employers with respect to health insurance. The ACA includes a 'shared responsibility' provision, with potential penalties for employer noncompliance. The course covers employer liability under the ACA and the specific ways the Act will impact access, quality, costs, and tax implications.
