data.description: Limited to qualified students who have permission from a faculty member and who present a plan of study including area and objectives. Students enrolled in this course are expected to have regularly scheduled meetings with their faculty advisor, and to submit a written report of their experiences. May be repeated. (Pass/Fail Only) Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.

data.subject: PSY
data.name: Directed Ind Study
data.description: Under the supervision of an instructor in the graduate degree program, the graduate student delves individually into a topic of mutual interest which requires intensive and profound analysis and which is not available in a formal offering. May be repeated once. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: PSY
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Research apprenticeship under the direction of a research professor or a thesis advisor. Prerequisite: Full graduate admission.

data.subject: PSY
data.name: Qualitative Methods Psych
data.description: Critical issues, theoretical and practical applications for conducting qualitative research in psychology. The focus will be on key research strategies and principles for research design.

data.subject: PSY
data.name: CurrTopicsNeurosci
data.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to present current topics in Neuroscience either from recently published literature or their own research. Course may be repeated for up to six credits

data.subject: PSY
data.name: Spec Topics In Psy
data.description: Special topics will be announced in advance.

data.subject: PSY
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Supervised research on an original research project submitted in partial fulfillment of doctoral degree requirements. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: PRAAC Orientation
data.description: This is a zero credit required orientation for students in the Bachelor of Science in Public Relations, Advertising and Applied Communication (PRAAC)

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Principles Of P. R.
data.description: An introduction to the theory, history, practice, and future of public relations. A comprehensive study of the field.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Writing For PR
data.description: Introduction to the content, format and style of multiple public relations tools including newsletters, magazines, brochures and digital media. Emphasis on news releases, AP style and media relations. Prerequisite: MMC 3123 or COM 3714, ADV 3008 or PUR 3000, MMC 3003 or PUR 1951  (Supplies fee assessed)

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Digital Editing and Design
data.description: Understanding the visual theories behind the design, editing and production of materials for print, broadcast and multimedia. Special attention given to digital pre-production and software skills. Prerequisites: MMC 3123 or COM 3714, ADV 3008 or PUR 3000, VIC 3400, MMC 3003 or PUR 1951. (Supplies fee assessed)

data.subject: PUR
data.name: BOLD Agency
data.description: This course operates as a student-run agency that has the infrastructure to train students from SJMC and other majors to run a successful strategic communication agency.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Strat Comm Theory
data.description: Examines theories and processes of strategic communication and media responsibility to society and the social and ethical responsibility of communicators.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Media Skills
data.description: This advanced skills course covers a broad range of written, interpersonal, social media, presentation, and team communication skills for the advertising, marketing, and public relations professions.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Strategic Facilitation
data.description: This course focuses on the theories and techniques to conduct strategic facilitation. Students learn facilitation skills, and enhanced communication skills to successfully facilitate communication.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Social Media Metrics
data.description: This course introduces strategic aspects of social media analytics by highlighting metrics for assessing effectiveness of social media strategies.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Global Strategic Communic
data.description: This course acquaints students with the professions and practice of global advertising and public relations in a multicultural world. Prerequisite: PUR 6806.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Digital Media Mgmt.
data.description: This course examines various methods and perspectives of managing digital media platforms and content in a strategic communication setting.

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Advanced Comm Seminar
data.description: The class will consist of a series of readings, discussions and presentations to immerse students in contemporary issues in Advertising and Public Relations. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor. (Offered at least once a year).

data.subject: PUR
data.name: Prof. Project
data.description: Designed to demonstrate student's competence in the pillars of global strategic communications. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor, 24 credit hours to align with the GSC track requirements

data.subject: QMB
data.name: Quant Foundations
data.description: Quantitative methods for business students, includes business applications of sets, combinatorics, matrices, linear/non-linear functions, derivatives and integrals with view to optimization. Prerequisite: MAC 1105, students cannot receive credit for this course and MAC 2233 or any Calculus I or higher and business students only.

data.subject: QMB
data.name: Bus Stats & Analysis I
data.description: Inference and modeling for business decisions under uncertainty. Topics covered include survey sampling, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing for mean(s), variance(s), and proportion(s), chi-square test for independence and goodness of fit, correlation, linear regression, time series, and analysis of variance. Use of computer packages to solve real business problems

data.subject: QMB
data.name: Bus Stats & Analysis II
data.description: Application of business tools and techniques to complete inventory/production time-series and forecasting, spreadsheet modeling, optimization modeling, and decision tree analyses. Prerequisites: QMB 3200 with a 'C' or better. b) Minimum 60 credit hours earned, and c) Business students only

data.subject: RCS
data.name: Ser Del & Case Man
data.description: This course covers an evaluation of disability and rehabilitation potential in the context of service delivery and case management in the vocational rehabilitation process.

data.subject: RCS
data.name: Supervised Field Exp
data.description: Demonstration of the full range of competences learned throughout the program in counseling. Internship placements include a variety of field settings.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Lang & Lit Dev
data.description: Introduces linguistic elements of English, language development, emergent literacy, and their impact on L1 and L2 students.  Part of Block I.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Emergent Literacy
data.description: Focuses on young children's process of constructing meaning through literacy and implications for classroom practices. Meets FLDOE Reading Competencies 1 & 3. Field Hours may be required.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Teach Lit in School
data.description: Provides content and methods needed to understand and teach a quality literacy program that meets the needs of all children. Prerequisites:  RED 4311 (For ELEMED:BS) or RED 4150 (for ECHDED: BS).

data.subject: RED
data.name: Teach Begin Read
data.description: Provides content and methods needed to understand and teach beginning literacy to elementary students of  diverse backgrounds and abilities. Prerequisites: RED 3313 or EEX 3113; For ECE Majors: LAE 4405 AND RED 4100

data.subject: RED
data.name: Teach Interm Read
data.description: Provides content and methods needed to understand and teach transitional literacy to elementary students of diverse backgrounds and abilities. Field hours required. Prerequisites: RED 3313 or SPA 3000, RED 4150.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Subj Area Reading
data.description: Skills, techniques and strategies for reading in content areas.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Subj-Related Rdg
data.description: Skills, techniques and strategies for scaffolding the reading of struggling students and enhancing the comprehension and learning independence of all students using subject area materials.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Dir Study Read Ed
data.description: Elective in Reading Education. Directed study in area of reading instruction. Permission of the instructor required.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Rdg In Content Area
data.description: Required in graduate programs in Elementary and Reading Education and in secondary Modified Master's Programs. Strategies for developing the reading abilities of students in specific subject areas.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Research In Reading
data.description: Required in doctoral program and thesis track of Reading Education Master's program. Elective in standard Master's track. Includes reading research, critique, methodology and planning.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Practicum In Reading
data.description: Elective in graduate program in Reading Education. Supervised experience as reading professional in teaching, assessing, supervising, or research role.

data.subject: RED
data.name: Doc Dir Study Read
data.description: An elective course in the reading education doctoral program. Directed research in a specified area of reading education. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Admission to reading education doctoral program.

data.subject: REE
data.name: Real Estate Prin
data.description: Introduction to the nature, principles, and fundamental practices of the real estate industry. Prerequisites: ACG3301, QMB 3003 or ((STA2023 or STA2122) and (MAC2233 or (any Calculus I or higher course)) or equivalents with a grade of 'C' or higher Business students only.

data.subject: REE
data.name: Legal Environ Re
data.description: The legal environment of real estate as it relates to buying, financing and selling of real property.

data.subject: REE
data.name: Independent Studies
data.description: Individual conferences; supervised readings; reports on personal investigations. Prerequisites: Consent of instructor and Department Chairperson required.

data.subject: REE
data.name: Intl Real Estate
data.description: Focus on characteristics of international real estate environment include: inbound and outbound transactions, accounting practice, tax law, legal constraint, global strategic plan, foreign exchange, global financing, and cultural issues.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Intro to Religion
data.description: Introduces methods of critical reflection on religion and some of their applications to fundamental topics such as knowledge, value, the sacred, the individual and human society. Meets the state composition requirement.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Meditation/Spiritual
data.description: An examination of the varieties of meditation, meditation and health, meditation in religious traditions.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Meditation & Mystic
data.description: The history, philosophy, and cultural impact of the role of meditation in various mystical traditions, including movements such as Kabbalah, Neo-Platonism, Sufism, Yoga, Tantra, Taoism, and Zen Buddhism.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Religion & Sci. Fiction
data.description: Explores the relationship between religion and science fiction, examining key themes such as creation myths, innocence and experience, ritual, sacrifice, redemption, and religious diversity.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Intro Rel & Culture
data.description: This course explores both the ways religion uses culture to express its basic concerns and the ways that culture and lifestyle reflect religious perspectives. Attention will be given to traditional and popular expressions of American culture.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Religion In Film
data.description: Students examine religious themes, images, symbols and characters in various feature and short films, a specific method of critical analysis, and the religious and societal effects of contemporary films.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Sacred Dance Sacred Ritual
data.description: Investigation of the spiritual/religious, historical, and cultural context in which a variety of sacred dance complexes occur throughout the world.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Church And State
data.description: Explores the separation of church and state in the United States, reviewing its historical background and studying contemporary cases involving religious freedom.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Witchcraft
data.description: Explores contemporary beliefs, practices, and theories about Witchcraft and neo-pagan religions.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Women And Religion
data.description: Explores the involvement, portrayal, and roles of women in religion, from early goddess religions through the cult of Mary to contemporary feminist theology.

data.subject: REL
data.name: The Holocaust
data.description: Examines different aspects of the Holocaust as well as issues and events that led to and arose from the World War II Experience. Special attention is given to Jewish-Christian relations, thought and ethics before, during and after the Holocaust.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Studies In World Rel
data.description: Examines the origins, teachings, and practices of selected world religions. The specific religions selected for examination may vary from semester to semester.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Intro Asian Rels
data.description: The great traditions which originated in India and China,  Brahmanism, Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Confucianism, Taoism are explored in the cultural and social contexts.  Special attention is paid to how these religions contribute to the construction of social identities, as well as to the interaction between religions and their artistic expressions in painting, architecture, poetry and drama.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Healing in Asian Rels
data.description: Survey of varieties of healing techniques utilized in Asian Religions.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Religs Of Mythology
data.description: Examines the beliefs and practices of ancient Egyptian, Semitic, Greek, and Germanic religions, their influences on later civilization and religious thought, and the possible continuing insights offered by each.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Earth Ethics
data.description: This course will explore resources from philosophy and religion that could contribute to a solution of the current environmental crisis. Specific ethical issues will especially be examined.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Methods Study Relig
data.description: This course examines a number of the most important methods used in the academic study of religion, together with representative examples of the use of these methods.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Fem Theology/Ethics
data.description: Surveys major feminists and womanists on revelation, sexuality and body, liturgy, religious community and other topics across a variety of religious traditions.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Islamic Mysticism
data.description: Explores the depth and breadth of the mystical tradition of Islam (Sufism) through primary and secondary texts which look at the esoteric dimensions of mystical practice in the Islamic World.

data.subject: REL
data.name: African Religions
data.description: Critical analysis of the beliefs, myths, symbols, and rituals of traditional African religion, African Christianity, and African Islam, and exploration of their place and function in African societies.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Latinas & Religion
data.description: Examines Latinas' participation in the history of religions in the Americas in order to explain the impact of women's religious experiences in cultural, social and political realms.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Independent Research
data.description: Topics will be selected to meet the academic needs of the individual student.

data.subject: REL
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: In-depth study of topics of special interest in religious studies.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Advanced Fieldwork
data.description: Techniques of ethnography used in Religious Studies beginning with research design and including participant observation, interviews, surveys.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Hebrew Exegesis II
data.description: A continuation of Hebrew Exegesis I emphasizing the reading of select passages of the Hebrew Bible to develop skills in translation and interpretation. Prerequisites: RLG 5232 and graduate standing.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Sufism: Islamic Mysticism
data.description: Explores the depth and breadth of the mystical tradition of Islam (Sufism) through primary and secondary texts which look at the esoteric dimensions of mystical practice in the Islamic World.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Latinas' Religious Exp
data.description: Focus on the diversity of religious experiences among women born and educated in Latin cultures such as: Brazil, Haiti and Hispanic American, including Hispanic in the U.S.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Indep Research
data.description: Topics are selected to meet the academic needs of the individual student. Prerequisites: Permission of the instructor is required.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Topics will be selected to meet the academic needs of groups of students.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Pedagogy Workshop
data.description: Two-day teaching workshop offered by the Academy for the Art of Teaching. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Sem Sacred Texts
data.description: Sacred texts with a common theme from several religions. Problems of interpretation are a central concern. Prerequisites: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor.

data.subject: RLG
data.name: Thesis
data.description: For students working on the thesis for the M.A. in Religious Studies. Prerequisites: Graduate standing and permission of the instructor.

data.subject: RMI
data.name: Prin Of Risk & Ins
data.description: Risk Management, Elements of Risk Theory and Risk Bearing. The Insurance industry, fundamentals and legal concepts in insurance. Overview of property and liability as well as life insurance policies.

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Intro To Television
data.description: Introduction to the history, regulation, industry structure and impact of television.

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Video Studio Prod
data.description: Use of television studio equipment and techniques in production of programs, newcasts, documentaries, commercials, training and video productions. Introduction to basic video directing. Prerequisites:  MMC 3003, MMC 3123, RTV 3531, RTV 3007, RTV 4101, 2.85 cumulative GPA.

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Multimedia Prod
data.description: Use of ENG/EFP equipment and techniques in production of programs, news, documentaries, music videos, commercials, training and video productions on location. Emphasis on single camera techniques and editing. Prerequisites:  MMC 3123, VIC 3400 or admission to Visual Production Certificate. Corequisite: MMC 3123, VIC 3400 (Equipment fee assessed)

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Writing for Video Production
data.description: The course is intended to introduce the student to various types of writing for television and Internet/Journalism videos. This will include storytelling for short videos and short documentaries. Prerequisites: MMC 3003, MMC 3123, RTV 3007, RTV 3531, 2.85 cumulative GPA. Corequisite: RTV 3007, RTV 3531

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Elec News Gathering
data.description: This course is an introduction to the real world of video news. It is designed to teach students to plan, research, report, write and execute electronic news productions from concept to finished product.  Prerequisites:  MMC 3003, MMC 3123, RTV 3531, JOU 3117, 2.85 cumulative GPA. (Equipment fee assessed)

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Int Broadcast Newsroom
data.description: Students will learn how to research, report, write, shoot, produce, and edit hard news and feature stories for broadcast (capstone course). Prerequisites: MMC 3003, MMC 3123, RTV 3531, JOU 3117, (DIG 4293 or (RTV 4320 and RTV 4350)), 2.85 cumulative GPA.

data.subject: RTV
data.name: News Show Production
data.description: This course will emphasize instruction on producing newscasts by learning to position news stories based on journalistic news values, newsroom leadership skills and knowledge of the market. Prerequisites: MMC 3003, MMC 3123, RTV 3531, JOU 3117, DIG 4293, RTV 4320, 2.85 cumulative GPA

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Vis Story and Prod
data.description: The course is designed to teach students the reporting, pre-production and production skills required in multimedia journalism. Prerequisite: MMC 4940.

data.subject: RTV
data.name: Studio Pdctn Pract
data.description: The student will be responsible for the organization and complete pre-production, production and post-production of his/her project(s). Will also be required to do directing and I.D. work. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: SCE
data.name: Pers in Sci and Math Ed
data.description: This course will help students to develop understanding of theoretical frameworks and multiple perspectives underpinning mathematics and science education.

data.subject: SCE
data.name: Teach Elem Science
data.description: Provides content and methods needed to teach science and technology to elementary students of diverse backgrounds. Field hours required. Prerequisite: Three lower-division science courses, one with a lab

data.subject: SCE
data.name: Adv Elem Science Methods
data.description: Provides advanced development of knowledge, skills and dispositions necessary to prepare education majors to be effective science teachers of upper elementary grades through grade 6. Field Hours. Prerequisite. SCE 4310

data.subject: SCE
data.name: Student Teaching
data.description: Supervised teaching in a middle school or senior high school.

data.subject: SCE
data.name: Curr Dev Science Ed
data.description: Analysis of theoretical basis of curriculum development in Science Education Evaluation of currently available material. Development and testing of science curriculum materials.

data.subject: SDS
data.name: Fac Comm Helping Skills
data.description: Basic principles in the facilitative model of communication, helping skills and techniques for working with and counseling diverse client populations.

data.subject: SDS
data.name: Cri Co Inter
data.description: This course addresses prevention and intervention strategies in crisis situations including child abuse and neglect, suicide, substance abuse, AIDS, and personal loss. Prerequisite: MHS 5400.

data.subject: SDS
data.name: Couns Child Adoles
data.description: Theory and application of counseling elementary age children and adolescents including family issues and interventions, legal and ethical considerations and counseling at-risk and exceptional children.

data.subject: SDS
data.name: Sup Fld Exp Coun Ed
data.description: This internship course covers a practical demonstration of the full range of competencies learned throughout the school counseling program. Internship placements include a variety of school field settings.

data.subject: SLS
data.name: Discover Your Major
data.description: This course is designed for exploratory majors. Through the process of self-exploration and career planning, students will learn how to match their interests and skills to an appropriate major/career.

data.subject: SLS
data.name: First Year Exper
data.description: A review of basic skills and competencies necessary to college success including time management, study skills, and academic policies/procedures.  Includes mandated information.

data.subject: SLS
data.name: Strategies for Success
data.description: Improve students' academic and personal development in the areas of learning strategies, study skills, time management, problem solving, goal setting, and how to use resources effectively.

data.subject: SLS
data.name: Major and Career Exploration
data.description: Students will be exposed to the fundamentals of career development strategies and clarify interests and skills as related to major/career choice.

data.subject: SLS
data.name: Spec Top in Ar, Sc, & Ed
data.description: N/A

data.subject: SMT
data.name: STEP 1&2 Lesson Math and Sci
data.description: Explore teaching in an middle school setting and become familiar with writing and teaching inquiry-based mathematics or science lessons using exemplary resources.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: STEP 1 Teach Math and Sci
data.description: Students who want to explore teaching careers become familiar with writing and teaching inquiry-based mathematics or science lessons using exemplary resources in an elementary school setting. Prerequisite: Interest in exploring science or mathematics teaching as a career.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: STEP 2 Lesson Math and Sci
data.description: Students who want to explore teaching careers become familiar with writing and teaching inquiry-based mathematics or science lessons using exemplary resources in an elementary school setting.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Know and Learn Math and Sci
data.description: Focus on knowing and learning in secondary mathematics and science as understood from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Students identify theories and employ theories to guide their own practice.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: LA Seminar
data.description: Evidence-based instructional theory and practice for undergraduate Learning Assistants. Covers effective pedagogical strategies, collaborative learning, and assessment across the STEM disciplines.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Class Interact Math and Sci
data.description: Focuses on examination of the interplay between teachers, students, and content, and how such interactions enable students to develop deep understanding of the mathematics and science ideas.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Prob Based Instr Math-Sci
data.description: Focus on exploring authentic, important, and meaningful questions and developing a PBI science/mathematics unit, employing processes/technologies that scientists, mathematicians, and engineers use. Prerequisite: SMT 4301 or Program permission

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Advanced LA Intern 2
data.description: Available to those with 1-3 semesters of LA Intern experience. Serves as LA team leader; works with faculty in weekly LA planning sessions. May be repeated. Permission of instructor required. Prerequisites: SMT4946. Corequisite: Students must be employed as LAs during the semester they registered.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Learning Assist Intern 1
data.description: LA internship 1-Introductory. Supervised, practical experience in a teaching a college STEM course or laboratory. Permission of instructor is required. May be repeated up to 3 semesters.Prerequisites: PHY 3012,MAE 3893,CHM 3945 and ESC 3050 or SCE 3813. Corequisite: Students must be employed as LAs during the semester they register.

data.subject: SMT
data.name: Know and Learn in STEM Ed
data.description:
Students will develop a deep understanding of learning theories and how these
help inform research in formal and informal STEM education settings.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Psy Of Sexual Behvr
data.description: An examination of the nature, development, decline, and disorders of sexual behaviors, primarily from the perspectives of normal adjustment and interpersonal relations. Discussion also addresses love, intimacy, and similar emotionally charged socio-psychological topics. Modern and popular treatment approaches - including the 'new sex therapies' are critically evaluated.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Intro Social Psy
data.description: Introduction to the study of the relationship of the individual to social systems, including topics such as social behavior, attitude development and change, social conflict, group processes, mass phenomena, and communication.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Soc & Per Dev
data.description: This course provides a survey of social and personality development throughout the life cycle. Emphasis will be placed on the interaction between psychological and environmental variables in life-span development changes.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Psy Of Women
data.description: An examination of women from various perspectives, such as biological, anthropological, mythological, religious, historical, legal, sociological, and psychoanalytical points of view. Discussions of ways in which these various perspectives influence the psychological development of contemporary women.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Psych of Drugs & Drug Use
data.description: This course will cover the nature and effects of various drugs, the social and personal dynamics involved in problematic substance use, and various rehabilitation programs.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Global Psychology
data.description: Examination of cultural contexts informing human behavior and psychological well internationally. Students will examine psychology research through direct application to global phenomena.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Women and Leadership
data.description: A social psychological examination of how gender and leadership are constructed, the behaviors of men and women leaders, and how men and women leaders are perceived.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Legal Psychology
data.description: Particular emphasis will be given to interpersonal courtroom processes. Topics considered include scientific jury selection, proximics, persuasive argumentation, witness demeanor, eyewitness testimony, and similar influences upon juror decision making.

data.subject: SOP
data.name: Prosem Soc Psy
data.description: An in-depth examination of the role of social psychology in the social sciences and the major substantive problems as they relate to contemporary societal issues. Minimum Prerequisites: An introductory course in social psychology or its equivalent.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Dyn Hum Bh/Soc Envm
data.description: Study of individual development, personality, and behavior from a bio-psychological and sociocultural perspective with emphasis on the life cycle, giving attention to racial/ethnic, gender and sexual orientation variables.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Socl Evirmnt & Hm Bh
data.description: Study of the socio-cultural factors (including racial, ethnic, and gender and sexual orientation variables) affecting human development and behavior in families, groups, organizations, and communities.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Intro Social Work
data.description: An overview of the profession of social work within the institution of social welfare. Historical and philosophical development, field of practice, values, and ethics.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Soc Wel Pol I
data.description: This course considers the major social welfare programs in the United States: how they emerged and developed, and how they operate today. Analysis of financial resources, decision-making processes, and structure of delivery systems serves as a basis for understanding policy assessment.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: So Wel Pol & Ser II
data.description: This course examines the frameworks and methods used to analyze social welfare policy and programs. Special attention is paid to current policy issues in the Social Welfare system and strategies that can be used to achieve policy change.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: SOW Prac with Fam/Ind
data.description: Overview of generalist social work practice with a focus on individuals and families. Social work practice framework and principles, use of values/ethics and skill development are included.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Interviewing Lab
data.description: This is a competency-based course providing students with basic interviewing skills for Social Work practice. Emphasis is on acquisition of interviewing behavior rather than theory. Prerequisite: Social Work Majors or by permission only Corequisite: SOW 3313 or by permission only

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Social Wk Research
data.description: Introduction to the basic language, methods, and skills of scientific research for beginning social work practice. Problem formulation, literature review, definition of variables, sampling, data collection and analysis, and report writing are addressed.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Soc Wk & Diversity
data.description: Prepares students for generalist social work practice with diverse populations focusing on knowledge, attitude, and skills. A global learning course.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: SOW Prac with Groups
data.description: This course is designed to provide the theories and techniques of generalist social work practice with small groups in a wide range of social service agencies and with a diverse client population.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: SOW Prac with Com/Org
data.description: Provides an understanding of planned change at the community level from a social work perspective, as well as strategies and methods utilized in community organization practice. Identification of generalist skills and prevalent models of groups and community organization in social work practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Practicum I
data.description: The first of two practicum courses that provide students with the opportunity to apply and integrate generalist social work knowledge and skills in a supervised practice experience.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Practicum II
data.description: The second of two practicum courses that provide students with the opportunity to apply and integrate generalist social work knowledge and skills in a supervised practice experience.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Field Seminar I
data.description: This seminar is taken concurrently with SOW 4511L and SOW 4322. It is designed to analyze the field practicum experience by emphasizing the integration of theory and practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Field Seminar II
data.description: This seminar is taken concurrently with SOW 4512L and SOW 4332. It is designed to analyze the field practicum experience by emphasizing the integration of theory and practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Child Abuse Interv
data.description: This course will examine best practices in the health, mental health and socio emotional development of children and adolescents within the child welfare system.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Individual Study
data.description: Individually selected program of supervised study related to specific social work issues. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Hum Bhr/Soc Env I
data.description: Study of individuals and families with emphasis on the analysis of biopsychosocio-cultural factors (including racial/ethnic and gender variables) affecting human development and social functioning through the life cycle.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Trauma Theory and Interv
data.description: This course will provide an overview of theories related to trauma over the lifespan and skills necessary to assess and intervene in situations involving trauma. Prerequisites: SOW 5105, Human Biology, Human Behavior, and Social Environment or similar. Corequisites: Social work major or similar field.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sw Policy I
data.description: This course analyzes major social welfare policies and programs in the United States, their emergence, development, contemporary operations and how they shaped the development of the Social Work profession.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Adv Child Abuse Interv
data.description: This course will examine best practices in the health, mental health, and socio emotional development of children and adolescents within the child welfare system.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Theory & Prac-Groups
data.description: Study and application of biopsychosocial, cultural dimensions, theories, techniques and intervention strategies for social work group practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sw Prac Indiv & Fam
data.description: This course is an overview of social work practice with individuals and families placing emphasis on professional values, interviewing skills, assessment, intervention, and outcome evaluation, all within a cross-cultural perspective.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Th And Prac-Com/Org
data.description: Study and application of biopsycho-socio-cultural dimensions, theories, techniques and intervention strategies for communities and organizations. Focuses on empowerment of populations at risk and promotion of social and economic justice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Interviewing Skills Lab
data.description: Competency-based course providing graduate students with basic interviewing skills for social work practice. Emphasis is on acquisition of interviewing behavior rather than theory.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sow Resrch Mthd I
data.description: This course provides information on the principles and methods of basic social work research. The ethical conduct of research is taught within the context of social work purposes and values. The formulation of problems for study that address the social needs of diverse population groups is emphasized.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Field Practicum I
data.description: The first masters-level field practicum and seminars that provide students with the opportunity to apply and integrate generalist social work knowledge and skills.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Medical Social Work
data.description: Principles of medical social work practice in hospitals and communities. Focuses on the social worker as part of the health care team, with basic knowledge of medical problems of patients and their families.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sow Prac-Diversity
data.description: Prepares students for responsive practice with diverse populations, with emphasis on South Florida. Includes knowledge and skills in interviewing, assessment interventions, termination, and follow-up.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Issues In Addiction
data.description: An overview of chemical dependency in the social service delivery system including policy and program approaches, client assessment, treatment techniques and prevention issues.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Individual Study
data.description: Individually selected program of advanced supervised study related to specific issues in social work and social welfare. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Hum Bhr/Soc Env II
data.description: Study of the psychosocial aspects of client problems, including psychopathology, frequently encountered by social workers in direct practice with attention to differential treatment issues. Prerequisite: SOW 5532 or advanced standing status.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sw Policy II
data.description: This course offers students the opportunity to gain in-depth knowledge about social welfare policy-making processes and their impact on the social service delivery system. Prerequisite: SOW 5532 or advanced standing status.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Sw Fam Practice
data.description: Provides students with a critical and culturally sensitive understanding and application of the major models of social work intervention with couples and families.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Assess and Interven
data.description: Critical analysis of assessment models, the current issues, skills of assessment and intervention planning, including the evidence basis of assessment practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Evidence-Based Practice
data.description: Examines the foundations of knowledge, tools to find resources, design tailored interventions, implement, and evaluate evidence-based social work practice.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Field Practicum II
data.description: The first part of two masters-level advanced field practicum courses and integrative seminars that provide students with the opportunity to apply and integrate advanced clinical knowledge and skills.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Field Practicum III
data.description: The second advanced field practicum/ integrative seminar which includes licensure prep and capstone, giving students the opportunity to apply and integrate advanced clinical knowledge and skills. Prerequisites:  SOW6533, SOW6435, SOW6125, SOW6236  Corequisite: SOW6351

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Addiction Prev
data.description: Course provides increased understanding of substance abuse prevention including history and effective approaches as well as skills to reinforce healthy lifestyles and identify early potential problems.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Independent Research
data.description: Individually selected program of supervised data collection and analysis on specific topics in social work and social welfare.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Micro Theor Res
data.description: Analysis of research priorities in the development of effective interventions in the social welfare field.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Macro Theor Res
data.description: This course focuses on intervention theory research and methods at the community, organizational and societal level.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Supervised Research
data.description: Directed experience in the conduct of research in social welfare and social work under the guidance of a faculty member. Must be taken twice for a total of six credits.

data.subject: SOW
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: This course provides dissertation guidance to doctoral candidates in the Ph.D. program in Social Welfare. Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Norm Comm Dev
data.description: Advanced study of the processes of typical speech and language acquisition as the basis for understanding associated developmental speech and language disorders. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Intro CSD
data.description: Introduction to the processes of communication sciences and principles of identification, assessment, and treatment of speech and language disorders. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Disorders Hg and Aud
data.description: Principles and procedures involved in the identification and assessment of problems associated with the auditory mechanism, including hearing loss prevention and conservation of auditory functioning. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Clin Obs and Procedures
data.description: Study of the principles involved in therapeutic intervention of communication disorders in different clinical settings. Observation of assessment and treatment sessions is a requirement of the course. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Adv Human AP Comm
data.description: Advanced study of anatomy, physiology, and neurology mechanisms of speech and hearing. Includes system study of speech production and perception: respiration, phonation, articulation, audition. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders. Corequisite: SPA 5102L.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Lab Adv Human AP
data.description: Laboratory extension of SPA 5102C Advance Human Anatomy and Physiology of Mechanisms of Communication to accompany this course. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders. Corequisite: SPA 5102C.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Neuro Bases Com
data.description: The anatomical and physiological aspects of the central and peripheral nervous system as they pertain to communication acquisition and disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Adv Appl Phonetics
data.description: Advanced study of principles of phonetics and phonetic transcription via International Phonetic Alphabet. Physiological descriptions and classification of speech sounds. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Acoustics Sph and Hg
data.description: Advanced study of the communication sciences associated with the process of speech and hearing, including speech perception and production, speech and hearing physiology, and acoustic phonetics. Prerequisite: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Ling for Speech-Lang Path
data.description: Study of linguistic theory as applicable to speech-language development and disorders relative to speech-language pathology. Emphasis is on description and analysis of major components of language.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Lng Lrn Sch-Age Chl
data.description: Overview and evaluation of the language skills of preschool and school aged children including metalinguistic and discourse development.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Basic Clin Prac
data.description: Supervised practice with representative speech and language problems in the school settings.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: As & Trmt Bilng Chld
data.description: Assessment and treatment of normal and atypical language development across cultures. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Aural Rehab
data.description: This course provides information and strategies for aural habilitation intervention with hearing impaired children. Includes techniques of speech reading, auditory training and language for the hearing impaired. The course is part of the Graduate Certificate in CSD and is an elective course in the Masters' in Speech-Language Pathology (if student has not completed an undergraduate course in aural rehabilitation or has not taken as part of the Graduate Certificate). Prerequisite: SPA 5035

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Dual Lang Acqui Dis
data.description: Development of normal and atypical language in speakers of more than one language.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Aphasia
data.description: Consideration of the neurological and psychological aspects of aphasia and related approaches are discussed and evaluated. Prerequisites: SPA 5107 and Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Com Dis and Aging BI
data.description: Survey of types and characteristics of bilingualism and normal and atypical speech and language changes associated with aging.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Adv Clin Prac
data.description: Supervised practice with severe communication problems in area hospitals and long term care facilities.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Master's Project
data.description: This course provides the student with an opportunity to explore in-depth a specific topic of interest in speech pathology. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Topics Spch Path
data.description: This course is intended to give students information about topical issues in the field of Speech Language Pathology. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.

data.subject: SPA
data.name: Master's Thesis
data.description: Supervised research on an original research project submitted in partial fulfillment of the Master's degree requirement. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Fund of Argument and Debate
data.description: Lectures and activities concerned with audience-centered reasoning. One will learn the nature of arguments consisting of analysis, reasoning, evidence, values, and building and refuting arguments.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Public Speaking
data.description: Study of the principles of ethical and effective public speaking, with practice in the construction and delivery of original speeches before an audience.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Communication Thry
data.description: Introduction to the study of human communication processes including verbal and nonverbal modalities. Key historical and contemporary definitions and concepts in communication theory are reviewed.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Rhetorical Communication
data.description: Students study how spoken and written language shapes human thought and influences the humanities.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Rhetoric and Public Address
data.description: The course explores the ways in which prominent figures have sought to define the nation and address major political controversies over the course of U.S. history through rhetorical public address.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Interpersonal Comm
data.description: Through an awareness of self-concept students explore the role communication plays in maintaining healthy relationships in areas such as: romantic relationships, friendships, families and colleagues.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Small Group Comm
data.description: The study of group development, group roles, decision-making, leadership, power, and conflict management.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Persuasion
data.description: A study of attitude formation and change are explored to identify how individuals process and act on information. Social influence theories/techniques and their ethical implications are examined.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Adv Public Speaking
data.description: Examines public speaking as a workplace activity and provides students with practical experience. Emphasis is placed on incorporating technology into the different types of speeches.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Gender and Commun
data.description: Using text and films, this course examines the different styles of verbal and non-verbal communication of men and women in various settings.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Comm for Effec Leadership
data.description: Leadership is given to those who speak well, inspire change, and motivate others. Leadership communication empowers students to become effective leaders ready to engage a global world.

data.subject: SPC
data.name: Pres Skills for Archtcts
data.description: This course provides architecture students with experiences delivering formal presentations. Participants will learn techniques for enhancing academic and professional presentations.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Spanish I
data.description: Course designed specifically for beginning university students with no previous language study. Emphasis on oral Spanish and on acquiring basic language skills.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Spanish II
data.description: Emphasis on oral Spanish and on acquiring basic language skills.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Interm Spanish I
data.description: Provides intermediate training in the acquisition and application of basic language skills.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Interm Spanish II
data.description: Last course of a four-semester sequence which implements a proficiency-oriented approach. Focuses on the development of listening and reading comprehension skills, and encourages maximum oral interaction and the practice of writing.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Interm Sp Herit Spks
data.description: Improves reading, grammar, and writing skills for heritage speakers educated in the U.S. that can understand and communicate in Spanish. Expands cultural knowledge of Hispanic countries.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Adv Spn Non-Herit Spks
data.description: Review and expand basic structures of Spanish, develop formal vocabulary, improve oral and written skills, learn more about history and cultures of Spanish-speaking countries. For non-heritage speakers.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Adv Spn Herit Spks
data.description: Improve literacy skills through grammar review, composition, and selected readings of representative Hispanic writers. For heritage speakers. Prerequisite: Advanced proficiency in Spanish.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Adv Spn Conver
data.description: Improvement of oral proficiency and listening comprehension skills, correction of accent, vocabulary building. Use of small group conversation, pronunciation tapes, and varied outside readings.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Adv Grammar-Comp I
data.description: To consolidate the student's command of oral and written Spanish. Advanced readings of authentic materials. Preparation and documentation of written monographs. For natives and advanced non-natives.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Spn Business Comp
data.description: Training in the special writing needs of business: letter-writing, memoranda, brochures, advertising, proposals, declarations, government documents, etc.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Span Bus Lat Am
data.description: A Spanish composition course with content matter in contemporary Latin American business and current events at the advances/intermediate level of Spanish language. Prerequisite: Intermediate level of written and oral composition of Spanish language.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Intro Span Linguistics
data.description: Study the sound system, word structure, phrase formation and the history of the Spanish language. Learn about dialects and sociolects in the Spanish-speaking world. Prerequisite: SPN 3422.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Spanish Culture
data.description: Examines global manifestations of Spanish culture throughout history to gain insight into contemporary aspects of Spanish identity. Prerequisite: Open to any student who understands the target language.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Latin Am Culture
data.description: Introduction to the major artistic and cultural phenomena in Latin America. Art, music, film, and literature will be discussed in their cultural context. Prerequisite: Ability to understand Spanish at an advanced level.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Project, field experience, readings, or research.

data.subject: SPN
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Research toward the completion of a doctoral dissertation. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of the Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: SPS
data.name: Psy Ed As I
data.description: This course addresses competencies in the assessment of intellectual ability and adaptive behavior in children. Corequisite: SPS 6191L for School Psychology majors. No corequisite for other majors.

data.subject: SPS
data.name: Psy Ed As III
data.description: Competencies in behavioral and personality assessment of students within the school setting with emphasis on projective testing and behavioral observations are addressed in this course.

data.subject: SPS
data.name: Fam School & Coll
data.description: This course is designed to develop essential communicative/interactive interpersonal skills, as well as collaborative problem-solving skills, in special education, counseling, and school psychology graduate students. Corequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: SPS
data.name: Sup Fld Exp Sch Psy
data.description: An internship where students demonstrate of the full range of competencies learned throughout the program in School Psychology. Internship placements include a variety of field settings.

data.subject: SPS
data.name: Practicum
data.description: Student engage in supervised clinical experience. This course may be repeated.

data.subject: SPT
data.name: Found Transl Skills
data.description: Techniques of translation, in Spanish and English, applied to law, business, technology, and literature.

data.subject: SPT
data.name: Found Interpreting
data.description: Exercises in sight translation, consecutive and simultaneous interpretation in Spanish and English. Theory and practice.

data.subject: SPT
data.name: Prac Legal Transl
data.description: Provides advanced training in translating most commonly used legal documents in both civil and criminal procedures.

data.subject: SPT
data.name: Prac Business Tran
data.description: Business and language translation and the business world. Principles, techniques, and methods of business translation. Extensive practical exercises in translating routine business documents English to Spanish and vice versa.

data.subject: SPT
data.name: Medical Interpret
data.description: Provides an overview of terminology, methods, ethics, standards of practice, as well as linguistic and cognitive processes of medical interpreting. Prerequisite: SPT 3812

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Span Am Lit
data.description: Close reading and analysis of prose, poetry and drama. Selections from Spanish American Literature.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Peninsular Span Lit
data.description: Close reading and analysis of prose, poetry, and drama. Selections from Spanish peninsular literature.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: Readings and discussion of literary/linguistic topics to be determined by students and instructor.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Spn Amer Poetry II
data.description: A view of Spanish American poetry from 1850 to the present. Representative works of the important poets will be examined, and special attention will be given to Lezama Lima, Parra, Paz, and Vallejo.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Golden Age Drama
data.description: Close readings from the finest plays written in Spain's Golden Age by Lope de Vega, Calderon, Tirso, and others, including the Don Juan theme. An examination of theatre as stylized conformity and as protest literature in a highly controlled society.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Sp Topics Lang/Lit
data.description: Content and objectives to be determined by student and instructor.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Lit Theory/Critic
data.description: Study of the theoretical foundation of literature and contemporary systems of critical approach to literary discourse. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.

data.subject: SPW
data.name: Pre-Dis Research
data.description: Enables students to concentrate on completion of their dissertation prospectus during the term in which they take Ph.D. comprehensive exams. Prerequisite: Completion of all other Ph.D. coursework.

data.subject: SSE
data.name: Teach Elem Soc Stud
data.description: Provides content and methods needed to understand and teach Social Studies from a global, multi-ethnic perspective to elementary students of diverse backgrounds.

data.subject: SSE
data.name: Ped & Content of Elem SS
data.description: Provides additional pedagogy & content needed to teach Social Studies from a global, multi-ethnic perspective to elementary students of diverse backgrounds. Field hours required. Prerequisite: SSE 4312

data.subject: SSE
data.name: Global Perspectives
data.description: Theory, content, and practice. Introduction and utilization of learning materials and teaching strategies in Global Education for K-12.

data.subject: SSE
data.name: Persp in Soc Sc Ed
data.description: This course explores in-depth social science content using various pedagogical methods based on an understanding of the various social science disciplines.

data.subject: SSE
data.name: Student Teaching
data.description: Supervised teaching in a middle school or senior high school.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat Bus & Eco
data.description: Starting with an introduction to probability, the course provides an introduction to statistical techniques used in management science. It includes descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and testing of hypotheses. Subsequent credit for STA 2122 or STA 3111 will not be granted. Prerequisite: High school algebra.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat for Behav Scien I
data.description: A course in descriptive and inferential statistics. Topics include: probability distribution of discrete and continuous random variables. Sampling distributions. Large sample estimation and hypothesis testing for means and proportions. Prerequisite: High school algebra.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Prob & Stat For Cs
data.description: Basic probability laws, probability distributions, basic sampling theory, point and interval estimation, tests of hypotheses, regression and correlation.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Statistics I
data.description: Descriptive statistics. Basic probability rules. Discrete and continuous probability distributions. Point and Interval estimation, hypothesis testing based on a single sample. Comparison of two proportions using independent and large samples. Subsequent credit for STA 2122 or STA 2023 will not be granted.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Statistics II
data.description: Estimation and hypothesis testing based on two samples. Analysis of Variance. Simple linear regression. Linear correlation. Analysis of categorial data. Non-parametric methods. Use of statistical software packages. Subsequent credit for STA 3123 will not be granted.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat for Behav Scien II
data.description: Small sample statistical inference for means and variances. T, chi-square and F distributions. Analysis of variance, regression, correlation, basic nonparametric tests, goodness of fit tests and tests of independence.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Sta Hlth Profession
data.description: Statistical analysis with applications in the health sciences. Binomial and normal distributions. Inferences about means and proportions. Regression, correlation, goodness of fit tests. Prerequisite: High school algebra.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat Methods II
data.description: This course presents tools for the analysis of data. Specific topics include: use of normal distribution, tests of means, variances and proportions; the analysis of variance and covariance (including contrasts and components of variance models), regression, correlation, sequential analysis, and non-parametric analysis.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat for Biology II
data.description: Analysis of variance, correlation, regression, discrete data analysis, analysis of covariance and non-parametric procedures. Introduction to design of experiments, bio assay, logistic regression and multivariate analysis.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Special Topics
data.description: A course designed to give groups of students an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Stat Presentations
data.description: Students will communicate orally all stages of statistical analysis through a presentation in front of faculty and students. The problem must have a global component to be explained by the student.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Intro Regression
data.description: Multiple and polynomial regression, residual analysis, model identification and other related topics. Credit will not be given for both STA 4234 and STA 5236.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Intro To Math Stat I
data.description: This course presents an introduction to the mathematics underlying the concepts of statistical analysis. It is based on a solid grounding in probability theory, and requires a knowledge of single and multivariable calculus. Specific topics include the following: basic probability concepts, random variables, probability densities, expectations, moment generating functions, sampling distributions, decision theory, estimation, hypothesis testing (parametric and non-parametric), regression, analysis of variance, and design of experiments.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Intr To Math Stat II
data.description: This course presents an introduction to the mathematics underlying the concepts of statistical analysis. It is based on a solid grounding in probability theory, and requires a knowledge of single and multivariable calculus. Specific topics include the following: basic probability concepts, random variables, probability densities, expectations, moment generating functions, sampling distributions, decision theory, estimation, hypothesis testing (parametric and non-parametric), regression, analysis of variance, and design of experiments.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Independent Study
data.description: Individual conferences, assigned readings, and reports on independent investigations.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Regression Analysis
data.description: Simple, multiple and polynomial regression, analysis of residuals, model building and other related topics. Credit for both STA 4234 and STA 5236 will not be granted. Prerequisites: STA 3112 or STA 3123 or STA 3164, or STA 6167.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Biostatistics
data.description: Statistical analysis of data encountered in medical sciences. Analysis of count data, Kaplan-Meier survival analysis, Cox proportional hazards model, analysis of covariance, logistic regression, etc. Prerequisites: STA 3163 or equivalent.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Linear Models
data.description: Introduction to the theory of linear models. Distribution of linear and quadratic functions of normal vectors. Development of inferential procedures for simple and other more complex linear models Prerequisites: MAS 3105, STA 6247, and STA 6327.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Data Analysis II
data.description: Analysis of variance, regression analysis. Analysis of covariance, quality control, correlation, empirical distributions. Prerequisites: MAS 3105 and STA 6244.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Math Stat II
data.description: Estimation of parameters, tests of hypotheses, regression, non-parametric methods, analysis of variance, and multivariate concepts. Prerequisite: STA 6326.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Large Data Analysis
data.description: Statistical techniques used to analyze high dimensional data sets. Topics include machine learning, high dimensional data, discriminant analysis and clustering. Prerequisites: STA 6246 and STA 5236 or equivalent.

data.subject: STA
data.name: Thesis Research
data.description: Supervised research on theoretical or applied statistics leading to a thesis. Repeatable. Prerequisite: Permission of student's program committee.

data.subject: SUR
data.name: Surveying
data.description: Computations and field procedures associated with the measurement of distances and angles using tape, level, transit, EDMs, and total station. Laboratory is included with field measurements.Prerequisite:  EGN1110C

data.subject: SWS
data.name: Adv Soil Resources
data.description: A review of soil science concepts: analysis of physical and chemical properties of soils and nutrient cycling, emphasizing the soils of South Florida.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Research Methods
data.description: Topics include the formulation of research problems; research design; data collection methods; hypothesis testing; and analysis, interpretation, and reporting results. Departmental permission required.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Intro Quant Soc Research
data.description: Introduction to quantitative methods used in the analysis of sociological data, as well as data in other areas of social research.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Internship
data.description: Working in an organization for the semester to acquire relevant professional experience related to the major. May be repeated.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Class Trad Soc Thry
data.description: Compares/contrasts propositions of key sociological theorists on origins/characteristics/transformations of societies. Explores application of theories for understanding & addressing social problems.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Social Theory
data.description: Focuses on one or more theoretical perspectives from the standpoint of a particular empirical research issue or set of issues. Topics may vary by instructor and by semester.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Dir Indiv Study
data.description: Supervised readings and/or field research and training. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Direct Individ Study
data.description: Supervised readings and/or field research and training. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Soc Res Quant Methods II
data.description: Second course in the graduate program's sequence in social research quantitative methods. Discusses the relationship between theory and research, and quantitative in relation to qualitative methods.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: GIS and Soc Research
data.description: Focuses on applications of GIS in social research; includes applying critical perspective on space, place, cartography to GIS social research projects.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Field Research
data.description: Research projects or certain aspects of research in a field situation carried out by one or more students under the direction of a faculty member. Topics vary. Usually selected on an individual basis. Hours may vary.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Prep Doctoral Exam
data.description: Preparation for the preliminary doctoral exam under the direction of a faculty member. Hours may vary.

data.subject: SYA
data.name: Ph.D. Dissertation
data.description: Hours taken by students to work on the dissertation under the supervision of a major professor and the doctoral committee. Hours may vary.  Prerequisites: Permission of Major Professor and Doctoral Candidacy.

data.subject: SYD
data.name: Sociology Of Gender
data.description: An examination of women's and men's roles, statuses, and life opportunities in society. Consideration of current theories of gender inequality.

data.subject: SYD
data.name: Immigr And Refugees
data.description: Examines causes and consequences of immigration and the forcible displacement of people. Investigates the experiences of immigrants and refugees.

data.subject: SYD
data.name: Latin & Carib Soc
data.description: Exploration of the types of social structures, statuses, and roles, and the resulting distributions of power and authority in the hemisphere.

data.subject: SYD
data.name: Adv Race, Gender, Sexuality
data.description: Examines the transnational, interrelated history of race and gender from the 16th century to the present.

data.subject: SYD
data.name: Directed Readings
data.description: Readings under the direction of a faculty member focusing on one of the tracks in the Ph.D. program. Hours may vary.

data.subject: SYG
data.name: Intro Sociology
data.description: Introduces sociological perspectives and methods, and the sociological study of issues such as socialization, gender, race/ethnicity, social class, and global inequality.

data.subject: SYG
data.name: Basic Ideas Of Soc
data.description: The course introduces the student to the ideas of community, authority, status, alienation, and the sacred, as used in sociological literature.

data.subject: SYG
data.name: Deviance in Society
data.description: Examines loca/glob cultural patterns in the social construction of deviance & social control. Topics may include deviant identities/sexualities/mental health/disability/crime & justice/cyber-deviance

data.subject: SYG
data.name: Soc Of Sexuality
data.description: Applies sociological perspectives to sexual attitudes and behavior, examining various world cultures. Topics include premarital and extramarital sex, sexual orientation, and prostitution.

data.subject: SYO
data.name: Health & Medicine in Soci
data.description: Presents an overview of the social facets of health/illness, healthcare approaches, and healthcare policies in local and global perspective.

data.subject: SYO
data.name: Political Soc
data.description: Explores power & conflict in local & global social life. Topics may include: formation of nation states/soc. Movements/soc. Inequalities/colonialism/immigration/human rights/environmental problems.

data.subject: SYP
data.name: Indiv In Society
data.description: Introduction to the study of the individual as a social being, with emphasis on theoretical conceptions of the relationship between the individual and society, and structural and cultural constraints versus individual agency.

data.subject: SYP
data.name: Societies in World
data.description: Investigates societies in comparative, historical, & global perspective. Possible topics: social class, gender, race-ethnicity, culture, politics, economy, globalization, migration, & environment.

data.subject: SYP
data.name: Crime & Society
data.description: Examines social construction of crime & its consequences for society. Considers theory & policy related to crime, law enforcement, & crim. justice in relation to political power & social inequalities.

data.subject: SYP
data.name: Global & Society
data.description: Examines the economic, political and social dimensions of globalization and the theories used to describe and account for globalization.  Course material may focus on particular world regions and comparisons between or among world regions.

data.subject: SYP
data.name: Develop Post Devel
data.description: Examines theories and case studies concerning development and post-development in global perspective.

data.subject: TAX
data.name: Income Tax Accountin
data.description:
A survey of federal income taxation with emphasis on taxation of individuals and corporations, and the ethics of income tax accounting.  	
Prerequisites:  a grade of 'C' or higher a)QMB3003 or MAC2233 or (any Calculus I or higher course), b)ACG3301 or equivalent for any with ; c) 60 credits earned d) qualifying Accounting Entrance Exam score and GPA (BUEE only)

data.subject: TAX
data.name: Taxation Corp & Part
data.description: An in-depth study of income taxation of corporations and partnerships, including tax planning. Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C' or higher in TAX4001 and ACG 4101, 60 credits earned Corequisite: BUL 4321.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Intro to IoT
data.description: Introduces the fundamental concepts of loT and motivates the study of loT. Focuses on the Devices, Data Collection, Networking, Cloud Computing, Risks and Opportunities in loT context.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Tele Net Security
data.description: Introduction and overview of security issues for engineering applications. Topics include design, implementation and management of security in networks.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Telecom Networks
data.description: Underlying engineering principles of computer and digital networks. Topics include physical, link and network layers; telecommunication and switching technologies.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Telenet Analys Des
data.description: The principle and practice of telecommunication and computer networks with emphasis on telecommunication network protocols, datagram services, routing and QoS.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Senior Project
data.description: Beginning of the Major Design Experiment of the Professional ethics, oral communications, project feasibility study, report writing, system design methodology, human factors, intellectual property. Prerequisite: Senior Standing

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Telecomm Soft & Meth
data.description: A high-level look into network architectures and distributed applications, client-server models, network software platforms and advanced techniques for programs specifications through implementation.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Wrls Comm Mmdia App
data.description: Overview of wireless communications systems; interference, blocking, spectral efficiency; performance of digital modulation in presence of fading; diversity techniques; and multimedia applications.  Prerequisite: EEL 3514.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Adv. IoT Comm. & Netw
data.description: This course presents advanced paradigms in terms of communication of IoT devices and the underlying networking protocols. Topics covered include IoT platforms, applications and protocol stack.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Mobile Computing
data.description: Enabling technologies and impediments of mobile computing.  It includes mobile architectural design, mobile-aware and transparent adaptation, mobile data access and file systems, and ad-hoc networks.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Wireless Info Sys
data.description: Enabling technologies and impediments of wireless information systems.  Focuses on software architectures, and information and location management in the wireless environment.

data.subject: TCN
data.name: Ind Dev Of Telecom
data.description: This course, from a management perspective, addresses the evolution of the telecom industry, the impact it has on reshaping our world, and the importance of management decisions in telecom.

data.subject: THE
data.name: Theatre Appreciation
data.description: A study of theatre: process and product, introducing the past of theatre, its literature and traditions; and the means by which theatre is produced: acting, directing and visual design.

data.subject: THE
data.name: Internship Experience
data.description: Experience in theatrical services gained through work with professionals.

data.subject: THE
data.name: Theatre History II
data.description: The development of the theatre from early 19th century to the present

data.subject: THE
data.name: Mod Dramatic Lit
data.description: Intensive play reading and discussion from early modern through contemporary

data.subject: THE
data.name: Research
data.description: Supervised individual investigation of special research projects. Credit will vary with the nature and scope of the project. May be repeated.

data.subject: THE
data.name: Theatre Internship
data.description: Supervised internship in a professional company in acting, directing, stage management, design, technical theatre, or theatre management. Repeatable one time for credit. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: THE
data.name: Senior Projects
data.description: Final preparation and performance or presentation of a creative project in the student's area of emphasis under the direction of a faculty advisor. Theatre majors only.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Intro to Design
data.description: An introduction to the concept of basic design elements and development of visual vocabulary as a prerequisite for Scenic, Lighting and Costume Design.  Lecture and Laboratory.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Stagecraft I
data.description: An introduction to construction techniques used in stage. Direct experience with wood and metal working tools, blueprint reading, and various materials including wood, metal, plastics and fabrics. Lecture and laboratory. Prerequisite: Permission of advisor.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Stage Lighting
data.description: Familiarization with stage lighting equipment, purposes, and aesthetics of stage lighting; development of an approach to designing lighting; practical experience in the use of equipment. Lecture and laboratory.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Stage Makeup
data.description: Facial analysis, color matching, makeup design and application techniques of makeup for the stage. Includes character analysis and history of makeup styles. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Tech Theatre Lab I
data.description: Supervised crew work in construction, painting, lighting, costuming, and running major productions. Required of Theatre majors.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Tech Theatre Lab II
data.description: Supervised crew work. Required of Theatre majors.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Tech Theatre Lab III
data.description: Supervised crew work. Required of Theatre majors.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Costume Technology
data.description: Practical instruction in costume construction and care, along with theatrical wardrobe organization. Prerequisite: Permission of the advisor.

data.subject: TPA
data.name: Costume Design I
